title: Global Warming Awareness To 10 Villages in India
description: This project will build a clean and green environment in our service villages providing supply of saplings and critical recycling support services to people in 10 villages in rural south India.  Environmental awareness through education and experience will be sponsored and monitored. 500 people will be the target, and they will spread the message far and wide.  Efforts at growing trees and fortressing atmosphere will be made through propagation of ideals of organic farming, health and hygiene.

title: Rescuing a child is just a phone call away
description: 40% of India’s population is below the age of 18. Of these,180 million children live in vulnerable conditions.They need to be rescued from unsafe situations where no one can reach them. CHILDLINE 1098 is a national, 24x7, emergency phone and outreach service for children in distress.Present in 162 cities and having responded to 19 million calls since its inception in 1996, it is the only helpline service offering a comprehensive package of child protection services to children in India.

title: Take 100 Waste Pickers in India Out of Poverty
description: Waste Ventures aims to permanently raise 100 waste picker families out of poverty in the next year by providing them with a blueprint for environmentally processing garbage, to increase incomes 3x and to put their children back into school.

title: Rehabilitate 300 disabled children in India
description: Vikash India plans to rehabilitate 300 disabled children in the villages in Puri District of Orissa, India by providing health services, assistive devices and inclusive education in the community.

title: Promotion of Small Family Norm in Rural India
description: In Balasore there are maximum numbers of backward families who belongs to mainly scheduled caste & other backward communities and their family size are very large.For which their socio economic condition are under develop.The reason behind it is level of awareness is very  low so the aim of the project here to access the family planning services at the door step of the rural community through awareness, behavior change,avail  of family planning services in Balasore district, Odisha.

title: Herbal medicine for isolated Indian village
description: Isolated residents of India's forests have no access to health care. Receiving training in the preparation of herbal remedies will improve their health and create an income-generating activity.

title: Tsunami Relief - Safe drinking water in India
description: Provide community water purification and disinfection systems for immediate tsunami relief as well as long-term rebuilding efforts in Tamil Nadu, and other tsunami-stricken areas in India.

title: Food and Clothing for Orphaned Children
description: Provide food and clothing for children who lost one or both parents in the tsunami.

title: Gift learning kits to rural girls
description: Educate Girls' learning kit emphasizes the use of activities and games to teach English, Hindi and Math to primary level grades. The kit provides every school with child-centric teaching material and training. Each kit includes a box of posters, playing cards, crayons and much more to make learning fun for children. We have already financed and implemented the project in close to 4500 schools in Pali and Jalore districts of Rajasthan.

title: Team Balika: Champions for girls' education!
description: Team Balika is a group of village based education volunteers that champion the cause of girls' education.  Members of Team Balika provide support and structure to the girl child in schools and also have a strong presence in the community, spreading awareness about girl child education. Their participation boosts enrollment, retention and learning outcomes for all girls. Team Balika animate the principle of, 'My village, my problem and I am the solution'.

title: Empower girls with life skills: Create Leaders!
description: We empower girl students to form groups called Bal Sabhas or a Girls' Councils, which are elected democratically by all students in the school. The girls engage in role playing and storytelling, which leads to an increase in the participation and helps in developing critical thinking, problem solving, communication, leadership skills and many more. This year, our target is to prepare 5,070 girls in 390 schools to lead their life and their communities.

title: Educate and Empower 450 girls in West Bengal
description: An entrenched system of patriarchy means that girls are grossly devalued and excluded in key arenas. Education is one such area. This project will empower girls through eradicating current barriers to their education - including young aged pregnancies and child marriage. Girls will be sensitised about their fundamental rights and a mass community awareness-raising campaign to redefine how they are viewed and treated.

title: Wooden Boats for Indian Fishermen
description: Provide boats and nets to help Indian fishermen return to work following the tsunami.

title: Donate to kids of domlur govt school
description: Dell employees have been volunteering in the schools G.H.P.S. Appareddy Palya (kannada), G.H.P.S. Jogu Palya (Tamil) , G.H.P.S. Jogu Palya (Urdu) schools. The kids are children of day laborers and have requirement of basic reading and writing materials. Dell employees during the interaction with the children in the schools routinely come across situation where there is a need that they can fulfill individually. They can do so by funding Sikshana through Global Giving website.

title: Vikasini: educating girls of urban Indian slum
description: In a slum where girls are historically uneducated and relegated to a life of hard labor, the new Vikasini girls' school is shaping bright futures and must grow to meet overwhelming enrollment

title: Million Moms Fund
description: The Million Moms Challenge is a call to action to engage a million Americans with millions of moms in the developing world around issues that impact pregnancy, childbirth and children's health. The goal is to create a global community, building on the common dream that every mother shares for her child:  a healthy pregnancy, a safe birth and a baby who will survive and thrive.

title: Setu Shiksha Jyoti Kendra Salarpur Village Noida
description: Formal Education for 60 children in an semi rural area, Children belonging to poor families- 40 girls and 20 boys. Parental occupation ranges from Labourers,maid servants, ragpickers, rickshaw oullers etc. Aim is to : a) To educate the underprivileged children in Village b) To create a better environment for the weaker section of the society  c) To develop a sense of Humanity.

title: Life skills training of 300 girls in Mumbai slums
description: The project will develop and enhance life skills of 100 poor girls in Mumbai's slums by creating opportunities for improving status of health, education and participation in public life. 200 more will be reached and motivated thru fairs, discussions and other events. 5 Girls' resource centers will provide safe spaces to provide training in skills and help them organize to become change agents. Mobile library, workshops, educational visits and health camps will lead to their capacity building.

title: Provide Education to 100 Disabled children
description: The project aims to provide nutrition and a safe haven along with quality education to the underprivileged children in the remote areas of Karnataka. The effort is made to address the issues of illiteracy, child labor and drop out from school faced by the underprivileged children in Karnataka through the inclusive education model.

title: Enhance health of 900 SaltPan Women in South India
description: 14% of India's and 70% of Tamilnadu's Salt production is from Thoothukudi. It has lot of underground saline water, extracting salt from 1500 salt pans. There are more than 7000 women working. These women work from 7a.m to 4p.m under the hot sun. As a result they suffer from various health Hazards (Defects in eyes, skin & wounds in feet). We will enhance the health conditions of selected workers through medical camps & Trainings, Eye camps, Referral for eye surgery, Provision of protective gears.
Chevaliar J.L.P. Roche Victoria K.S.G. Memorial Trust Society

title: Promotion of organic farming in Thoothukudi, India
description: This project will work with 300 farmers in promoting organic farming. South Asia's largest chemical fertilizer industry is in Thoothukudi,so the usage of chemical fertilizer has gone up significantly. Therefore the soil has lost its fertility. The Chemical fertilizers affects the health of the public.We plan to implement various interventions through Organic training center, Organic pharmacy, vermi composting, Printing and issue of Brochures and Establishment of Organic village.
Chevaliar J.L.P. Roche Victoria K.S.G. Memorial Trust Society

title: Safe Drinking Water For 200 People in India
description: Arsenic tainted water tragically affects 13 million people in West Bengal, India. Arsenic poisoning leads to lesions, diarrhea, vomiting, cancers &, often, death. This Blue Planet Network project is funding our member, Project Well, to build arsenic-free wells & provide hygiene education in Nadia, a district in West Bengal. Project Well has successfully worked with villages in West Bengal since 2001.  Clean water leads to better community health and more children, esp. girls, back in school.

title: SURAKSHA: HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care in India
description: Community intervention for prevention of HIV/AIDS amongst disenfranchised women in India and care and support of PLHA.

title: Conserve bats in International year of bats, India
description: Bats play important part in ecosystem.They play an important role by eating insects (Eg.mosquitoes and crop pests) and pollinating plants.As a result of superstition and fear,many bat species are threatened by poisoning and habitat destruction.We aim to protect their habitats by educating community to understand and ecological services.We will create awareness through Seminars,Workshops,Documentaries and competitions.We have planned to build bat houses in order to protect the endangered species.
Chevaliar J.L.P. Roche Victoria K.S.G. Memorial Trust Society

title: Protect 1,500 children in Orissa, India from abuse
description:
This project aims to protect vulnerable children, such as street children, child labourers, and children of migrant families, from risks of abuse and exploitation and reduce infant mortality, malnutrition and child hunger in Orissa, India.

The project will do this through rehabilitation and reintegration of separated children back to their families and communities; training in safe sexual & reproductive health practices; and advocating for government entitlements for education and healthcare.

title: Nourishment for HIV/AIDS Infected Indian Children
description: This project is for providing high value and fresh nutritious food, counseling & guidance and regular health check up for 120 HIV/AIDS infected children in and around Madurai District in Tamil Nadu state, India. The nutritious food contains Carbohydrates, Fats, Proteins, Vitamins, and Minerals for daily diet to the target children and also the project has to provide counseling and guidance for their prospects and future career.

title: Empower 100 unprivileged Indian children
description:
Pagdandi ('narrow trail' in Hindi) is an alternative educational space for the children of Jagdamba Camp, a slum community in New Delhi.
Since 2009, this project has reached hundreds of children from the age of 5.
Pagdandi's volunteers are trained students and professionals who engage these children in activities that ensure their overall development and character building.

title: Feed 50 children of Hiv/Aids patients in India
description: This project helps 50 children of the poor people affected by HIV/AIDS, and get hospitalisation in Madurai, district, Tamilnadu, India. Their children becomes orphans and left in the streets. We Madura Trust for Community Development, bring those children, make them stay in a Children's home run by us in a village in the outskirts of Madura city. We feed them and protect them from all sorts of exploitation until their parents come and take them to their homes.

title: Rescuing a child is just a phone call away!
description: 40% of India's population is below the age of 18. Of these,180 million children live in vulnerable conditions.They need to be rescued from unsafe situations where no one can reach them. CHILDLINE 1098 is a national, 24x7, emergency phone and outreach service for children in distress.Present in 183 cities and having responded to 19 million calls since its inception in 1996, it is the only helpline service offering a comprehensive package of child protection services to children in India.

title: Open Kindergarten Centres in 40 villages in 2013
description: Hippocampus Kindergarten and after school Primary Education Centres were launched in villages in 2011 to provide good quality education and a meaningful learning experience. From 82 villages in 2012 we aim to open 40 more Kindergarten Centres in newer villages by June 2013. Our project aims to provide early learning which is critical during this cognitive and emotional developmental period in a child's life and is often not available in villages.

title: Building Medical Camps for Mineworkers in India
description: Unsafe working conditions in the mines of Rajasthan lead to high numbers of silicosis and tuberculosis.  Often fatal, the building of medical camps is critical to the survival of the mineworkers.

title: Medicines to 200 terminal cancer patients in India
description:
Karunashraya, based in Bangalore, provides free palliative care to terminally ill cancer patients. Through this project you can alleviate pain and suffering due to terminal cancer, to patients being cared for at Karunashraya. 

Most of our patients are from very poor economic background and your contributions will help ease pain and suffering during the last days of their lives.

title: Give Smile to a Child by Providing Shelter
description: We are running a childline(1098) project, it is basically a toll free number for children in need and care. During our interventions with children we find so many children who don't have home to live. They are residing on railway station, streets, bus stand etc. Our city also don't have any govt. supported orphanage. So these children at times reside at out office.

title: Wipe The Tears of Girls
description: Rescue, Rehabilitation & Repatriation of girls, victims of human trafficking sold for forced prostitution. girls are underprivileged & deprived of human rights. we rescue & reintegrate them in respectable society

title: CRHP Project Villages
description:
Over the past 40 years, CRHP has worked in over 300 project villages across India, directly impacting the lives of millions of the poorest of the poor and marginalized. Currently, it works with 45 villages within a 50 kilometer radius of the CRHP Campus in Jamkhed, Dist. Ahmednagar, Maharashtra. 
We have successfully raised 17K USD for the first year of commitment and would like to raise the rest of the 28K USD for the 5 years that it takes to implement self-sustaining programs in a village.

title: Educate to 150 disabled send schooling in India
description: The Institute for the Handicapped and Backward People will provide free education through schooling for children with disabilities who are healing from the poorest sections of society in West Bengal and also provide for the girl children with disabilities free meals,cloth,uniform,book,medicine artificial equipments etc.
INSTITUTE FOR THE HANDICAPPED AND BACKWARD PEOPLE

title: Give life to 40 MentallyRetardedchildren in India
description: The project will ensure an enabling and inclusive lead to the Mentally Retarded Children in India through support and care taking services at the existing home.
Trust for Rural Uplift and Education (TRUE)

title: Improve school learning for 40,000 children!
description: We plan to implement a proven 1-year training program to significantly improve the teaching skills of 100 rural school teachers in Karnataka, India.  This will benefit 40,000 underprivileged children on a sustained basis.

title: Setup 175 computers-5 schools-3000 students India
description: In February 2012, TSC will set up 175 computers in 5 school labs in the Hyderabad, India area serving 3,000 students. This project, a partnership with IDEX, a social enterprise fellowship program that helps affordable non-government schools be sustainable while serving low-income children previously not in school.  IDEX will help maintain the computer labs and provide curriculum/teaching support. TSC will send15 US high school students and 3 chaperones to India to create the networked labs

title: Sponsor & Educateion support for children in India
description: Through this project, we will provide Education,Uniform, Dresses, Nutritious food, Health care, Moral Education, Counseling and Insurance for 100 Disabled, Orphaned, Vulnerable,  Mentally challenged children in India.

title: Empowering 1000 Persons in Self Care in India
description: 181,000 persons affected by leprosy in India have loss of sensation in their hands and feet making them prone to injuries leading to impairments, disabilities and disfigurement, further leading to stigma and discrimination. 1000 persons in West Bengal will be trained in self-care, empowering them to take care of their anesthetic hands and feet resulting in ulcer healing, reducing disfigurement and stigma which will give them an opportunity to be self-reliant.

title: Educate & empower 3,600 kids in Jharkhand, India
description:
In a region of largely tribal & uneducated population, this project aims to enable and support communities to educate all children thus achieving 100% enrollment & retention of kids for 10 years in school.

India Literacy Project (ILP) partnering with ChetnaVikas, an effective local NGO is working in 20 villages (Dumka district)  allowing families to dream a better life via education/rights awareness, to show them that education is the best investment for their future & to live beyond serfdom.

title: Support 100 children to obtain quality education
description: Annai Trust plans to provide or to receive quality education to the children of Physically challenged parents who are the most vulnerable section in the society in Coimbatore.PWD people are not able to meet their basic needs since they get very low income or surviving without any income.educating thier child is not at all possible;providing free study materials,tution fees  to the children and Vocational training to the PWD parents with financial assistance will assure thier betterment.

title: Special chairs for 100 children with disabilities
description:
There are  increasing number of children with disabilities who are not receiving the appropriate developmental aids they need due to financial hardship. 

Mobility India develops these aids which help a child to achieve its developmental milestones like sitting, standing and walking. These aids like corner seat, special chair, standing frame, peg board provide support and also allows the child to have enough freedom to move and explore.

title: Educate 100 girl children in a Tribal area, India
description: The project Nanhi Kali ensures 10 years of quality education with guaranteed learning outcomes for underprivileged girl children in tribal, conflict afflicted, rural and urban slums in India. Currently it empowers over 75,000 girl children through 9 states by providing them with academic, material and social support. The project helps in improving the enrollment in Schools, curtailing the high drop out rate of girl children and aims to strengthen the existing education system in India.
K.C Mahindra Education Trust - Project Nanhi Kali

title: Educate and Empower the Blind through Technology
description: Funded by three Blind who are visually challenged. Snehadeep runs an education program in internet and other new media for the Visually Challenged. Every year 50 to 75 young adults are accepted in this program and are supported all the way to employment. The main purpose of this project is to provide a computer literacy rehabilitation program for the Visually Impaired. Through this project they can build up their ability to independently access information using a Computer and the Internet,

title: Sponsor a education of 50 children's for a year
description: This project will help the poor, needy children to have uniforms,shoes,educational materials like books,note books,study materials,ect. The target children would have the benefit of enjoying the finer points of educational life and would not be discriminated or disadvantaged. Good education always keeps the holistic well being of an entire society.

title: EMPOWER INDIAN TRIBAL ADOLESCENT GIRLS
description: BSWI's training network brings life-changing education on health, livelihoods and family finance to hundreds of adolescent girls and women in self-help groups across rural Bengal. BSWI provides 100% of its loans to women, who are most in need of financial services. BSWI intends to create growing opportunities for adolescent girls through elementary education and vocational training project to help 2000 poor deprived tribal adolescent girls equipped with business skills and school educacation.

title: Fund Great Schools For Low Income Kids Worldwide
description: Help all children achieve a great education. EdVillage supports transformational school leaders to open excellent schools for the most impoverished communities around the world. This project supports the launch of new college prep schools in the townships of South Africa and the slums of India.

title: The Livelihood of Waste Pickers in Bangalore
description: Creating conditions through which waste pickers can earn sustainable livelihoods in urban service delivery

title: Empowering 50 South Asian Youth In Peace Activism
description: South Asia Peace Alliance plans a  5 day Training  in India for 50 Youth from selected youth from Member organizations from across South Asia from Afghanistan to Bangladesh(SAARC countries).  This includes live participation in historic Jan Satyagraha Campaingn 2011-12 of Ekta Parishad. (Year long Gandhian actionIn India.) and non-violent training.

title: Adopt An Elephant Calf
description: This project provides foster parent care for orphaned elephant calves and prepares them for release back to the wild. Generous donations has helped raise $11430 to support Philip Dev and Rani's rehabilitation expenses for the last year. An elephantine thank you from IFAW-WTI! We are now raising funds for Philip and Rani for the new year 2013. Both of them are around 2 years now and their individual milk intake averages 21 liters in 24 hours. These young ones need a lot of taking care of!

title: Better Learning situation for children in 15 villa
description: The quality of Education and learning environment for 750 children in 15 villages in Sivagangai District will be enhanced with better recreation, learning atmosphere and aware of their rights.
BETTER ENVIRONMENT FOR EVERYBODY IN THE SOCIETY(BEES)

title: Environmental Standards for Lead Battery Plants
description: The objective of the Better Environmental Sustainability Targets (BEST) Certification is to reduce emissions from lead battery plants and recyclers to prevent lead poisoning in developing countries.
National Referral Centre for Lead Poisoning

title: Redesigning Destinies: Women Changing Their Worlds
description: MarketPlace is a leading textile Fair Trade nonprofit organization. It provides access to global markets for low-income Indian women by using design to bridge the gap between skills and markets.

title: India: Rainwater Harvesting
description: Rainwater Center implements rainwater harvesting to relieve charitable insititutions from overhead costs of buying water for inmates.

title: New Year's gifts for 4800 street kids in India
description: Every year, Food for Life Vrindvan raises funds to give thousands of desperately poor children in the area around Vrindavan, Uttar Pradesh  some basic necessities that will help keep them warm and healthy through India's cold winter months and provide a little bit of joy. For just $10, you can give two children something to smile about by providing each with a schoolbag that contains tooth paste and tooth brush, a wool cap and scarf, a jar of Vaseline, some sweet treats and small toys.

title: Water Security on the Parched Lands of the Thar
description: Assists the needy rural population in the Thar Desert region, India, in conserving runoff water from the limited rainfalls for a continuous supply of potable water in an exceedingly arid setting.

title: Digital Tablets-Tools for The Yuwa Classroom
description: Computer tablets are tools that provide a unique and interactive experience within the classroom.  Give Yuwa students the tools that encourage engagement and stimulate learning.  5 tablets impact 50 students within the classroom.

title: REHABITILATION OF THANE CYCLONE VICTIMS IN S.INDIA
description: The most terrible " Cyclone Thane" crossed between south India, Tamilnadu coastal districts with wind speeds at 120 km per hour Leaving a major destruction and taking death of 44 lives , uprooting lakhs of trees & major damaging roads Cyclone Thane gives us the lesson that community was assault even though the State Govt. warned the community many times The place has been hit by Tsunami (2004) and Thane (2011) It is our foremost aim to make the community ready everthrough any Disasters arise
Chevaliar J.L.P. Roche Victoria K.S.G. Memorial Trust Society

title: skills to 1500 disabled & underprivilege youth
description: "CHHASE Computer education" and Fashion school is a community outreach training program for less privileged disabled and youth, to enhance their skills, abilities and personalities. There is high income in Sewing business and demand for computer literates as companies hire more. Thus 1500 under privileged disabled and Unable to continue further education adults in our area need sewing & computer education in order to keep pace with time and society.
Community Health, Housing and Social Education (CHHASE)

title: Help eye screening for 50000 children in India
description: The project will screen 50000 children between the age group of 5-18 years in two district (Bidar & Gulbarga) in northern Karnataka for any of the several causes of childhood blindness and low vision and children requiring further intervention are referred to the base hospitals.

title: Provide affordable water to villagers in Kerala
description: Rainwater for Humanity provides clean water to improve community health, increase financial savings and empower women in the Kuttanad region of Kerala, India. Our program develops a sustainable approach to water scarcity in partnership with the M S Swaminathan Research Foundation by financing the construction of rainwater harvesting structures, training women to manage tank networks, and implementing a financially independent vending model.

title: Reduce Poverty for Indigenous Rat Catchers
description: 3 million indigenous rat-catching tribals in India suffer from poverty through use of an inefficient and  hazardous traditional rat-catching method. New technology/plan is safer and more profitable.
Centre for Development of Disadvantaged people

title: Free Education Material for Poor Children
description: Education is the primary source for children to keep their life in safe way. This project provides education material to poor children upto elementary section. Basic education material required for their studies without any interruption is our goal.

title: Empower 200 Women to Become Entrepreneurs In India
description: SAMRUDHI provides a livelihood based financial services to 200 women to take up income generating activities enabling them to become economically self-reliant.

title: Make 100 girls Free Forever in Jalpaiguri
description: Made By Survivors, in partnership with Women's Interlink Foundation, is providing shelter and employment in Jalpaiguri, West Bengal, India to 100 female survivors of sex trafficking. $400 will provide a 6 month training stipend for a survivor, setting her on a path to a new life in which she can economically provide for herself safely from abuse and bondage.

title: Help restore 500 waste pickers' burnt down homes
description: Early in the morning about a week ago a fire broke out in the waste picker slum called Ghazipur Dairy. Here hundreds of families live in plastic and bamboo shacks, meaning that the fire spread quickly. In only a couple of hours more than 350 families had lost their homes and all their belongings. This, during the coldest season of the year. Please help us support these families to rebuild their homes and protect them against the cold.

title: Create 5,000 Youth Nature Leaders in India
description: 45% of India's land is degraded, air pollution is increasing in all its cities and it is losing its rare plants and animals more rapidly than before.Protect India's nature now!  The Green Rhinos Program will create 5,000 youth nature leaders in India by December 31, 2016. Young people will implement nature conservation projects and be a force for nature!  Till now more than 1200 Green Rhinos have been created.
Association for Social and Environmental Developme

title: Made By Survivors Jewelry Centers - Training
description: Made By Survivors trains survivors of human trafficking to make artisan silver and gold jewelry.  This skill provides income, independence, increased social status, & confidence to dream & hope.  Survivors of sexual slavery go from having the most shameful job in society to having one that is valued & admired.  Made By Survivors has 3 jewelry centers in Kolkata & Mumbai & Jalpaiguri, India and one in Nepal.    $400 provides 6 months of paid training, setting the survivor on a path of freedom.

title: Educate 100 Disabled Children In India
description: Children with disability are 5 times more likely to be out of school than average. This raises the lack of education in them. Our project is aimed to educate 100 disabled children who are residing in the rural areas of Karnataka, India. This project will provide them accommodation and nutritious food at free of cost. Through education, they will be protected from poverty and related exploitations thus contributing to the full investment of their time and energy on education and growth.

title: Educating the Children of Mineworkers in India
description: Many mining communities in Rajasthan are without schools.  Illiteracy is rampant and breaking out of poverty is close to impossible.  Building schools and educating children is the only solution.

title: Educate & Empower 50 girls from Rural India
description: Will Urvi realize her dreams? That's a question only you can answer. Because only your support will decide whether she'll take the next big step of secondary education and realise her true potential. Project Nanhi Kali ensures 10 years of quality education for underprivileged girl children in tribal, rural and urban slums in India. Currently it empowers over 75,000 girl children like Urvi through 9 states by providing them with academic, material and social support
K.C Mahindra Education Trust - Project Nanhi Kali

title: SISHU VIDYA-Education-40 Visually challenged kids
description: SISHU VIDYA works on " Right to Education".  This project focuses on inclusive pattern which integrates Visually impaired children in the mainstream school at an early stage. This provides education to the visually impaired child and enables them to compete with normal children. The impact is no child is denied of education due to visual disability, increase in the Literacy rates of the Visually impaired, facilitates higher and quality education,Leads to empowerment and economic independence
The National Association for the Blind

title: Support320 Poor/disabled Old People In Bihar,India
description: ADD has always been thinking of doing something better for the poor/disabled helpless old people  whom nobody is there to take care of and ADD implemented it by providing food stuffs, clothing, Nutritional support and medical care with medicine for 2 months to such poor old people in Bihar, India.

title: Prevent Early Marriage-Educate an Indian girl
description: Most of the teenaged rural girls of Bengal experience the agonies as child-wives. Their dreams to enjoy the girlhood are never materialised owing to endemic poverty. They suffer abysmally with teen-pregnancy, malnutrition and oppression. We would equip many such girls with quality education by providing books, scholarship grants, nutritious food and health coverages. The project would mainstream the girls and support their families with small enterprises to make poverty and girl-abuse a history.

title: Empowerment of urban communities living in slums
description:
Jana Sahayog is an Urban Resource Centre established in 1995 by SAMUHA to work with the urban poor communities as a resource centre in the state of Karnataka. It became an independent community-based organisation in August 2003 by registering itself under the Societies Registration Act. Jana Sahayog believes that people living in slums, by their very experiences, understand their problems best, and they themselves have the capabilities to arrive at solutions. It has now transformed as an organization that is managed and led by people living in slums. In 2002, the amendment of the Slum Act paved the way for people living in slums to organize themselves to achieve positive results for change.

The program stems from the context of steady withdrawal of the State from its responsibility to provide entitlements to all citizens irrespective of social, economic, and ethnicity.  The privatisation of agencies providing basic necessities of health, food, shelter, education and security, and the urban poor communities being steadily being pushed to impoverishment, loss of control over their meagre resources and deprivation on all fronts. The State’s treatment of the urban poor is characterised by insufficient political will, rampant corruption and top-down approach of planning with complete ignorance of the ground realities. The emerging political climate in the country that sees new alignment of dominant caste-class forces coupled with the new economic trend of liberalisation and privatisation, has further alienated the urban poor from the development that the country claims in the global arena. Combined with acute agrarian crisis, destruction of traditional livelihoods and large scale appropriation of resources has further pushed the marginalised communities towards destruction. The above scenario is very relevant for the state of Karnataka which has developed and marketed as one of the most lucrative destinations for foreign investment, albeit the lack of pro-poor development. 

The most prominent strategy of the project is to empower the affected people, the residents of urban community in this case, with the goal to enable people living in slums to come out of social discrimination, deprivation and to uphold multi-cultural social justice and caste-lessness through their own fora. The specific objectives are as follows: to create conducive atmosphere for enhancing awareness and conscientisize deprived communities; to enable the youth from deprived communities to become aware of their role in society by taking leadership role; to strengthen people’s institution of deprived communities; and to facilitate conducive atmosphere for integrating and promoting culture of deprived communities. Towards these ends, activities like organization and mobilization of workers, to include unorganized workers, temporary labourers, street vendors, and other marginalized workers’ groups into the peoples institution; seminars, lobby on state and central policies affecting the deprived communities; research on peoples culture and traditions of Karnataka; and identifying and promoting slum culture which is term used to define the people’s culture—will be undertaken. This project is being supported by ICCO as it fits well with its program for the region on grassroots democratization.
Human Rights Education and Urban Slum Resource Centre
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Livelihood Opportunities and right to food
description:
India is classified by the Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations as a low-income, food-deficit country. 350 million people in India face hunger, the largest number of hungry people worldwide. 57 million children in India are malnourished and make up a third of the world’s 146 million undernourished children (UNICEF report titled "Progress for Children: A Report Card on Nutrition" May 2006). Malnutrition also increases during early childhood, particularly for girls, reflecting persistent social discrimination against girl child (National Family Health Survey-NFHS-2 in 1998-99 and NFHS-3, 2005-06). Government of India suggests that 79% children are suffering from Anaemia and 46% children are undernourished. 36% of both rural and urban Indians live below the poverty line according to the calorie intake (Tendulkar Committee Report, 2009). World Bank estimates 380 million people are living below the poverty line (2010).

The project goal is to improve access to food and food resources for selected groups whose right to food have been violated. This program will focus on documentation and monitoring of right to food violation cases. Aim and FIAN in India have already been successful in contributing to the ongoing struggles of the right to food, nutrition, work, land, social security and forest movements in the country and have also developed a strong organisational structure. FIAN India has documented violations of the right to food and elaborated a parallel report on the status of implementation of the right to food in India, which has been submitted to the UN in May 2008, and the officers of the president, prime minister and the commissioners in India.

Through this project AIM & FIAN can peruse the Indian Government to expedite cases and projects within the target timeframe. The beneficiaries of this project will include the vulnerable and marginalised communities living in India, who are the victims of violations of the right to food and living under chronic food insecurity circumstances, particularly women and children; CBOs (Community Based Organizations) and CSOs (Civil Society Organizations) working closely with these vulnerable communities are another group of key actors targeted; government agencies, parliamentarians, politicians and national and international human rights institutions in particular the National Human Rights Commission, Food Commissioners of Supreme Court, the judiciary/ lawyers; and different stakeholders are being targeted as key actors and supporters. ICCO’s  Food & Nutrition Security Programme for India and its support to this project will be meaningful to the marginalised communities in India as it will pave way for them to have improved food security.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Advocacy on Dalit rights
description:
Project overview>> The Reds-Tumkur (REDS) development organization has been working since 1983 in the Tumkur district of Karnataka state. REDS began its work with the economically weaker section of the society and gradually shifted to working primarily with the Dalit community due to the prevalence of caste-based discrimination. During two previous ICCO-funded project phases, REDS has worked to enhance the dignity and self-esteem of Dalit communities through actions to enhance the acceptance of Dalit culture and advocate for the enforcement of their constitutional rights. REDS has also been successful in the formation of the effective linkages with other advocacy initiatives at the national and international levels and mobilizing public funds for the development of the Dalit community. 
Project activities and outputs>> This follow up project aims to strengthen and scale up existing interventions by enhancing collaboration with government authorities and strengthening the community organization Dalit Panchayat to safeguard the fundamental rights of Dalits and improve access to basic services. Other activities include an existing project to provide low cost solar lamps that provides training to local youth on repair and maintenance of the lamps, and support for climate change adaptation and mitigation.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Promotion of Sustainable Agriculture & Diversified Livelihoo
description: Project overview>> Accion Fraterna Ecology Centre (AF) was founded by Father Vincent Ferrer in 1982 to promote people’s empowerment through drought management, environmental development and policy advocacy. The center’s flagship Participatory Watershed Development Program, which has been implemented since 1986 in Anantapur district, is perhaps the largest participatory watershed programme by an NGO in India. The program is implemented in more than 300 villages, covering about 1.35 lakh ha of farm land and 60,000 farmers, and disseminates a range of ecologically sound practices including soil and moisture conservation, rain water harvesting, horticulture and biogas production, as well as the institutional development of community organizations, and gender and social equity. Since 2007, AF has focused on promoting sustainable agriculture and has been a leading voice in calling for a favorable policy environment to support people-centered watershed development and rural employment in the state of Andhra Pradesh. This project focuses on the drought prone and semi-arid district of Ananttpur, where malnutrition, illiteracy, lack of access to healthcare and other basic services, and caste and gender discrimination, are higher than the state average. Due to the difficulty of earning a livelihood, which makes many households slip into a spiral of indebtedness, poverty and farmer suicides, large numbers of farmers are abandoning agriculture in search of employment opportunities in cities. The project aims to work closely with the poorest farmers, women, children, the elderly and the disabled to address their concerns in an integrated way, hence contributing to the empowerment of the most marginalized segments of the population. Through the project, AF aims to provide support to 57,400 families in 214 villages and 8 mandals project to enhance food and nutritional security, access to health and education, diversification of income sources, gender and social equity, and eco-friendly farming practices.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: PIIRD V
description:
Project background>> The Centre for Community Economics and Development Consultants Society (CECOEDECON) was initiated by a group of young social workers to provide relief to the flood victims in Jaipur district in 1982. Over the past three decades the organization has become one of the leading NGOs in Rajasthan. CECOEDECON is currently implementing the fifth phase of the Participatory Initiative for Integrated Rural Development (PIIRD) program, which aims to facilitate the engagement of partner organizations and other stakeholders to ensure the rights of the most vulnerable communities through building partnerships, networking, advocacy and exchanging learning at micro and meso level. ICCO has supported CECOEDECON in this consortium project since 2000 and will specifically support PIIRD V interventions related to aspects of livelihood security, economic justice, basic rights and institutional development.
Project overview>> This project will be implemented in more than 500 villages across three districts of Rajasthan (Jaipur, Tonk and Baran) and aims to directly reach 250,722 individuals (50% women). Besides these, 349 elected women representatives from the five blocks covered by the project will be engaged as direct partners of the project. Through related interventions by other CSOs, the project aims to reach a further 585,000 inhabitants in other regions of the state, of which at least 50% will be women. The project has four specific objectives: (i) ensure improved access to productive resources; (ii) ensure sustainability of natural resource base through climate change adaptation; (iii) reduce risk in agriculture based livelihoods from extreme weather events and facilitate community based efforts for risk reduction; and (iv) improve access to off-farm and non-farm livelihoods.
Expected outcomes>> The following results are expected, linked to the above objectives:
Objective 1: Communities become aware of their land rights; communities undertake the process of documenting and claiming their rights; there is greater access to financial services and social service scheme; there are enhanced linkages and participation in campaigns and movements for policy interventions related to food security at state and national level.
Objective 2: Crop productivity is sustained under water stress conditions; timely seed availability at village level; enhanced nutritional security at household level; variability of livestock productivity is reduced; farmers are aware of climate change adaptation measures undertaken in similar agro-climatic regions.
Objective 3: Communities become aware of insurance schemes; communities are able to articulate demands related to crop and livestock insurance; increased numbers of families are linked to insurance schemes; access to disaster relief is ensured for affected families; task forces develop the capacity for disaster response; better synergy and coordination among CBOs and state government for disaster management.
Objective 4: Women and girls receive computer training; youth are trained as business facilitators; off-farm and non-farm income generation activities are established at household level.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Gramya Lambada Girls School
description:
Gramya was founded in 1993 by a group of women activists to address gender equality. Initially, it provided gender training to NGO staff across Andhra Pradesh to mainstream gender issues.  Since 1997 it has been involved in field interventions in Nalgonda district. Currently the organization is working to promote child rights with a focus on the girl child, as well as survival and education and empowerment of women. Since 1997 Gramya has been working in Nalgonda district and four additional districts to reach out to  women, girls and families from the Lambada community, to ensure education for girls and prevent violence against women. Gramya intervened in Chandampet Mandal to stop female infanticide and sale of girl babies.   The bridge school was set up as a response to provide safety and education to the most vulnerable girls among the Lambada community. The bridge school has acted as a presence to motivate Lambada families to send girls to school. With Gramya campaigns ongoing on a regular basis, the Lambada community has increasingly sent girls to school. After living with Gramya for one or two years, the girls are mainstreamed annually into the government system. 

Some of the girls who have completed high school come back to Gramya for hostel facilities to complete their higher education. Currently there are 22 girls who are enrolled in college. Gramya has reached out to 4470 children, where 2492 are girls. Gramya has ensured that children have adequate competence levels of learning for the class in which they are studying (primary school). Towards this, teacher training is provided to government volunteer teachers who act as a support to the government system in the 50 villages in which Gramya is working. Additionally, in the last three years, Gramya has supported 54 women facing domestic violence. Further they have trained more than 1300 women leaders from the government. It is projected that its self-help group programme will reach about 278 villages in five districts, to assess the condition of Lambada adolescent girls. Gramya will also be working in 50 villages intensively and more than 320 villages indirectly.ICCO’s support to this project resonates with its program for India on Children at Risk.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Children As an instrument of Social Change
description:
The NGO, Community and Rural Development Society (CARDS) was founded in 1979. The founding members of CARDS are social activists of Andhra Pradesh and grassroots level leaders. A strong support during the start phase came from the Lutheran, Salvation Army, Baptist and Roman Catholic communities.  The strategy of CARDS is pursuing its mission to conceive, design, plan and implement programs with Dalits to push for their equity and equality. CARDS has  already been working on this issue for the last eight years in 20 districts in the state of Andhra Pradesh and other states, including Karnataka, Maharashtra and Orissa. CARDS is also part of the National Movement to Educate and Empower Dalit Children (NEED) from the year 2006.

The core problem being addressed in this project is illiteracy. The project aims at eliminating illiteracy among children aged between 5-15 years hailing from Dalit and the tribal communities. With the support from Kerk in Actie, CARDS has been working for the past three years on the Balabata project towards these objectives. This project is being implemented in the Ranga Reddy District of Andhra Pradesh in 8 Mandals, constituting of 154 villages. It has been focusing on providing quality education to the children in rural areas aged 5-15 years old. A total of 180 Balabatas have been established in the past three years in the said district. The project aims at eliminating illiteracy among children below 5-15 years hailing from Dalit and the tribal communities. The project aims at maintaining the 180 Balabata schools established in the previous years, with its fourfold mission – “A path shown to children by the society, and also a path shown to the society by the children”: education through play way methods (songs and scripts); encouraging children to motivate their parents to start kitchen gardens at their homes; encourage children in clean and green activities; and enabling their parents to take up Income Generation Programme under Vision 2020. The programme draws inspiration from a verse in the Bible which states, “It was a child who has shown a path to Jesus Christ to feed the 5000 by offering what he has – Two fish and Five pieces of Bread.”  By introducing new way of life to Dalit Children through Balabata CARDS proposes to build up a new society – a society based on equality and fraternity."

Currently, there are 180 Development Organizers in the 180 Balabatas that have been established in the past three years in the project area. Regular training programs (3-5 days) are conducted for the Development professionals to equip them with skills to help them deal effectively with the school children. It is projected that during the duration of the project, 530 students will join in government residential schools to continue their education for 5th & 6th class. In the past three years 10,800 new students have joined in the Balabata schools. Out of these 5875 are now continuing their education in government schools while, the remaining 4925 children have joined local private schools. Among the new children joining the Balabata schools there are 2500 children who were child labours. Moreover, in the 154 villages nearly '18,397 families will be educated by the Balabata programme.
 
Also, there were 180 Mothers’ committee formed. The community was encouraged to take up the responsibility of educating the children and dealing with the needs of the villages. Networking with the government department was encouraged. It is interesting to note that Andhra Pradesh has shown positive performance in decreasing the percentage of Out of School Children from 5.9% to 4.1% in the last few years and programmes like the Balabata initiative has significantly contributed to the positive performance. ICCO’s support in this project is part of its program for India with the Children at Risk.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Consolidation Phase of the ABCD Project
description:
International Services Association (INSA) India was established in 1982, to fill the gap in rural access and equity to basic health and development care, in line with the Alma Ata Declaration.  It has been instrumental in facilitating over 700 NGOs and GOs in India, Nepal and Bangladesh to establish community participatory, cost effective multi-disciplinary programs that relate to priority challenges in enabling child survival and protection, directly and indirectly. This organization believes that Community Health and Development are two sides of one coin.  It has determined that multi-pronged interventions work effectively to break the inextricable link between HIV and AIDS-related stigma, discrimination and human rights violations, especially for children living and affected by HIV and AIDS. INSA India has the reputation of creating innovative pilot initiatives promoting dignity of personhood towards its vision of a ‘just society living with health and development’. 

The current project is a continuation of a previous project and the consolidation phase of the Approaches for Boosting Child Development and Empowerment (ABCDE) project. INSA India through the ABCDE initiative introduced priority for child protection programing in the urban slums of Bangalore from 2011 onwards. The prioritization of child protection, though urgently felt, is not mainstreamed into regular child care settings, in organizations working for child rights, and least of all in communities. A case in point, a baseline study in December 2010 conducted by INSA showed that none of the child care workers knew what the child helpline number is. Moreover, INSA identified 20 child care settings in Bangalore that are in vulnerable situations, together with local and state stakeholders and began the project in January 2011. The project implementation began in March 2011 after a thorough baseline and situational assessment. The nationwide program began in May 2011 after a thorough process of floating EOIs and selecting key lead organizations. Although the project is well on its way to completion as per the project contract, there is a felt need to consolidate the project for stronger outcomes and learning. More needs to be done to strengthen the gender sensitization component that is critical for sustaining child protection. By August 2012, through a series of direct interventions, 591 children in 29 child parliaments in Bangalore claimed child rights and protection through written petitions, approached local and municipal leaders to ensure that men with substance abuse do not throw used bottles into their school yards; that garbage is not dumped in their school compound; that child abuse is recognized and child protection is respected as a child right.  Through careful selection, 17 lead organizations were partnered with for strengthening resource pools for child protection in selected areas of India spanning 10 states. In addition 2988 leaders nationwide participated in half day, one day or two day child protection consultation using the EVERY-CHILD-OUR CHILD process through 58 workshops. INSA-India team participated in adaptations of the Juvenile Justice Act. Because of this, 17 organizations have undertaken a child protection capacity audit and are developing child protection policies. It is hoped that by December 2013, stronger child participation, visibility, evidence and collectivism for child protection will be strengthened locally in Bangalore and nationwide through INSA-India undertaking consolidation processes of community building, skills, research and convergence in child protection systems and programs. ICCO’s support to this project is part of its program for India on Children at Risk.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening Enabling Environment and Credibility Mechanism
description:
Project background: Voluntary Action Network India (VANI) is the largest apex body of voluntary organizations in the country, with a direct membership of 465 organizations and an indirect membership of over 5000 organizations, including 19 network federations. VANI has also become coordinating agency for strengthening similar national networks in other countries of south and south east Asia, and the Far East. VANI represents the sector’s concerns through advocacy and networking activities and sensitizing the government, media, and public, VANI has so far advocated and lobbied for simplification of Acts, Rules, and Regulations pertaining to voluntary sector (Society Registration Act, Foreign Contribution Regulation Act & Income Tax Act) and taken measures to further strengthen the voluntary sector. The rationale for the current project is derived from the current scenario of rapidly changing environment for operations for NGOs in India, which threatens to restrict the operating space of civil society organizations. This changing landscape is characterized by, among other developments: a shift in development support for the voluntary sector from bilateral and flexible grants to the “tenderization” of development in which NGOs are seen as “efficient and cheap sub-contractors”; rising cases of harassment of NGOs because of their alleged involvement in the naxal (communist) activities in several states, including reduced access to local communities and false charges filed against NGO staff; growing public criticism of NGOs for misuse of tax provisions and poor functioning of the voluntary sector; and the lack of awareness among many NGOs of the changing legal and policy environment for the voluntary sector. In order to establish uniform practices amongst the NGOs and to improve internal governance, the government has announced plans to establish a national accreditation body to regulate the voluntary sector. VANI seeks to coordinate an effective response from the voluntary sector through setting up a self-regulated governance mechanism, based on a process of nationwide debate and research- based advocacy works.
Project overview: The specific objective of this project is to strengthen the capacities of the target 1000 voluntary sector small and medium sized organizations to handle relationship with government and private sector and create an enabling environment for their smooth functioning. In this way, VANI seeks to address the core factors that are contributing to the current negative environment by: (i) raising awareness of the challenges faced by the civil society as a result of the new developments in the sector; (ii) building the capacity of small and medium sized organizations to update their systems of internal governance so that the whole sector can move at one pace; (iii) contributing to the emergence of an effective institutional mechanism to ensure transparent and accountable governance within the NGO sector, which will enable them to raise the issue of good governance of public institutions; and (iv) continuing to disseminate training and specific input to capacitate NGOs to form effective partnerships with the corporate sector. An important component of the intervention is the development of strong thematic networks to enhance the profile of the voluntary sector as an influential player, both nationally and globally.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: 7th Comprehensive Plan
description:
ICCO and Seva Mandir share a long history of partnership which goes back to early 80’s.  Over the years, the organization has shown strong commitment in mobilizing communities and in addressing their development needs through various intervention strategies. It has grown not just as an organization in terms of capacity and knowledge but is also recognized at the national fora as one of the pioneer NGOs in India which have contributed to the cause of marginalized section of society.
Today, it continues to enable people to become agents of their own development by building institutional space and structure so that they will be empowered to make decisions for a life of security and dignity.

The program of Seva Mandir focuses, among others; on improving the economic position of the target groups (in particular through sustainable land use, improved water management and sustainable forest management).The ultimate goal is to make these beneficiaries self-reliant in the long run. Seva Mandir aims to achieve this by building and strengthening the capacities of the target users (through education, awareness and knowledge promotion), to include the target organizations, and other relevant structures in the society (through the empowerment of the poor, political participation).

In all its programs, whenever possible, Seva Mandir (with local authorities) allows the use of local funds. The organization is hoping that its programs be adopted and replicated by the government in providing services to the people. Currently, Seva Mandir is working in 6 rural blocks in Udaipur and Rajsamand districts in addition to selected slum areas within Udaipur City and one peri-urban settlement, Delwara.

In total, Seva Mandir reaches out to over 634 settlements (including slum areas), equivalent to around 75,000 families. While Seva Mandir works with all sections of the population, it is primarily concerned with empowering the most vulnerable– women, youth, children, and other disadvantaged sections of the population. 

In this particular project, Seva Mandir with the help of ICCO will: strengthen institutions; strengthen human capabilities; and improve livelihoods. This project also fits with ICCO program for India on Food Security.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: VBN- Engaging Markets- 2
description:
Project overview>> Vikas Bazar Network (VBN) is a coalition of 18 partners working for poverty alleviation through market-led livelihoods and value chain development in Jharkhand. The network has been supported by ICCO since 2006. Although the network was initiated to meet the growing challenges of dealing with markets and helping the poor to improve their income levels through value chain development, it has additionally taken up the task of facilitating linkages and building the capacities of partners to engage in market-led interventions. It also seeks to facilitate enhanced cooperation among its members for sustained impact.  The members of the network have decided to register VBN under the Society Registration Act 1860 in order to attract funding from varied sources. The network reached out to more than 13,000 farmers in the first phase of the “Engaging Markets” project. The second phase of the project will intensify interventions taken up in the first phase by undertaking various livelihood programs in Jharkhand. Moreover, this phase also looks into ways to make VBN a financially sustainable unit and to contribute to relevant decision making processes to foster inclusive value chain development. 
Project activities and outputs>> The main components of the project are: (i) Promoting livelihoods for 17,000 poorer households by 2013; Developing producer collectives and strengthening value chain coalitions; (iii) Institution building of VBN and capacity building of partner organizations; and (iv) Mobilizing other agencies for financial support.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Improving Adolescent Sexual Health to address HIV and AIDS
description:
Project background>> The Christian Medical Association of India (CMAI) is the health agency of the National Council of Churches in India and serves as an umbrella body for more than 330 member institutions including Christian Medical Colleges at Vellore and Ludhiana, secondary care hospitals such as St Stephens and Holy Family Hospital in Delhi and community programs such as CRHP Jamkhed, Maharashtra. Over 10,000 healthcare professionals are registered as individual members, working in the government, NGO and corporate sectors across the country. CMAI also has strong secular collaborations and work with governments and the civil society in almost every state providing services to the marginalized and the poor. CMAI started its initiatives to combat HIV/Aids in 1992 and has undertaken numerous large scale projects ranging from training of medical personnel on diagnosis and management of HIV/Aids, production of public awareness materials, establishing learning sites in four HIV/Aids prevalent states and (with support from ICCO) developing HIV/Aids policy guidance for churches. CMAI has also worked the field of adolescent health with schools in North and South India with a focus on life skills training for students and is currently in the process of developing an accreditation system for HIV Services in hospitals. 
Project overview>> The current project aims to develop a HIV/Aids prevention program for Manipur state, which has the third highest rate of seroprevalence in the country after Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu. Fear of disclosure and stigma lead most adolescents to make significant efforts to conceal their risky behaviors from families in particular, and society in general. Although there are well-established HIV and Hepatitis C co-infection epidemic among injecting drug users in Manipur, awareness is very poor. There is therefore an urgent need to build awareness about safe and unsafe drug use and sexual practices, as well as the location and availability of health services. With the support of SAN and Kerk in Actie, CMAI, in collaboration with one of its members, SHALOM, intends to sensitize adolescents about sexual and reproductive health and to identify and train volunteers and health care providers in counseling and care giving on this subject. The project will facilitate linkages with services within the government like the Adolescent Clinic in the state with constant consultation with the stakeholders. This will be one of the strategies to sustain the programme. Learning from CMAI and other youth intervention programmes will also be factored in the implementation of the project. The project will ensure that there is active participation from youth at various levels including planning, designing of module, implementation and monitoring of the program. This will be done through a process of dialogue. Through this process, change agents will be identified and encouraged to speak to and influence their peers. For more details on the organization  please visit http://www.cmai.org/
CMAI - CHRISTIAN MEDICAL ASSOCIATION OF INDIA

title: COFA- Strengthening Institutional Arrangements
description:
The current project with the Forum For Integrated Development (FFID) called Chetna attempts to create a sustainable participation of small and marginal farming households in markets, as well as initiating a profound change process to break through the long standing social exclusion of the poor, the power abuses across the system and to protect the fragile natural resource base to enable more just and fair participation of vulnerable groups in society. The project works with the economically and socially fragile region of Vidarbha, Telangana and South Odisha. The organization, that was initially focused on creating an exclusive value chain for organic cotton has not taken an integrated approach, which is a direct result of the learnings derived from the past project.

ICCO and Solidaridad jointly initiated the Chetna Organic & Fairtrade Cotton Supply Chain Intervention Program India in 2004 as a composite pilot on organic, non-pesticide management (NPM) and Fairtrade cotton supply chain development, mainly to address the agrarian crisis faced by small-holder cotton farmers in India. The Forum for Integrated Development (FFID) was chosen as the implementing partner for the Chetna project because of its experience in sustainable agriculture. In 2007, COFA was registered as an independent national level farmers’ support organization (as a society) with a multi-state representation of members from the smallholder farmers’ cooperatives from the states of Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Odisha, mainly to promote greater ownership among the smallholder farmers over the program. 

Over the years, Chetna has emerged as an expert on sustainable (organic, non-pesticide management) agriculture-based livelihood and in providing support to various other projects and agencies, and also in representing various organizations and advisory committees, both at national and international level. In this current project, FFID will support Chetna towards addressing the multi-dimensional challenges encountered by the smallholder farmers from rain-fed regions, through community led climate resilient sustainable agriculture livelihood systems. Considering the multi-dimensional problems of the small-holder farmers from the rain-fed regions, FFID has carved out strategic thrust areas for Chetna to implement the interventions comprehensively in an integrated manner. The interventions of the project will revolve on: sustainable farmer owned and managed institutions –and emerging as innovative enterprises and domain experts and /or expert resource centre; promotion of integrated farming systems (primarily in cotton); Germplasm conservation; sustainable management of natural resources; diversification of household livelihoods portfolio and entrepreneurship; value chain development; food safety/security and nutrition; and women and child welfare. These interventions are aimed at directly reaching and impacting 30,000 small-holder farming households, with 150,000 family members, primarily engaged in cotton cultivation from the rain-fed states in India, particularly Telangana region of Andhra Pradesh, South Western region of Odisha and Vidarbha region of Maharashtra.

The next three years are important for strengthening and consolidating the work of FFID and paving the way for sustaining the institutional mechanisms put in place by Chetna Organic. ICCO’s support to this project is in line with its Fair Economic program for India.

title: Passive Solar Housing
description:
Project overview>> Ladakh Ecological Development Group (LEDeG) is a grassroots NGO whose vision is to promote development policies that promote harmony with the existing cultural and environmental practices so as to encourage a sound and sustainable future for local communities in the trans-Himalayan cold desert region in the north east of the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. The region experiences a lot of sunshine during the day even if the temperature falls drastically during night in winter. LEDeG’s flagship renewables program has introduced a wide range of appropriate technologies based on adaptive research to ensure their suitability to local conditions and needs. These include micro-hydroelectric units, solar photo voltaic power plants, passive solar buildings, solar water heating systems, solar ovens and cookers, and hydraulic ram pumps, all geared towards providing sustainable off-grid energy solutions for the rural poor and reducing their dependence on fossil and biomass fuels.
Project activities and outputs>> This project aims to introduce passive solar housing (PSH) technology for 100 families in Leh and Kargil districts of Ladakh. The construction technique enables the harnessing of solar radiation during the winter to heat the interior of the building, through specially designed and insulated trombe walls (sun spaces) and large south-facing solarized windows for direct heat gain. Insulated roofs and floors help absorb and retain the heat and keep the rooms warm during the day and night. The project contributes to the objectives of ICCO’s Fair Climate Program Climate because the carbon emission levels of each PSH building will go down by a minimum 3.5 tons and the total emission reduction will be around 350 tons per year after the completion of the project. This is the direct result of reduction in carbon emission in the house and also the reduction in the extraction level of trees and bushes for space heating which enhances carbon sequestration.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Pan India LCF
description:
Low Carbon Farming (LCF) is one of the most unique initiatives not just by the Fair Climate Network (FCN) coalition but also as an initiative in India. It is especially unique given that in India, there are two other forms of farming which has dominated the society for the longest time:  mainstream agriculture and sustainable agriculture.
Mainstream agriculture is a popular farming system of choice, aggressively promoted by the government and industry. A direct and indirect state subsidy keeps it afloat not just in the form of subsidized seeds, fertilizer and crop insurance. It is also through the creation and maintenance of an infrastructure that provides transport, communication, electricity, timely supply of farm inputs, information, technical, financial and marketing support; plus the support prices that the State pays to procure. These are hard to resist since they address the dire cash needs of the farmers. On the other hand, small and poor peasants subsist by working as agricultural labourers on middle peasant lands for less than minimum wages, and by migrating during summer months. They come back with the onset of monsoons to scratch subsistence cultivation from small patches of scattered holdings, far away from the villages and hugging the hillsides, averaging less than optimal holding sizes. Although this is sustainable farming, it is beset with insufficient inputs, inadequate attention, uncertain monsoons and continuous drought; disenchantment of schooled youth in farming, or the non-participation of women in farming matters or decisions. 

The farm sector offers significant opportunities for carbon sequestration and emission reductions. Emissions from farming contribute 14% of global Greenhouse Gases. In India, farming contributes to 28% of the national GHG emissions. Low Carbon Farming practices offer farmers the opportunity to capitalize on the carbon market, as they shift to agricultural methods that are more sustainable, involve lower input costs and result in emission reduction and sequestration by sinks.

Several Fair Climate Network Members are grassroots NGOs involved in Sustainable Agriculture (SA). They have developed technologies that go by various terms like organic or natural farming, chemical free cultivation, low external input sustainable agriculture (LEISA), permaculture, etc. These have resulted in shifts in cropping patterns and cultivation practices, and demonstrated drought resistance. They have shown these techniques as workable on demonstrations that range from small pockets in scattered villages to hundreds of hectares in contiguous tracts. Scaling up these SA practices was the challenge. 

In December 2008, FCN began to explore ways and means by which small and marginal farmers could be rewarded for their low emissions. Initially, a rather banal and prosaic definition of Low Carbon Farming (LCF) as “SA + Carbon Revenue” was formulated. The 3 other Economic Drivers that root for SA are: Increased Yield; Decreased Input Costs; Improved Price for SA Produce. On further reflection, the network now understands Low Carbon Farming as synonymous to low carbon growth trajectory in all fields of farm economics, fulfilling farm and family energy needs. In this manner, LCF contributes to the traditional understanding of Sustainable Agriculture as a healthy balance between crops, trees, animals and people. Spread across the length and breadth of India, FCN can show the developing world how to approach the issue of Climate Change domestically.  The Pan India LCF Coalition has 15 grassroots NGOs and several external stakeholders. This one year project will have just 6 Participant NGOs where 6,7615 Participating Farmers have been able to grow some crops in 2012 in spite of erratic monsoons. 6 Participant NGOs will, in the 2012 crop season, bring 9,400 Discrete Plots, totalling 17,100 acres, under Low Carbon Farming in 271 villages.  This project resonates with ICCO’s program for the region on Fair Climate Change.

title: Potato Value Chain in Jharkhand
description:
Project background>>. More than two-thirds of the population of Jharkhand state lives in rural areas, with limited livelihood opportunities, despite an abundance of rainfall, good soil and natural resources. The undulating landscape and agro-climatic condition are extremely favorable for potato production, with the added advantage of being able to produce early season potato unlike neighboring states. The fundamental problem faced by the small-scale potato producers is the shortage of quality potato tubers due to a lack of skills to propagate seed potato. They are forced to import tubers from other states, which amounts to around 60% of the total cost of inputs. Providing farmers with the requisite skills for producing quality tubers would therefore have a major impact on farmers’ marginal costs and hence increasing their income. Indian Grameen Services (IGS) works to promote and support microfinance and livelihood initiatives by community based organizations, community based microfinance institutions and upcoming NGO-MFIs in India. 
Project overview>> Under ICCO’s strategic framework (MASP 2020) the Fair Economic Development program focuses on promoting multi-stakeholder partnerships around selected value chains, piloting new models of cooperation and linking with financial and advisory resources for the capacity development and financial sustainability of producer organizations and community based enterprises. In response to high demand from farmers, IGS/BASIX has started supporting potato seed production, together with Vikas Bazar Network (VBN) partners (PRADAN, IGS, Agragati, and Arouse), Pepsico and others. This project seeks to contribute to the VBN-led initiative by supporting livelihoods of more than 2,300 enterprising smallholder and marginal farmers of Jharkhand to develop the production and marketing support system for potato seed by 2015. The project will train 40 Village Resource Persons (VRPs) to support the seed productions systems at village level and create the institutional mechanism for proper seed storage and distribution. The 2300 farmers are expected to earn an additional income of at least Rs.20000 to Rs.25000 per year/acre as a result.

title: SODI Value Chain Pilot- Turmeric
