title: VC development in CG and MP
description:
Project overview>> Self-Reliant Initiatives though Joint Action (SRIJAN) is a not-for profit organization that supports the establishment of self-reliant community based institutions in 17 districts of Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Odisha & Karnataka. This project aims to contribute to sustained improvements of the socio-economic conditions of poor producers in the Korea district of Chhattisgarh and Anuppur district of Madhya Pradesh by adopting a value chain approach in three products, mahua (Indian butter tree), pomegranate and chilli. The project not only focuses on increasing the incomes of tribal poor families, but also to develop appropriate institutional mechanism for the producers. The project has mobilized support from the National Bank for Rural Development (NABARD), the Indian government’s rural banking arm for establishing horticultural farms and from Axis Bank Foundation (one of India’s premier private bank) for human resources and training, ICCO’s support is mainly focused on activities to strengthen upper end of the value chain in processing, institution building and marketing of the produce.
Project activities and outputs>> The two-year project aims to reach a total of 1900 producers (600 chilli producers, 100 pomegranate producers and 1200 mahua collectors). The value additions in these crops/ produce are simple and will be executed with support from research agencies. Fruiting has already started for the pomegranate trees promoted and the focus will be on increasing the productivity and quality and also marketing the produce. An appropriate package of production and processing techniques will be developed to enhance the productivity and quality of chilli, and ensure that producers benefit from successive levels in the value chain. For mahua, appropriate technology and credit linkages for storage have been identified as essential steps for increasing the sale price. With a major focus on marketing and developing linkages with the private sector, the project will support a team exclusively devoted to marketing the produce not only from these farmers but from other regions where Srijan works.
Self Reliant Initiatives through Joint Action
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Improving Policy Response to Food and Nutritional Security
description:
Project overview>> Public Advocacy Initiatives for Rights and Values in India (PAIRVI) was formed in 1998 as an initiative of civil society organizations working to strengthen the advocacy skills of grassroots organizations working in North India and especially in the Hindi speaking belt. Pairvi has been an old ICCO partner mostly supported under the Conflict Transformation and Democratization project. However Pairvi is also recognized for its strong lobby and advocacy work in the area of food security and climate change issues. This intervention aims at improving the food security scenario in some of the poorer states namely Bihar, Rajasthan, Jharkhand, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgrah by adopting a comprehensive approach to food and nutritional security. This includes engaging with systemic issues such as production, distribution and management, and the impact of other policies and legislation on food security. Preliminary analysis of previous interventions shows that while macro-economic indicators, and broader policy initiatives receive appropriate attention from the point of view of advocacy and lobbying, FNS efforts at state and micro levels have remained under the radar. Moreover, despite concerted efforts around FNS issues such as the national food security bill, seeds Bill, FDI Policy, biotechnology regulation and the Land Acquisition Act, not enough efforts have been made to scale up the nutritional emergency, experiences and gaps in managing malnutrition, and food security at state level. It is noteworthy for instance that many better-off states too face the challenges of ensuring improved FNS to the ever-rising number of children and women living in poverty. 
Project activities and outputs>> This intervention builds on previous FNS program experiences to arrive at a better understanding of the drivers of food security, hunger and malnutrition and hence contribute to improved policy responses at state and national level. The project further aims to raise the profile of nutrition in the national food policy framework, and provide policy-relevant insights on malnutrition management. Specific activities and outputs of the project include:
(i) Undertaking the first comprehensive assessment of the effectiveness and program performance of nutrition rehabilitation centres (NRCs) in four states, and especially the linkages and gaps in positioning nutrition within the institutional policy framework on delivering right to food. The findings will be discussed in the state consultations and national consultations with a view to informing nutritional management policies at state and national level. 
(ii) Preparing a scoping paper on malnutrition management in India and implications for policy to address the lack of an operational definition of malnutrition, standards and baseline data, tools for identification of malnutrition and entry and exit criteria for NRCs. The paper aims to generate insights for better institution and community-based management of malnutrition, and options for policy and operational support.
(iii) Developing a Hunger Reduction Commitment Index to assess the commitments of state governments and their performance on reducing hunger and malnutrition. The index will provide a valuable advocacy tool for civil society advocates to monitor the performance of state governments on a variety of factors and indicators, and offer policy options for improved status in these states (including Bihar, Jharkhand, Rajasthan, MP, Chhattisgarh and Uttarakhand).
Public Advocacy Initiatives for Rights and  Values in India
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Ensuring Food Security of Camel Pastoralists by Strengthenin
description:
Sahjeevan is an NGO in Bhuj, Gujarat focusing on natural resources management in the Kutch region. Sahjeevan, (coined word for sah or together and jeevan or living) was set up in 1991 and has over a decade of experience  working on action research and developing models with the women collectives. It links society with technology, building relationships with communities and collaborating to integrate traditional and modern methods of natural resource management. The organization connects communities with technical resources, and monitors progress within the community until the projects are sustainable. Sahjeevan has focused in the rural areas of Kutch for approximately twenty years. In the past few years, it has begun working in urban areas as well. It is also an active member of the Kutch Nav Nirman Abhiyan a civil society network, leading the Drought Proofing Program in the district, coordinated by the same people. 

Sahjeevan has four main units: Water, Renewable Energy, Animal Husbandry, and Urban. The first three units focus on the rural poor in their respective areas of expertise, and the urban unit works in the city of Bhuj and its slums on drinking water and solid waste management projects. One of the reasons that Sahjeevan developed an urban team is because of the toll the 2001 Bhuj earthquake. Camel is one of the important livestocks in the Kachchh region. Due to accelerated industrializations in Kutch, particularly after the 2001 earthquake, the camel breeders of Kutch had problems finding enough grazing areas for the camel as a lot of these have been destroyed due to the construction of SEZs and other industrial activities. 

Due to this, the project aims to create food and livelihood security of camel breeders by strengthening the breeders’ association. The goal is for the breeders to establish a market for camel milk and other camel products, while ensuring the conservation and protection of natural resources which they have been traditionally using for camel grazing. The program will especially focus on the empowerment of women through the formation of women groups at village and taluk level. They will also be given orientation on other income opportunities from camel milk and other camel products. Further towards ensuring animal health care, various health camps will be organized to ensure increased animal health care while reducing mortality. Also, to ensure the sustainability of the program lobbying and advocacy will be continuously held. ICCO’s support for this project will help create food and livelihood security among the camel breeders in the region, which also resonates with its Food and Nutrition Security program for India.

title: Strengthening Producers and Producer Companies for Sustainab
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Biogas Project
description:
There are more than 25 lakhs members of milk cooperatives across the state of Gujarat, with many families indulged mainly in animal husbandry to earn a living. In these villages however, because of the lack of toilet facilities, people are forced to defecate in the open, resulting to diseases, high mortality, morbidity and health hazards. Women suffer the most in this situation. Sometimes they face sexual harassment due to lack of privacy. The lack of sanitation facility in schools leads school girls to drop out of school.  

Because of this, the Ministry of Drinking Water and Sanitation is administering the flagship program known as Nirmal Bharat Abhiyan (NBA) in all the states in India. Through this, the Ministry is providing financial support for the construction of individual household toilets for the people living Below Poverty Line (BPL), marginal farmers, castes and tribes. In spite of this, there was hardly any change or improvement in the situation of villagers due to some reasons. Under the program of the Ministry of New and Renewable energy, financial support is provided for family biogas plant based on animal dung. Additional incentive amounting to 30-35% of the total cost of a biogas plant is given to family-linked biogas. However, most people are unable to bear the cost of construction of biogas plant especially the below poverty line families. Cognizant of this situation, Program FINISH will initiate the pre triggering and triggering phase of safe sanitation and generation of bio energy. Program FINISH stands for Financial Inclusion Improves Sanitation and Health and is being supported and implemented since 2009 by an Indian-Dutch consortium comprising of banks, insurance companies, NGOs and academic and government institutions from the two countries. Its objective is to provide safe sanitation systems (i.e. toilets with proper treatment of waste produced) to low income communities in rural India through mobilizing funds from end-user households. The goal is to provide family size biogas plant based on cow/ buffalo dung as well as human excreta. The program will be implemented in Valsad, Navsari, and Surat districts of Gujarat. It is estimated that 4000 individual household in the phased manner (2000 new LTGB units+ 2000 Toilets) will be linked to existing bio gas unit.

Biogas plant is important in providing sustainable energy sources in rural communities. Generation and utilization of bio-energy from human wastes has additional advantages. It helps improve sanitation, provide bio-energy at negligible recurring expenditure and finally slurry/ effluent of biogas plant has more plant nutrient value to be used for agriculture purposes. The project aims to provide proper training to the beneficiaries for operation and maintenance of the plant. It also aims to   address the social stigma attached to the use of gas obtained from human excreta for cooking purpose and the use of dried slurry of human excreta as fertilizer.

The above project involves different stages of implementation; pre-triggering, triggering, post triggering and scaling up.  ICCO's support for post triggering and scaling up of the project will be valuable. Not only will the need for basic, hygienic toilets become a dream come true for the beneficiaries, but at the same time, the generation of sustainable bio energy will benefit the stakeholders and the environment as well.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Scaling Up Tomato- Phase 3
description:
This project is the third and final instalment of a coalition being implemented by long term ICCO partners, Rural Development Association (RDA) and Tagore Society for Rural Development (TSRD). Both RDA and TSRD are members of the Vikas Bazar Network (VBN), which is a network of 18 NGOs working in the state of Jharkhand. Both organizations mainly work with very poor household belonging to tribal and disadvantaged families in the area; most of whom are very small farmers (land holding: 0.5 Ha average).

While RDA and TSRD are both established organisations in terms of social and rights based work, they have only started working on market based livelihood promotion after becoming members of VBN. In the first year, the coalition has reached out to 2000 producers. In the second year, it rose to 3,000 producers; and in this project duration, the coalition will reach out to about 4000 small producers.

This project is being implemented jointly by RDA and TSRD, with the support of VBN and PRADAN, in the Patamda, Ghatshila and Bhulbamgarh blocks in Jharkhand. These areas are very good for growing vegetables and are especially known for their tomatoes. However, the small farmers find it difficult to access the bigger markets and better prices. They also find it difficult to get quality inputs like seeds and fertilizers in time. Since most of the farmers are poor, they also lack money to invest in agriculture. The farming practices of these small farmers are not scientific and they produce much less compared to the more financially-able farmers. Hence, this project aims to establish a replicable model of tomato value chain and producer’s institution which will ensure fair access to the market to facilitate sustainable income of small and marginal producer within ten years’ time. Through this project, it is hoped that a sustainable annual income of at least Rs.10,000 for 4000 individual producers from 0.25 acre land, leading to total additional earning of Rs.300,00,000 is achieved. Also, this project will help establish direct linkage of farmers with major markets and market players, as well as increase the farmers’ access to information and communication regarding markets, market rate, demand –supply, modern technology. This project also aims to promote producers’ cooperative to provide opportunity for the small holders to access markets, information, linkage, resources, and technology, among others. This project with RDA supports ICCO’s Fair Economic Development Program for India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Ecunemical Solidarity For HIV & AIDS
description:
The National Council of Churches in India (NCCI) is the ecumenical council for 30 protestant and orthodox churches in India. It’s membership comprise of 17 Regional Councils of Churches (RCCs), 17 All India Christian Organizations (AICOs), and 7 Related Agencies (RAs). The NCCI manages its intervention through 7 commissions and 3 Autonomous Bodies of the Council. The Council has its headquarters in Nagpur and runs a liaison office in Delhi. The main thrusts of the Council are Mission, Evangelism, Unity, Policy, Governance and Public witness, Justice, Peace and Creation. NCCI carries forward these thrusts within and through the member churches, Regional Councils of Churches and AICOs and especially among women, young people, Dalits, tribes, and through the children. Among its many activities, the NCCI has been in the forefront of making policies in the field of HIV/AIDS (this in partnership with the ICCO & KiA, Netherlands), climate justice, youth and children; committing itself to justice in all its pursuits. The NCCI has initiated campaigns for justice for Dalit Christians. The Christian Service Agency or CSA (the contracted agency by ICCO) is the service wing of the NCCI. Almost all the programs are undertaken by the CSA on behalf of the NCCI. The CSA undertakes programs in line with capacity building in the areas of ecology and the Church, peace-building, youth and ecumenical formation, gender, mainstreaming and advocacy, and on issues relating to the public witness of the church.
ICCO has partnered with NCCI/CSA since 2007 to operationalize Ecumenical solidarity for HIV and AIDS (ESHA) amongst Protestant churches in India .The HIV and AIDS Policy Guideline which was accepted by the Member Churches of NCCI in Shillong General Assembly in 2008 was the first milestone. As the next operational step, ESHA identified the salient features of this historic document, namely-gender, sex & sexuality stigma and discrimination, and mainstreamed them over the last 4 years through various initiatives.  ESHA has played a prominent role in encouraging and accompanying NCCI to become increasingly visible in its overall response to stigma and discrimination. From the initial denial and silence, a remarkable progress is being witnessed. ESHA has contributed to an “awakening in churches and church institutions” by, among other strategies, providing quality theological literature, mobilizing men and boys, and using Contextual Bible Study (CBS). Meanwhile in 2013, two National-level Policies – one on Education [NEPE], and the other, a Work Place Policy (WPP) for NCCI’s Christian Organisations were developed and rolled out in some constituencies. In the current phase (phase 4), the program implemented will be scaled up to other AICOs and Christian education institutions. Phase 4 will also be the consolidating phase of the collaborative work of ICCO and ESHA over the last several years.  
The phase 4 of this project will focus on consolidating the collaborative work of ICCO and ESHA over the last several years.  The two important focuses will be to demonstrate the implementation of a Work Place Policy for selected 5 India Christian Organisations (AICOS) of NCCI. Second, is to formulate guidelines for Educational Institutions to enable them to incorporate the Inclusive features of NEPE. Another key feature is to demonstrate implementation in 35 colleges by All India Association for Christian Higher Education (AIACCHE), which will facilitate scale up. The program also emphasises the creation of an Interfaith Youth Action Team from all over India. This will include youth who attended the Regional and National Conferences [in Phase 3 year 2 and 3], and marginalized voices like transgenders and PLWA. The primary stakeholders in the program will be the 13 All India Christian Organizations, the Schools managed by the 30 member churches of the NCCI represented by their respective education boards and the local congregations of the mainline Protestant and Orthodox Churches in India and leaders from different faith (like Islam, Hindu and Sikh). ICCO’s support to this project is in line with its Health and HIV/AIDS program for India.

title: Ending Violence against Women in Odisha and Uttar Pradesh
description:
Project overview: Violence against women is a common and insidious phenomenon in India. Being positioned at the lowest social order of Indian society, Dalit women face a triple marginalization based on class, caste, and gender. The Dalit Foundation was registered in June 2003 as a public trust committed exclusively to the eradication of caste discrimination and the empowerment of Dalits and other marginalized communities. This ICCO-supported multi-stakeholder project to be implemented in two states of Odisha and Uttar Pradesh seeks to build Dalit women’s capacities to fight against the violence and oppression they face by targeting potential women leaders who can help accelerate processes of change in the lives of Dalit women. 
Project activities and outputs: One of the change theories underlying the project design is that when women have access to knowledge combined with access to resources, they are more capable to lead change in their families and communities. Apart from leadership and capacity building the thrust of the program will therefore be on contributing to the economic empowerment of Dalit women, with a focus on creating a sustainable development model. To ensure the sustainability of the program its interventions and activities will be implemented at the community level thus not only making women more aware about the impact of violence and oppression, but also sensitizing the broader community as well.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: IDSN Programme 2010 - 2012- part 2
description: Project overview: The International Dalit Solidarity Network (IDSN) was founded in March 2000 to advocate for Dalit human rights and to raise awareness on Dalit issues. This project aims to contribute to ISDN’s ongoing program of work with Dalit communities in India by pursuing four main objectives: (i) enhancing awareness of caste discrimination as a global human rights problem; (ii) influencing key global players, including human rights bodies, UN agencies, experts and member, and NGOs, to develop and apply caste sensitive programming and guidelines and undertake further effective action for the elimination of caste based discrimination; (iii) undertaking effective communication and networking to further strengthen and sustain network relations and resources; and (iv) promoting better understanding of the links between business and human rights, including the links between caste and labor exploitation (such as bonded labor), misappropriation of land allocated to Dalit and other marginalized communities, and discrimination in access to basic services like housing, health, education and training.  The project aims to directly contribute to ICCO’s MASP strategic framework, which seeks to enhance economic opportunities for marginalized communities by linking business and human rights.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: EDF, USA
description:
Project overview>> Since 1967, Environmental Defense Fund (EDF) has linked science, economics, law and innovative private sector partnerships to create solutions to the world’s most serious environmental problems. EDF is one of the core members of the Fair Climate Network (FCN). Low-carbon development is an integral component of EDF’s work on international climate, which includes demonstrating benefits for participants in terms of reducing their agriculture-input costs (e.g., for fertilizer) and improved long term yields, as well as how carbon markets can provide an additional income stream to farmers, thus helping incentivize adoption of new strategies. Though focused on India, this initiative has far broader ramifications. Because smallholder communities have important similarities even across global regions, creating workable systems in India will provide inspiring models that can be adapted for use elsewhere. This follow up project builds on pilot EDF projects supported by ICCO and its partners in four locations in India. Hitherto, the FCN partners have established five labs (each proximate to a field site) at the following locations: Accion Fraterna Ecology Centre in Anantapur, Andhra Pradesh; Bharath Environment Seva Team in Pudokottai, Tamil Nadu; Palmyrah Workers’ Development Society in Marthandam, Tamil Nadu; Social Animation Centre for Rural Education and Development in Bangalore Rural District, Karnataka; and Timbaktu Collective in Anantapur, Andhra Pradesh (beginning operations in September 2013). A sixth lab is due to established in late 2013/early 2014. Three labs will become operational in additional agro-ecological zones later in 2014. The overall goal of the project is to promote long term sustainable farming by operationalizing the use of carbon markets. The markets reward farmers who adopt low-carbon farming practices, thus increasing farmers’ incomes and reducing their expenses while also minimizing agricultural emissions of greenhouse gases. 
Project activities and outputs>> The project aims to:
(i) Generate the data needed to develop GHG emission reductions methodologies for smallholder farming for rice and upland crops, and securing approval of those methodologies from an international standard-setting body;
(ii) Generate the data needed to establish regional emission factors for three or more crops in a total of eight agro-ecological zones, thus allowing the methodologies to be applied with regard to those crops in those zones:
(iii) Build capacity among local NGOs to establish and run analytic laboratories, thus enabling them to generate the data needed to establish emission factors for additional regions and crops and, in turn, allowing additional farmers to be rewarded by carbon markets for using LCF practices.
Expected outcomes>> LCF-EMD will strengthen the capacity of the FCN and its member Indian NGOs to generate emission factors for additional crops and additional agro-ecological zones inasmuch as the laboratory equipment and tools, staff training, standard operating procedures and manuals will remain available after this project is completed. Under the  MASP 2020 strategic framwork, EDF and FCN form an important part of ICCO’s long term strategic alliances and this project will contribute to strengthening this partnership.

title: Promoting  household level food and nutritional security amo

title: KNNA FNS
description:
In 2012 KNNA implemented the pilot project mandate of ICCO under Food and Nutrition Security (FNS) that focused on enhancing the income and ensuring food security in Kutch district, Gujarat. The main components of the project are 6 farmer -producer companies, covering almost   113 villages, spread over 8 blocks of Kutch District, with 4 partner organizations. The main objective of the project is to support producers for sustainability of agriculture and livestock production system to enhance food and livelihood security. This project also aims to strengthen the capacity of producer companies to enhance quality of services to increase the reach to 113 villages under the producer company, by developing business related to agriculture.

During the project, it is hoped that 2475 farmer families will be involved directly or indirectly into this project to enhance their income through supporting the producers for sustainability of agriculture and livestock production system (through producer companies). Also, it is envisioned that 6 producer companies will be established in Kutch district of Gujarat; with each of them buying from farmers and selling to the market up to 1000 tons of output during one season. Through the interventions of this project, 300 farmer & livestock owner families get direct benefit, and approximately about 250 families from the area will get indirect benefits through value addition of the agriculture and milk produce at the producer company level, with promotion of local traditional variety of seeds. Fodder management and storage system development activity will be carried out as well with six producer companies, covering about 150 farmer and livestock owner-families. 

Producers and producer companies will likewise be empowered and strengthened in this project. Training, capacity building of producers will be carried out to about 250 farmer & livestock owner families. Workshop at district and state levels will be organised for capacity building of producer companies and for better linkages with different schemes of governments and private sectors. This project fits in ICCO’s Food and Nutrition Security program for the region, benefitting 6 producer organisations, and 2475 families for sustainability of agriculture and livestock production system.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Engaging ICCO partners with Corporate Social Responsibility
description:
This project aims at developing the Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) portfolio of ICCO and its CSO partners. In India, CSR is deemed to provide a major role in the field of development. Since the new Companies Bill has been passed in Parliament, the project partners will provide support to ICCO and its CSO partners in developing a portfolio of engaging the CSRs of prominent companies in India in the development process.

It is assumed that after the passing of the Companies Bill in 2013, 2% of the profits of certain companies in India have to be reserved for community development projects through CSR. However, concrete action relative to this has yet to be taken by most corporations. In India, approximately 200 Billion INR is dedicated for CRS annually. Not only is the budget substantial, but there is no clear cut plan by most corporates on the use of these resources.

This project aims at targeting corporates with a substantial outlay of CSR funds, while helping them to utilise the funds in the most efficient manner at the same time. One of the objectives of the project is to organize deliberations and workshops between CSO partners and the private sector that have been involved in CSR activities. Specific action points for this project include the identification of companies that lack a specific CSR plan, helping them strengthen their CSR portfolio and support targeted interventions in a phased manner. The project seeks to mobilize resources from the corporate world for ICCO partners. ICCO's support will be aimed at supporting CSRs to develop a pro poor and pro community portfolio.

This project is in line with ICCO’s overall goal, wherein the partner base is diversified, to include targeted interventions with the private sector. Through this project, the following interventions will be carried out:  consultancy to develop the CSR portfolio, specifically engaging at least two companies on CSR development; organise Consultative Workshop with the corporate sector on possible partnership development; and detailed monitoring and follow up of existing CSR projects.

title: Empowerment & Entitlement Coalition

title: Claiming rights for urban poor
description:
Project background: Janasahayog is an Urban Resource Centre that was established in 1995 to work with the urban poor communities as a resource centre in the state of Karnataka in Southern India. The adoption of the Slum Act in 2002 paved the way for people living in slums to galvanize themselves and achieved positive results for change. Janasahayog was subsequently transformed into an independent community based organization in August 2003 that is managed and led by people living in slums. In recent years the Centre has been successful in mobilizing communities in eight cities in the state of Karnataka, including the state capital, Bangalore, to secure access to justice and fundamental rights such as jobs, medical treatment, housing and sanitation. At the same time, the project has created strong leadership within the community members, enabling them to speak for themselves in the process of demand rights and helping to revive their sense of identity and culture. 
Project overview: This project will continue to focus on securing the rights of the residents of urban slums in 8 cities of Karnataka, with the overall goal of reducing social discrimination and deprivation, and to uphold multi-cultural social justice and equity through community-led action. The specific objectives of the project are to: enable a conducive atmosphere for enhancing awareness and consciousness of deprived communities; strengthen peoples’ institutions in deprived communities; and enable conducive atmosphere for integrating and promoting the cultures of deprived communities. The project will prioritize
the capacity development of youth and women to take on leadership roles in their community.
Human Rights Education and Urban Slum Resource Centre
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Promoting vegetable to enhance the income of 500 rural women
description:
Udyogini means ‘’women entrepreneur’’, and its vision and perspective on microenterprises for women have always been to empower women so that they understand and participate in critical enterprise processes. As the market gains prominence, the need for women to become knowledgeable, confident and to lead enterprises just as they have led microcredit initiatives becomes critical. Udyogini has made innovative efforts to establish theory and practice for women's microenterprise knowledge, promotion and service provision for outreach. It works with the poor, mainly illiterate women to improve their skills as producers and their knowledge of the markets they operate in, so as to ensure long-term returns. This program operates  in Rajasthan, MP, Jharkhand, Uttarakhand, UP, Bihar, and Orissa,  but a variety of enterprise services are provided  in many other states as well.

In the past 10 years, Udyogini has been the pioneer in micro-enterprise and value chain development to empower women in rural India. Vegetable has become a crucial part of value chain product as it provides a substantial income to women throughout the year. Densely forested and insurgency-affected Bundu is one of the largest and tribal-inhabited blocks of Ranchi district in Jharkhand. The societal pattern of the block is traditionally patriarchal. Girls are denied access to education and are married off early. The families have only 4 months of assured livelihoods and for the rest of the year they mainly depend on wages from agricultural labour. 

This project will promote vegetables to enhance income, enterprise and skills of 500 rural women in Humta and Gambhariya panchayat of Bundu block (Ranchi district) within one year and build the value chain, coupled with an institutional focus within three years. Humta and Gambhariya Panchayat of Bundu block are among the poorest areas of Jharkhand, with a population of 4600 people, with 950 households. Vegetable cultivation is being practiced by more than 75% of the households. Tomato is one of the major vegetable being cultivated in this area and it has the involvement of maximum workforce of the Panchayat, with a peak season yield of around 200 quintals per month. In the villages like Jaamgami, kajibaru, Lotehatu, Kuchidih of this Panchayat, more than 70% of the households grow tomato in their field. However, repeated cultivation has affected the yield rate of this highly favoured crop. And since tomato is highly perishable, farmers are faced with poor sales at the market. The lack of organized aggregation and marketing system at the producer’s level results in farmers not getting fair prices for their produce. In this project, Udyogini will work on its key value chain innovations that lie in the architecture of the chain and its approach to service delivery, focusing on capacity-building, systems and key value chain tiers for controlling the production, value-addition and marketing processes.  The strategies  in this project  involve research and development; building capacity of producers; building up of business development service providers (BDSPs); promotion of vegetable enterprises through BDSPs; systems and institutions; and creation and strengthening of  agriculture.

Through this intervention, ICCO will help ensure the food security of 500 families will increase (previously from 6-9 months) to a year. At least 540 women will have an improved socio-economic condition which will also influence their and their family's nutritional and health status positively. At least 400 children will have an improved nutritional and health condition through enhanced health and nutritional practices within the community, as well as access to government development schemes. This project also supports ICCO’s Food and Nutrition Security Program for the region.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Business Planning for Producer Companies
description:
Project overview>> This follow up project aims to implement the findings of the Scopeinsight (SI) survey, which assessed the capacity needs of 20 producer organizations (POs). The Centre for Innovation and Incubation of Entrepreneurship (CIIE), which is the business incubation center of India's premier business school (IIM, Ahmedabad) will provide extensive capacity development for five of the POs along the nine parameters assessed in the study. CIIE has a history of working closely with entrepreneurs and start-ups and has mentored several successful entrepreneurs. With this project, ICCO India seeks to provide an integrated and sustainable approach solution to the capacity building of POs. This is in line with the vision set forth in the strategic framework (MASP 2020) for the Fair Economic Development program, wherein ICCO acts as a broker and facilitator of multi-stakeholder approaches to address common development challenges. The project is designed as a long-term initiative in which the successful completion of each cycle of PO assessment and capacity building will leverage funding from new partners to support more POs. 
Project activities and outputs>> CIIE will organize visioning workshops, develop the business plan and provide backstopping support to the five POs over the period of one year, following which Scopeinsight will conduct a follow up rating/assessment of the POs. The success of the project will be measured by the positive change in the SI ratings. The capacity development activities will be provided provided by CIIE staff as well as IIMA faculty, alumni and students. Mentors and service providers from the private sector who span a variety of functional areas, sectoral domains and geographical locations will also be brought on board. An important characteristic of the trainers (and a prerequisite for the project’s success) is their commitment to identifying disruptive innovations and helping aspiring entrepreneurs to succeed commercially.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Rights of women in conflict and fragile states
description:
Project background: In its early years, Grameen Sahara ran small-scale agricultural training programs among the tribal communities in Goalpara district of Assam. In 2007 the organization initiated the Golden Weavers’ Project, an Ericulture livelihood project, with support from Sir Dorabji TataTrust. In order to ensure optimum benefits to the community, Grameen Sahara subsequently incorporated an Eri Silk Producer Company in 2011, which is owned and run by the producers themselves. The organization also promotes and implements System of Crop Intensification (SCI) and Diversion Based Irrigation (DBI) in various areas of Assam. Through its microfinance operations, Grameen Sahara currently reaches around 27,000 families in the area. 
Project overview: This project is implemented as part of a new Grameen Sahara program that aims to promote sustainable livelihoods for the poor through the provision of financial services, technical assistance and other development support services in integrated manner. The specific objectives are to: improve the pace and quality of life of the rural and urban poor especially the village and decentralized sector; focus attention on women, children, the historically disadvantaged scheduled castes and scheduled tribes, minorities and other marginalized communities for their economic self-sustenance; create, develop and support self employment avenues for rural and urban youth; build social capital that will be used by and for the community; and optimally utilize all the available natural, social, economic and other resources for the well being of the community. 
Project activities and outputs: The project aims to facilitate the organization of producer groups of women weavers and spinners to address common problems such marketing, publicity, product diversification, skills upgrading. It will also provide capacity development support in the field of design development as well as working capital assistance towards purchase of raw materials. To address the scarcity of cocoons during the lean seasons, Grameen Sahara will also maintain a stock of cocoons to meet the needs of spinners. As a result of these activities, the project aims to contribute to higher and more predictable income for home-based women producers due to increased production and product quality This is expected to enhance the self respect and status of women in the community. By providing a steady supply of cocoons, the project will also help safeguard producers against market price fluctuations.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Survey-Awareness-Skill Training Project in TN 2011-2014
description:
The Indian Economy is characterized by the existence of a vast majority of informal or unorganized labour employment. According to the Economic Survey in 2007-08, 93% of India’s workforce is either self-employed or employed from unorganized sectors. The workers of the informal sector do not have regular jobs as their work is seasonal or they depend on contract or are contractual workers. Many of them are obliged to migrate to other parts where there is some work; these workers do not have an employer. Their wages are very low, subsistence wages in most cases. These workers are unprotected in the sense that in most cases they do not have social protection, social security and are not entitled to old age pension. Given also the fact that the trade unions are not really present in the informal sector, it is difficult for them to raise problems in the tripartite negotiations. Informal sector workers, must therefore organize themselves, form unions and with the help of existing unions and civil society organization, realize that all Core Labour Rights, should be respected in the work places and in the society. 

Creating awareness within the unorganized sector on labour rights is the key entry point for initiatives for the Centre for Labour Education and Development (CLEAD). The work this organization has undertaken towards supporting transformation of informal sector economy by making it decent and less exploitative for workers undoubtedly needs support. With the assistance of Kerk in Actie and ICCO, CLEAD has been actively involved in conducting surveys on unorganized sector workers, Awareness Camps on Labour Rights, Social Security and Welfare Boards and Skill Training programs and Self-Help Group Training for women. These have helped unorganized workers from various occupations to get organized into unions and to access their rights and become registered in Welfare Boards, so that they can derive benefits from them.

The main problem that will be addressed by the proposed project is to make the problems of labour conditions, migration, bondage, child labour and marginalization become visible through survey and awareness.  This will not only help the workers realize their rights with respect to Welfare Boards but also lead to the improvement of their working and living conditions. The social equity in terms of caste and gender are also implicit in the invisibility and vulnerability of manual workers. Specifically the issues of women workers will be focused on, and strategies will tackle on how to overcome the economic and sexual exploitation and inequity. Elimination of bondage and child labour and protection of migrant labour are also a priority in this project, especially in the Districts of Chennai, Madurai, Trichy, Thiruvallur, Kanchipuram, Villupuram, Cuddalore; as well as the Districts of Tuticorin and Krishnagiri. 

The primary stakeholders (beneficiaries) are workers in various occupations: agriculture; handloom; street vending; domestic; sanitary; fish; and salt pan, among others. This project is in line with ICCO’s program for Children at Risk in India.
CLEaD (Centre for Labour Education and Development)
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Child and women health care project, Bihar, 2011-2015
description:
Since 2011 Help a Child Of India (HACI) has been implementing the Madhepura child development Project. Mother and child health is one of the thematic focuses of the project. Madhepura district is located in Bihar State, one of the least developed states of India. 

The project is being implemented in 10 villages of Gowalpara block of Madhepura district. 
With a population of 103 million of which 87% reside in rural areas communities are  at times isolated from information, services, and supplies, which support survival. Over 54% of the population is below the poverty line. The infant mortality rate is 48 deaths per 1000 live births (2012). For Madhephure it is the highest in the state (64 deaths per 1000 live births).  Under 5 years of age mortality rates is 70 per 1000 children is the fifth highest in the country.  The maternal mortality ratio of Bihar  is 274 deaths per 100,000 live births (2014) the second highest in the country. 
Madhepura Child Development project aims to reach the unreached in the neglected and deserted parts of the state. The target communities are economically poor Dalit and vulnerable groups of tribal communities called Santhals and Yadav.  

The project works towards an increased access and utilisation of government health schemes and services by the target communities and improved quality services offered by the government PHC and Sub – centres. 
The project works with change agents that are supported by community based organizations  in addressing factors that impede access to mother and child health care. Community organization and mobilization takes place and the  strengthening of community based organizations and change agents to facilitate the use and access of health services. Cluster and block level mass awareness campaign on mother & child health care, immunization, National Rural Health Mission and HIV/AIDs is one of the activities of the change agents. At village level community meetings on mother & child health care, immunization, National Rural Health Mission and HIV/AIDS take place.  Cluster and block level meeting with Primary Health Centre and Integrated Child Development Scheme and other government health & nutrition schemes and programme contribute to better access.  Communities are facilitated to submit petitions to government health and concerned departments on community health issues.  Training and capacity building of Village Health Committee on community monitoring systems of the government health programmes at village level contributes to towards the accountability of the health services.

The project collaborates with government departments – Health, Education and administration to access resources and services for the targeted communities. Other NGOs specialized in health sector – I.e Madhepura Christian Hospital, Emmanual Health Association and Nav Jyothi Mission. Resource organization like PRAXIS- for advocacy and action research support.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Spandana Food & Nutriotion Security
description:
In this project Emmanuel Hospital Association (EHA) aims to empower the communities in Seoni District in Madhya Pradesh with a focus on marginalised groups as Schedule Caste and Schedule Tribe to ensure adequate access to food and improved nutritional status of the people so that they live healthy productive lives with dignity. EHA empowers communities to demonstrate good stewardship of their available natural resources.  

In the target area many villages faces severe drought each year. Major part of the landscape is undulating and rocky with thin layer of soil cover, steep slopes with high surface runoff, unavailability of drought resistant variety of quality seeds coupled with unavailability of livelihood opportunities. The Human Development Indicators such as literacy, health, and poverty reflected an all time low, with the result that the area was labelled  by the government as backward and unfortunate. The target area consists mainly Scheduled Tribes and Scheduled Caste population. The population largely resides in little hamlets scattered a few kilometres from each other. Many villagers live on a single meal a day.  Most are dependent on agriculture labour for their living, Scarcity of irrigation facilities (only 21% of the farmers in the target population have facility for irrigation whole year round), no land rights and no adequate agricultural knowledge leads to insufficient agricultural produce, which in turn forces many to migrate to the nearest big town or city in search of daily wage labour. Unemployment rate is high. The high prevalence of under-nutrition among the target population is due to poverty, lack of awareness about, and access to and utilization of the available nutrition supplementation programmes; social barriers preventing the utilization of available nutrition supplementation programme and services; lack of safe drinking water. 

The aims as described above are worked towards by activities on crop diversification, raise the gound water level, anticipating on Climate Change and focus on Disaster Risk Reduction, improved food production, gender equality for food, Rigth to Food campaign. The main strategy  of the project is to empower communities (capacities, ownership, knowledge, skills, attitude). Helping & orienting the people to help themselves by forming appropriate groups, consolidating themselves and implementing their own objectives to accomplish. Another strategy is to cooperate with all relevant stakeholders and activities in the villages and their area in one catchement area, to ensure the sustainability. 

EHA cooperates together with the communities, relevant government authorities and departments and NGOs. EHA is member of several networks, alliances and coalitions.

title: Understanding Impunity : the Right to Truth, Justice and Reparation
description: The phenomenon of impunity, understood as the freedom to commit violent acts normally subject to penal process, is routinely enjoyed by agencies of the state in South Asia. In spite of very enlightened constitutions, armed forces in all South Asian countries receive legislative sanction for their actions in the name of sovereignty, security, public order or counter-terrorism. Compensation to the victims of  human rights abuses remains arbitrary. This project aims to understand both the effects of state impunity and the culture in which it survives. Researchers will examine violence, rights violations, mainstream perception of rights violations and the discourse that contributes to legitimizing violence in Gujarat, Kashmir, and the Punjab, both in India. They will endeavor to understand how impunity works, affects citizens' rights and contributes to the cycle of violence. In this way, it is hoped to hold the state accountable for failing to uphold the rule of law and fulfill its commitment to international conventions.

title: Reasoned Approach to Setting Priorities in Health
description: This project will develop a concise set of guidelines and tools for priority setting, and apply them to two different resource allocation problems, the one focusing on equitable redistribution of health services toward the most vulnerable in Namibia, and the other on the sustainability of the Aarogyasri Health Insurance Scheme for the poor in Andhra Pradesh, India. The project will provide essential capacity building and enhanced technical inputs from the World Health Organization (WHO) in support of the long-expressed aim of these two governments to reduce existing inequities with respect to the allocation of and access to resources for health.

Ministry of Health and Social Services of the Government of the Republic of Namibia
Ministry of Health and Social Services of the Government of the Republic of Namibia

title: Options for Diversification in Tobacco Farming and Related Activities (India)
description: Although India is a signatory to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) and has put in place a number of policies aimed at reducing the demand for tobacco products, the tobacco industry still benefits from strong institutional support. India is, however, a member of the World Health Organization (WHO) Working Group on Alternative Livelihoods to Tobacco Production, and has set up its own national working group to review and suggest feasible alternatives. This project aims to provide the national working group with data on the socioeconomic status of the population engaged in tobacco farming and related activities such as bidi rolling and tendu leaf plucking; identify feasible alternative livelihoods; and design an intervention to facilitate a gradual shift to other viable and sustainable livelihoods.

title: Engendering Policy through Evaluation: Uncovering Exclusion and Challenging Inequities in India
description: The socioeconomic context in India is characterized by persistent gender gaps and inequalities; an increasing demand for transparency and accountability; and growing interest in evaluation, but shortfall in evaluation capacity. This project will strengthen the ability of social science researchers to use gender-sensitive approaches to understanding the gendered implications of policies and programs in the area of education, health, governance and livelihood. It will do so by enabling IDRC grantees and other researchers to participate in workshops, where they will acquire the tools, training and peer support to improve the quality of the evaluations that they are working on. At the same time, the project will endeavour to demonstrate that such research yields useful knowledge on persistent inequities, thereby contributing to a new sub-field in evaluation based on feminist and equity-oriented approaches. The focus of the project is India. Given the interest of researchers from neighboring countries, however, it will also be open to other South Asians.

title: Justice, Reparations and Accountability for Religious and Caste Massacres in India
description: The secular Constitution of India guarantees protection and equality before the law to religious minorities, Dalits and tribal communities. But, recurring episodes of communal violence during and since Partition have given rise to the perception that the Government of India is unwilling to hold perpetrators and complicit public officials accountable for their actions against minorities. This project will build on the findings of a pilot study that indicated widespread failure of public institutions to protect minorities before, during and after communal violence (106022). Researchers will examine the experience of survivors/victims in two locations (Gujarat and Orissa or Delhi) with respect to the following areas of state responsibility: the duty to prevent the outbreak of targeted mass violence; the duty to control violence effectively and protect all citizens regardless of their identities; the duty to provide adequate, fair and timely relief, rehabilitation and reparation to enable victims to rebuild their lives; and the duty to ensure that perpetrators are prosecuted and subjected to due process of criminal law. The project is expected to produce fresh insight into how state institutions can be held accountable in the aftermath of mass violence, and prepare the ground for a just policy and binding national norms on compensation, relief and rehabilitation. It will also help specify what changes to the law are required to make public officials more accountable and reduce their immunity to prosecution.

title: Dalit Women in Indian Politics: Making Impact through Parliament?
description:
IDRC's Democratic Governance, Women's Rights and Gender Equality initiative is supporting a body of comparative research on whether and how democratic processes and institutions are responding to women's rights and gender equality. The projects under this initiative will investigate issues surrounding women's participation in political decision-making, the judiciary and the public sector, and explore ways in which state institutions, political parties, civil society and kin-based social organizations can be influenced to advance women's choices and entitlements as citizens, including through increased representation.

A previous IDRC-supported research project on Dalit women's rights and citizenship in India (104939) showed that Dalit women are not "just like" other women in the way they experience discrimination. They are also subject to caste-based exclusion that deprives them of opportunities to escape poverty and denies them a voice to claim their rights. This grant will take the work further by examining the impact of Dalit women's political participation on economic and social policy outcomes affecting their constituencies, communities and families. The results are expected to initiate serious debate in policy and academic circles on Dalit women's political participation and representation, and serve as a baseline for future studies.

title: Health Rights and Equity-oriented Health System Change in Maharashtra, India
description: The private sector is the largest health provider in India, and unregulated private healthcare is resulting in inequitable access to services and irrational or misguided use of healthcare resources. The first phase of the project (103234) highlighted these issues and brought together health researchers, activists and experts to give them more prominence. This project will combine research on specific aspects of heathcare access (including misguided forms of women's health services promoted by private practitioners) with policy research, and propose a system to address the problem. Researchers will draw up a roadmap and possible models for a system universal health care for Maharashtra state, and contribute to similar discourse at the national level. The project will also include a fellowship program to build the capacity of young healthcare professionals in the field of equity and rights. This is expected to result in pool of health professionals with the skills to advocate for and contribute to the movement for universal access to health care.

title: Institutional Visit to Canada by Chinmaya Organization for Rural Development (India)
description: Chinmaya Organization for Rural Development (CORD) is a nongovernmental organization that seeks to empower women by increasing their ability to contribute to their families' support and encouraging them to take on local leadership roles. This grant will allow Dr Kshama Metre, a practicing pediatrician and National Director of CORD (India), to visit Canada along with two individuals who have benefited from the organization's work in Kangra District, Himachal Pradesh, one of the most depressed states in India. The visit will include a presentation by Dr Metre as well as a workshop on Kangra-style painting illustrating the CORD approach to development. The overall goal of the visit is to demonstrate that well-managed foreign assistance at the local level can lead to self-sufficiency and improved livelihoods.

title: Alleviating Poverty and Malnutrition in Agro-biodiversity Hotspots of India (CIFSRF)
description: The Government of India estimates that approximately one-quarter of its population is poor, with the majority living in rural regions and dependent on dryland farming for a living. Although India has a rich heritage of genetic diversity - more than 30 different main crops are grown in 18 of India's 31 states - this diversity and local food security is being challenged on the one hand, by central policies promoting irrigated rice and wheat cultivation, and on the other, by weak local capability and patchy infrastructure. This project - supported by the Canadian International Food Security Research Fund (CIFSRF), a joint program of IDRC and the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) - seeks to address the contradiction between the prosperity of nature and the poverty of the people in three distinct agro-biodiversity hotspots in the states of Orissa, Tamil Nadu and Kerala. Researchers at the M.S Swaminathan Research Foundation, India, and the University of Alberta, Canada, will design and test interventions aimed at enhancing farm productivity and increasing food, nutrition and income security in three dryland test regions. Attention to gender equity, environmental health and sustainable energy will be built into the project.

title: Revalorizing Minor Millets in Rainfed Regions of South Asia (CIFSRF)
description:
Despite their nutritional properties, storability and tolerance for adverse growing conditions, small millets have consistently been neglected in favour of the major cereals (rice, wheat) and cash crops in South Asian agricultural policy. Small millets could provide smallholders and indigenous groups with resilience in the face of climate change, disease and pests. But, there is a need for research to support smallholders and indigenous groups in the development of improved cultivars, the recovery of village-based seed systems and the adoption of sustainable cultivation practices.

This project - supported by the Canadian International Food Security Research Fund (CIFSRF), a joint program of IDRC and the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) - will allow researchers to document and test on-farm conservation of agrobiodiversity and increase production (and consumption) of small millets, pulses and oilseeds in eight rainfed regions across India, Nepal and Sri Lanka. Scientists and farmers will study postharvest technologies (including dehulling and processing), value chains and policy opportunities to enhance small millet farming in South Asia. This is expected to increase the availability of nutrients, particularly to women and small children. The project results will be disseminated to decision-makers, researchers and practitioners in the region and worldwide.

title: Food and Livelihood Security in Punjab through Water, Energy and Agricultural Management
description:
Climate change poses a significant threat to agrarian societies in tropical regions. In Punjab, which produces more than half of India's annual food grain production, there is rising uncertainty in the timing of the rainy season. This - combined with large state subsidies for the use of electricity in irrigation - has prompted farmers to increase their reliance on water drawn from deep aquifers and pay scant attention to irrigation scheduling based on climate and meteorological information. The result is declining groundwater levels and, for low-income farmers without direct access to electricity, increased food insecurity.

This project aims to engage farmers, corporations and the state agricultural extension program in making better use of meteorological information to optimize water and energy use, and reduce pressure on overexploited aquifers. While previous work has targeted higher income farmers, this work will focus on lower income groups.

Researchers will assess the vulnerability of the food production system to water scarcity; use seasonal climate forecasts to guide irrigation scheduling, fertilizer application and crop choice; optimize the use of agricultural technology to improve water use efficiency; and make use of mobile phone technology to facilitate an exchange of information between farmers and planners. The project is expected to result in policy recommendations aimed at promoting sustainable resource management and facilitating access to resources by low-income farmers.

title: Research on Innovation Systems and Social Inclusion in Emerging 	Economies and Beyond: RISSI at BRICS+
description:
How can science, technology, and innovation contribute to poverty reduction and inclusive development, especially in Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, otherwise known as the BRICS countries?

Earlier IDRC-supported research analyzed and compared the diverse paths and development strategies of BRICS countries from the point of view of national innovation systems. A key finding is that the benefits of innovations rarely address the needs of the poor because most policies and systems that support science, technology, and innovation target economic growth and competitiveness, not reducing poverty or inequalities. 

This research aims to:

-  build the capacity of PhD students and policymakers gathering at the Rio de Janeiro GLOBELICS Academy in August 2012;
-  develop a framework to capture the dynamics of socially inclusive innovation systems that are not usually evident to policymakers; and
- expand the BRICS research network to include other developing countries. 

	More generally, the research aims to compare how science, technology, and innovation foster development compared to how development interventions achieve this goal. It also aims to foster a better understanding of how innovation and social inclusion operate in emerging economies. Other goals include expanding the network of countries to analyze the dynamics within and between these emerging economies and drawing lessons for neighbouring countries. The research is expected to lead to the creation of alternative development strategies that build on the intensive use of science, technology, and innovation to reduce poverty and contribute to social inclusion.

Prof. K.J. Joseph, CDS Trivandrum and Dr. Dinesh Abrol, NISTADS, New Delhi for and on behalf of Kerala Development Society
Prof. K.J. Joseph, CDS Trivandrum and Dr. Dinesh Abrol, NISTADS, New Delhi for and on behalf of Kerala Development Society

title: Adding A2K Principles to the UN Guidelines for Consumer Protection
description:
The United Nations (UN) Guidelines for Consumer Protection, passed in 1985, were intended as a set of standards for good practices in consumer protection, particularly for developing countries. The UN Guidelines cover eight areas of consumer protection or rights: the right to satisfaction of basic needs, safety, choice, information, consumer education, redressal, representation and a healthy environment. The UN Guidelines are soft or nonbinding law instruments, but they have been influential, The Guidelines have, with adaptations, been adopted into law in many developing countries.
The emergence and spread of digital technologies has resulted in new opportunities and challenges for consumers. There is need to amend the UN Guidelines in light of these developments. This project aims to table amendments and recommendations for the UN Guidelines for Consumer Protection that introduce access to knowledge (A2K) principles, and that promote justice, freedom and economic development.

title: Strengthening Livelihood Security and Adapting to Climate Uncertainty in Chilika Lagoon, India
description:
Chilika is a brackish coastal lagoon and biodiversity hotspot situated in the eastern state of Orissa, India. It is a source of livelihood for more than 200 000 fishers and 400 000 farmers living in and around the wetland and its adjoining catchment area. In recent years, however, climate uncertainty and environmental degradation in the form of salt intrusion and increased sediment loads have affected the hydrological regime and the balance between coastal and freshwater, threatening livelihood security and posing a considerable flood risk, particularly during the monsoon.
Current ecosystem approaches to wetland management do not take climate uncertainty into account. This grant will allow Wetlands International South Asia (WISA), in collaboration local stakeholders, to identify management options for reducing risk and increasing community preparedness for changes in wetland systems due to climate variability. Researchers will elaborate scenarios of changes in ecosystem services due to climate variability; assess current coping mechanisms within vulnerable communities; demonstrate options for enhancing livelihood resilience through pilot interventions; formulate a "climate smart" plan for wetland management; and build the capacity of wetland managers to respond to climate change, particularly as it concerns livelihood resilience.

title: Citizen-centric Delivery of Justice: An Agenda for Democratic Reforms
description:
Governments' commitments to protect women from gender-based violence in South Asia does not always translate into safety, security, and equal access to justice for women. 

Because of failings of the criminal justice system, women do not enjoy the full benefits of citizenship. This reduces the hallmarks of a working democracy, such as upholding the rule of law and safeguarding human rights. 
 
Most states in South Asia claim to be committed to protecting women from violence and holding perpetrators to account. This research aims to help improve how justice is delivered. 

In helping to set an agenda for democratic reforms and in setting up a framework that will support analysis of the effectiveness of the criminal justice system, the Institute for Development and Communication will focus its efforts on the Indian states of Assam, Punjab, and Gujarat. 

The research is expected to lead to the creation of a gender-sensitive social audit tool to mobilize and sensitize citizens and citizens' groups to better ways to deliver justice. Other expected outcomes include a new level of discussion of the core issues among policy groups, civil society, and the media, as well as the building of more peaceful, inclusive, and secure societies with accountable and legitimate governance institutions.

title: Gender and Governance in Conflict Zones: A South Asian Perspective
description:
Women face many barriers to political participation in conflict zones across South Asia, including laws that perpetuate a culture of impunity and lack of justice for victims of violence and abuse by security forces.

To help women in countries like India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and post-war Sri Lanka overcome these and other barriers to political participation, this research focuses on women's specific concerns in conflict zones. 

Research will document two critical challenges women face when trying to influence governance practices in conflict zones:
the impact of strong state security across all South Asian conflict zones, which often creates higher threats to women's physical security and sexual integrity; a culture of impunity among security forces, and a lack of justice for victims of violence and abuse. 

The research study will explore how women's marginalization in politics in South Asian conflict zones is due to governance practices, the political economy underpinning conflict, and local cultural norms rather than to the number of women in governance bodies. It underscores that while a quota strategy is an important way to ensure women's voice and agency in politics, it is inadequate.

The research will bring together researchers, women's groups, women's rights activists, policymakers, the media, non-governmental organizations, and others in three workshops in each of the four countries. A colloquium will be held to explore ways in which women's activism could have a stronger impact on governance and security policy through local and regional networks. Regional workshops and a monograph to share research findings among groups are also planned.

title: Evaluation of Rajiv Aarogyasri Health Insurance Scheme in Andrha Pradesh, India
description:
In 2007, out-of-pocket expenditures accounted for 90% of total private expenditure on healthcare in India. The cost of coping with serious disease can be ruinous for families living below the poverty line. The Rajiv Aarogyasri Health Insurance Scheme was established in Andrha Pradesh to mitigate catastrophic healthcare expenses for enrolled families, and to ensure that the target population has access to quality health services for serious illnesses.
Aarogyasri currently covers more than 80% of the population of Andrha Pradesh. As one of the first schemes of its kind at this scale, Aarogyasri has generated national and international interest. A detailed evaluation is critical not only to keep improving the scheme, but also to ensure that the lessons learned from it benefit other states and countries. 
The Aarogyasri Trust Board has therefore asked a consortium of institutions to evaluate the scheme and consider its potential role in prevention and primary healthcare. This project is a response to that request. The evaluation will also establish a baseline for future evaluations, identify areas for further research, and build capacity for research, evaluation and evidence-based policymaking in India.

title: Asymmetric Demography and Global Financial Governance
description: Different countries are at different stages of demographic change. These differences ("asymmetries") can create opportunities for mutually beneficial financial cooperation between them. However, flaws in the current international financial architecture and weak financial institutions in the developing world may constrain the ability of developing economies to take advantage of these opportunities. Moreover, demographic changes can lead to changes in capital accumulation and savings, and these can aggravate global financial imbalances and increase developed countries' public debt. The financial crisis and the absence of a reliable global liquidity safety net have increased incentives toward protectionism, thus reducing the chance that the window of opportunity provided by demographic change can be used effectively. Research teams in four emerging economies (Brazil, China, India, South Africa) will identify strategies to reform the international and domestic financial architectures and propose these for discussion at the G-20 and other relevant forums.
Centro de Estudios de Estado y Sociedad
Centro de Estudios de Estado y Sociedad

title: Panel Discussion on Africa, Emerging Economies and Trade in National Resources at the WTO Public Forum 2011
description: The importance of emerging economies in trade with and investment in Africa has increased sharply in recent years, reducing Africa's dependence on its traditional partners in Europe and the United States. About one-third of Africa's total trade is now with markets in emerging or developing countries. TERI (The Energy and Resources Institute) is organizing a panel on Africa, Emerging Economies and Trade in Natural Resources at the World Trade Organization (WTO) Public Forum 2011 (Geneva, September 2011). The TERI session will consist of four panellists, two from Africa and one each from China and India, and a moderator (expert-practitioner) from India. This grant will cover the cost of a background paper, and travel and accommodation for the five participants. TERI will publish the highlights of the discussion in the form of a policy brief and disseminate it widely.

title: Making Local Governance Work for Women: Exploring New 	Institutional Possibilities
description:
Digital technologies have the power to transform and to offer developing country women opportunities to advance gender justice and equality. Led by IT for Change, this action research project will examine how information technologies can enhance women's citizenship, increase institutional responsiveness, and promote accountability.

Despite two decades of legal and policy measures to promote gender equality, women struggle to hold a legitimate place in government and democracy in most developing countries. Most are marginalized by poverty and traditional patriarchal societies. This often leaves them subject to technocratic top-down development projects that fail to build their collective identity or help them negotiate power. 

The proposed research will take place over five local sites in three countries: Brazil, India, and South Africa. It will use digital technologies to enable marginalized women to negotiate their roles and to promote more inclusive governance and secure active citizenship. Researchers will use technosocial models - technological aids that influence the way people interact with one another - across different 	developing country contexts.

The project will help shape academic theory and practical knowledge on new opportunities and challenges facing women as they seek to attain full citizenship. It will show local groups how to leverage new 	technology for social and political change, allowing them to foster greater responsiveness and accountability in formal and informal governance structures.
