Instituto Nupef - Núcleo de Pesquisa, Estudos e Formação
Instituto Nupef - Núcleo de Pesquisa, Estudos e Formação

title: Reducing Gender Disparities in India Through Effective Service Delivery
description:
Despite progressive measures to reduce gender disparities in India, there exist wide disparities in women's and girls' education, health, survival rates, employment, and work participation across states and regions. Initiatives include gender budgeting, cash transfer programs, women's employment provisions, and improved coordination between National Mission for Empowerment of Women stakeholders.

This project funding will support the conference, "Reducing Gender Disparities Across States in India Through Effective Service Delivery: Challenges and Opportunities," in Hyderabad, India, in 2012. The conference will examine the implementation challenges that influence the large degree of regional disparities in gender equality achievements in India.

Conference delegates will explore several questions: What are the reasons for these disparities? Why are some states doing better than others? Do patriarchal practices and women's subordination in specific regions hinder success? What impact does women's level of involvement in local self-government have on service delivery? Can government officials demonstrate greater innovations in governance, accountability, and delivery structures? 

The conference will bring together researchers, academics, and representatives from NGOs and state women and child development departments. It will offer a critical look at strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and constraints in addressing gender equality outcomes. Research papers will identify and map distinctions between gender outcomes across states and reflect on the effectiveness of current national and state interventions. 

The conference will provide input into the Ministry of Women and Child Development's policies and programs. The Ministry and the Government of India are providing additional funding. The Administrative Staff College of India is organizing the conference.

title: Labour Market Inequality in Brazil and India: A Comparative Brazil, Russia, India and China (BRIC) Study
description:
Think tanks in Brazil and India are joining forces to examine the factors behind wage inequality in their countries and propose policy options to reduce inequality in labour markets. 

While these two economies have succeeded in reducing poverty and gaining influence in global affairs, both still experience high inequality, though with different patterns. 

In Brazil, inequality has dropped by 9% between 1993 and 2008, while in India,,  it increased by 16%. This reflects the different labour markets in both countries, which provide the main source of income for households.

This research project brings together The Centre for Analysis and Planning in São Paulo (CEBRAP) and the Institute for Human Development in Delhi who will develop comparable measures of inequality in wage income and examine contributing factors such as changes in supply and demand for workers and social factors such as gender, race, and caste. 

Researchers will assess and compare the impact of specific policy instruments in the two countries, and engage social actors in debate on the findings. The project will also encourage interaction between the research communities in Brazil and India to strengthen South-South research collaboration.
Centro Brasileiro de Analise e Planejamento
Centro Brasileiro de Analise e Planejamento

title: Enhanced Preservation of Fruits in South Asia (CIFSRF)
description:
India and Sri Lanka produce an abundance of vegetables and tropical fruits, but post-harvest losses are between 35 and 40%, valued at about $800 million annually. These losses affect the livelihoods of nearly one-third of the population, the majority of which are smallholder farmers. Past research to increase post-harvest shelf life has focused primarily on keeping fruit firm, which is unsuitable for tropical fruits such as mangoes. 

This project brings together research partners from Canada and South Asia to develop a nanotechnology-based packaging system that will extend the shelf life of fruits, thus augmenting local food and livelihood security.

The nano-particles in this project are developed from agricultural waste products, namely the natural fibres extracted from coconut husks and banana plants, creating new income opportunities for small-scale entrepreneurs, particularly women. The project is also building links with the private sector for biodegradable packaging materials.

Researchers expect to adapt the technologies developed in this project to other economically important horticultural crops, including flowers, and vegetables. Benefits for the soft fruit industry, such as berries, can also be extended to Canada.

This project is supported by IDRC and Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development Canada through the Canadian International Food Security Research Fund (CIFSRF).

title: Comparison of Fiscal and Regulatory Policies to Prevent Non-Communicable Diseases in India
description:
India is facing a rising burden of cardiovascular disease and obesity-related diabetes due to increasingly unhealthy diets and tobacco use. 

Educational initiatives to reduce the consumption of "'risky commodities"' such as foods high in salt and sugar, palm oils, and cigarettes have been disappointing. As a result, fiscal and regulatory strategies such as food taxes have been proposed to limit consumption of these goods. 

This project will explore how to implement these kinds of strategies to maximize health and economic benefits while minimizing potential adverse consequences. Although many studies suggest that fiscal and regulatory approaches can be beneficial, questions remain whether they could have unintended consequences for public health or economic development in India. 

For example, would reducing salt intake cause greater iodine deficiency, already a significant risk among rural populations? Will taxes on high-sugar foods negatively affect the economy? How will reducing subsidies to palm oils and increasing subsidies for alternative oils affect food supplies? Will tobacco taxation cause an increase in cardiovascular disease deaths if users switch from taxed cigarettes to bidis (a popular, thin Indian-manufactured cigarette)? 

Researchers will develop mathematical models designed to simulate fiscal and regulatory strategies. They will incorporate recently collected survey data of disease risk and consumer purchasing into the models to determine optimal strategies. 

Indian legislators are expected to use the study results to inform debates on existing and future legislation regarding nutrition and tobacco policy at the national and state levels. The research will also provide new knowledge about alternative approaches to regulation and fiscal policy and how to minimize any adverse effects.
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University
Board of Trustees of the Leland Stanford Junior University

title: Foreign Assistance Policies of India and China
description:
International development assistance has traditionally been dominated by former colonial powers and wealthy industrialized nations. But today, emerging economies are beginning to make their mark: these new, emerging donors are an increasingly important source of financial flows into poor countries. India, for example, is among the top five donors to Afghanistan. Understanding what motivates emerging donors is of interest to both recipient countries and members of the established donor community. 

This grant supports a comparative study of the emerging foreign aid programs of India and China. The study analyzes these programs in the context of the international aid regime and each country's long-term economic and foreign policy strategies. The study will be jointly undertaken by Indian and Chinese scholars. 

Both countries tend to operate on the basis of regional and international power politics and their own national interests in pursuing aid policies, particularly vis-à-vis their neighbours. While the aid policies of these countries have garnered attention, there is, as yet, little understanding of their systems and strategies. This study addresses this gap by updating data on each country's foreign assistance and mapping the institutions involved, the beneficiaries, the sectors they are investing in, and their funding approaches. It also examines the underlying philosophy that guides each country's foreign assistance policies.
University of Pennsylvania Institute for the Advanced Study of India
University of Pennsylvania Institute for the Advanced Study of India

title: Edited Book on India and Multilateralism
description:
This grant links an international centre in New York with the Centre for Policy Research (CPR) in New Delhi to produce an edited book on India's approach to multilateralism.

As the economic, political, and military strength of traditional world powers recedes, India is reasserting itself on the global stage. New York University's Center on International Cooperation (NYU-CIC) will collaborate with the CPR in New Delhi to examine the drivers of India's current foreign and security policies.

The book's editor and project leader, Pal Sidhu, works at NYU-CIC. His investment in setting a focus for the book puts the project on a sound footing. His reputation as an author and international expert on security and foreign policy issues has allowed him to secure the participation of an impressive list of contributors. During the project's early days, experts in the field will convene to discuss factors that determine India's approach to multilateralism. Analysis of those factors will focus on how this approach might help to build healthier and more prosperous societies. 

The outcome of this work will be an edited volume on the topic.

title: Support for Studying the Gendered Impact of Security Policies and Laws in India
description:
This funding aims to support work required to document the impact of certain Indian security policies and laws on women.

In late 2010, the United Nations' (UN) Special Rapporteur, Margaret Sekaggya, embarked on a fact-finding mission to assess the situation of human rights defenders in India. Based on her travels to New Delhi, Bhubaneshwar (Orissa), Kolkata (West Bengal), Guwahati (Assam), 
Ahmedabad (Gujarat), Jammu, and Srinagar (Jammu and Kashmir), she reported that that while India faces serious security challenges, the use of security laws at the national and state levels - most notably the Public Security Act, the Armed Forces (Special) Powers Act, the Public Safety Act, and the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act - compromise citizens' human rights. This grant will help to document how this situation is affecting women in India.

In recent years, bodies such as the UN have come to accept that modern armed conflicts have a strong impact on women and girls, even though they are generally not directly engaged in combat. After the Bosnian and Rwanda conflicts, the UN Security Council introduced Resolution 1325, -adopted in October 2000, stating that it was important, in the future, to ensure that women's needs and views be part of conflict prevention, peace processes, peacekeeping operations, and recovery when conflicts end. Because the resolution's objectives remained mostly "on paper" and were not being integrated as intended, the UN's Special Rapporteur completed her tour of India in 2010. 

Long years of conflict in various parts of India have left communities bereft of peace and development that they rightfully deserve. The support this funding provides will increase knowledge of the impacts that certain Indian laws and security policies are having on women.

title: Support to the 10th International Consortium on Anti-Virals International Symposium
description:
This grant will give scholars from Indian and Canadian institutions the opportunity to participate in the International Consortium on Anti-Virals (ICAV) in February 2012. 

ICAV is hosting its 10th International Symposium in Delhi, India, in partnership with the International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology. The theme of the meeting involves ways to develop safe, affordable, and effective anti-viral therapies for new and neglected infectious diseases. 

The symposium will attract scientists, public health experts, industry representatives, and philanthropic organizations. Topics include both the science and features of emerging and re-emerging infectious disease, governance, funding, and selection criteria for possible interventions.

The symposium may provide an ideal platform to announce a bilateral, India-Canada, Infectious Disease strategy.
International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology
International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology

title: Conference on Understanding Change in Rural India: Perspective on Longitudinal Village Studies
description:
This two-day conference will bring together scholars from different disciplines who have been doing longitudinal village studies across India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh. 

Longitudinal village studies are enjoying a revival among researchers. This may be because they are uniquely equipped to provide insight into long-term economic, social, and political transformations in villages. In particular, such studies can shed light on the processes that underlie unequal growth and the effect this has on rural groups. From a policy perspective, longitudinal village studies improve people's understanding of cause-and-effect in village settings, and may help to define or develop future policy choices.

Many discussions about inclusive growth in India increasingly focus on the fact that rural areas and villages can no longer be ignored. Scholars working on longitudinal village studies in Pakistan and Bangladesh, along with other South Asian countries, may be able to learn from India's experiences as well as their own, since the contexts are often similar. 

The planned conference will bring together about 25 researchers (with a few doctoral students) from various disciplines, and about five people from policy circles. Their gathering in the fall of 2012 will allow them to share learning from the rich and complex data that has emerged from longitudinal village studies. 

Organizers expect up to 12 international participants. This research support project will provide funding for six.

title: Brainstorming Meeting to Examine Enforced Disappearances and the Spiral of Impunity in Conflict Zones In South Asia
description:
Across South Asia, the people of Sri Lanka, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Afghanistan, and Nepal have been caught in widespread or localized armed conflict. While the causes and scale of conflict vary in each country, a widespread pattern of human rights violations has emerged. This research support project aims to develop a research agenda to examine state impunity and improve international norms and standards in the region. 

State responses to conflict in these countries has involved enacting counter-terrorism measures that may include

- enacting emergency laws
- imposing laws that do not meet constitutional and international standards 
- imposing martial law (directly or implied) 
- employing military and paramilitary forces against civilians beyond the normal rules of justice, and
- suspending fundamental rights without any access to remedies.  

These types of responses have led to violations of human rights that are often identified as crimes under international law. The violations may include acts such as torture, killings not sanctioned by law or the justice system, and enforced disappearances. 

This lack of accountability has been dubbed a "spiral of impunity." It has a negative impact on the region's stability and undermines efforts to build democratic institutions among South Asia governments. 

Legal and human rights experts in South Asia want to develop a research agenda to examine problems of enforced disappearance and illegal state actions in conflict zones in their countries.

Experts attending this brainstorming meeting aim to develop an analysis to challenge state impunity in the region and to deepen international norms and standards in South Asia. The three-day meeting will review commissioned country background papers on enforced disappearances and impunity and produce a paper identifying gaps in knowledge and proposals for future work.
Institute for Development Education and Learning (IDEAL)
Institute for Development Education and Learning (IDEAL)

title: Exposure Visits of Community Groups: India's Urban Slum Dwellers to Visit Others Like Themselves
description:
People living in India's urban slums may be better able to resist slum demolitions by learning from each other.

Increasing urbanization in India and a desire among middle- and high-income classes for "world-class" cities has caused slums to be evicted on a large scale. Women and youth are most seriously affected when it comes to loss of shelter, jobs in the informal sector, basic services, and access to welfare. Their attempts to resist slum demolitions are often hampered by a lack of information about government policies, a lack of skills to convert knowledge into action, and difficulty getting wider support for their campaigns.

Since 1997, the Hazards Centre - a wing of the Sanchal Foundation - has helped community groups, labour organizations, and development agencies deal with issues such as slum governance, health, education, shelter, jobs, and environmental protection. One of the central findings of the Hazard Centre is that community groups can make great strides when they share their experiences. 

To this end, IDRC will support seven visits among representatives of target community groups in cities across India in 2012. The people visiting others l will include homeless people, informal waste pickers, migrants from minority and marginalized groups, and informal sector workers, such as casual labourers, skilled artisans, hawkers, and rickshaw pullers.
  
The cities involved are Delhi, Hyderabad, Pune, Mumbai, and Bengaluru. Four of the visits will see Delhi groups going to other cities, and three others will involve groups from other cities visiting Delhi or other cities. Each visit will average three days. Ten people selected by their communities will participate in each visit. 

The goal is for urban slum dwellers to share successful ways to resist and survive displacement. The visits are also expected to reduce each group's sense of isolation and alienation.

title: Research on Innovation Systems and Social Inclusion (RISSI): Policy and Planning Workshop
description:
IDRC supported a comparative study of national innovation systems in the BRICS countries (Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa) from 2006 to 2010. To build on this work and set the stage for a new research program focusing on social inclusion, IDRC is supporting a workshop at Tshwane University of Technology, Pretoria, South Africa in March 2012.

This workshop aims to be a learning and training event for partners in southern Africa's policy community. Specifically, it aims to initiate a dialogue to learn from the findings from the earlier research on innovation systems, as well as to discuss the next steps toward a research project oriented to improving the understanding of how science, technology, and innovation can contribute to reducing poverty. The meeting will also give participants a chance to discuss the methods and processes involved in expanding research to a second tier of countries, namely Kenya, Nigeria, Peru, Thailand, Vietnam, and Uruguay. 

The new network will be known as Research on Innovation Systems and Social Inclusion (RISSI).

title: Support for a Dialogue on Economic Cooperation between India and Canada
description:
Research and Information System for Developing Countries (RIS), an Indian Ministry of External Affairs think tank, is working to strengthen the engagement of Indian and Canadian scholars in governmental discussions on trade, investment, and economic relations in the context of the Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) proposed by both countries' Prime Ministers for 2013. 

This grant will support a two-day session in June 2012 that will bring together Indian government representatives, economists, private sector groups, and leading trade scholars with a select group of Canadian scholars. The meetings will happen in India, with specific agenda topics identified by the Government of India. 

RIS will also organize other meetings and interviews for visiting Canadian scholars with a variety of Indian groups.
Research and Information System for Developing Countries
Research and Information System for Developing Countries

title: Undernourishment and Public Policy in India
description:
Scientists, donors, and Indian policymakers are puzzled why India has the highest percentage of undernourished children in the world. This project explores the reasons why the country's high economic growth rate has not translated into better nutrition for its people, particularly poor women and children. It aims to shape policies underlying the development of India's proposed National Food Security Act. As well, it will help restructure the public food distribution system and the delivery of social welfare programs that affect food and nutritional security. 

The project's two streams are led by the National Council for Applied Economic Research (India) and the Institute of Development Studies (United Kingdom). The first stream will analyze national data sets to examine the magnitude and distribution of malnutrition, how income and dietary compositions affect nutrition, the different effects on women and men, and how nutrition is connected to water, sanitation, and hygiene. The second stream of the project will analyze policy needs for designing and implementing nutrition-focused initiatives. 

These projects will establish research gaps and lead to the commissioning of 15 to18 research articles analyzing identified needs. Those articles will feed into policy development through briefs, website content for the Institute of Development Studies, other online platforms, and the publication of an edited book and/or journal issue. A symposium in India will share research results with key policymakers, researchers, civil society, and the media in order to highlight the issue of malnutrition in the country and spur action.
National Council of Applied Economic Research
National Council of Applied Economic Research

title: Undernourishment and Public Policy in India
description:
Scientists, donors, and Indian policymakers are puzzled why India has the highest percentage of undernourished children in the world. This project explores the reasons why the country's high economic growth rate has not translated into better nutrition for its people, particularly poor women and children. It aims to shape policies underlying the development of India's proposed National Food Security Act. As well, it will help restructure the public food distribution system and the delivery of social welfare programs that affect food and nutritional security. 

The project's two streams are led by the National Council for Applied Economic Research (India) and the Institute of Development Studies (United Kingdom). The first stream will analyze national data sets to examine the magnitude and distribution of malnutrition, how income and dietary compositions affect nutrition, the different effects on women and men, and how nutrition is connected to water, sanitation, and hygiene. The second stream of the project will analyze policy needs for designing and implementing nutrition-focused initiatives. 

These projects will establish research gaps and lead to the commissioning of 15 to18 research articles analyzing identified needs. Those articles will feed into policy development through briefs, website content for the Institute of Development Studies, other online platforms, and the publication of an edited book and/or journal issue. A symposium in India will share research results with key policymakers, researchers, civil society, and the media in order to highlight the issue of malnutrition in the country and spur action.

title: Support to the 2012 Indian National Conference on Universal Health Coverage: Advancing the Agenda and Addressing the Challenges
description:
India's politicians may be ready to implement universal health coverage, and this conference aims to support that agenda.

In October 2010, India created a high-level Expert Group to review the experiences of India's health sector and to recommend ways to advance universal health coverage. The Public Health Foundation of India has provided technical expertise and logistical support to the Expert Group. 

This grant will support a two-day national conference followed by a one-day symposium convened by the Health Economics Association of India. The events, to be held in New Delhi in April 2012, aim to actively engage various stakeholders involved in the reforms by reviewing the recommendations of the high level group, and identifying specific challenges linked to implementing universal health coverage in India.

The groups likely to attend the events include health experts, policymakers, civil society groups, academics, and the media.

title: From Data to Development: Exploring the Emerging Impact of Open Government Data in Developing Countries
description:
Releasing freely accessible, standardized, and easily readable government data can increase transparency and accountability. This open government data movement can foster greater civic participation and promote new business opportunities.

Worldwide, governments have posted an estimated one-million datasets on the Internet. A small fraction of these datasets comes from developing countries, but this is changing rapidly. Citizens in Brazil, Nepal, and Nigeria can now use publicly available government budget data to track and fight corruption. Developers and entrepreneurs across Latin America, Africa, and Asia can create Web and mobile applications using government data on education, health, and crime to promote smarter and more efficient local public services.

In the developed world, open government data has delivered economic benefits. The re-use of public sector data in the Eurozone generated EUR32 billion in 2010. A UK study valued the economic impact of open government data at GBP6 billion per year. Qualitative evidence shows that open data can stem corruption and increase accountability. Much less is known about its impact in the developing world.

Open government data offers the potential for greater government accountability, efficiency, and transparency in the developing world. It can also create new economic opportunities for all segments of society. However, rigorous evidence on the use, outcomes, and impact of these objectives remains scarce. Those responsible for funding and implementing these programs must understand emerging best practices. They must also have insight into the varying impacts of open data in strikingly different social, economic, and cultural contexts. 

This project will help create a research network to explore the implications of releasing government data. More specifically, it will aim to:

-generate research on the emerging impacts of open data interventions
-deliver policy and practice findings that can inform local and global debates
-build research capacity worldwide to explore the emerging impacts of open data.

The World Wide Web Foundation will administer the proposed research network. The organization promotes and supports an Internet that is open, usable, and valuable for everyone, particularly developing countries. It will include 18 partners in Latin America, Africa, and Asia who will undertake case studies to assess existing initiatives, challenges, emerging outcomes, and impacts. 

The research will address key issues and gaps in knowledge. For example, well-intentioned open data initiatives may cause adverse effects by exacerbating social or economic inequalities. They can favour well-resourced groups that are more capable of extracting value from the data for their own economic and political gain. Commercial elites in Bangalore, for example, have used the digitization of land records to find gaps in title and errors in documentation to gain ownership of land occupied by poor communities.

The project will also develop data collection instruments to help explain if and how open data is bringing change to developing countries. It will engage policymakers at global and local levels to foster robust evidence-based practice in this emerging policy area.

title: Sexual and Domestic Violence: Policy Protocols
description:
India is witnessing a rising rate of crime against women. According to recent National Crime Bureau data, a rape happens every 26 minutes, molestation every 14 minutes, dowry death every 63 minutes, and acts of cruelty by husband and relatives every 6 minutes. 

Charge-sheets are filed in 92% of these cases, but the conviction rate is 27%. For cases of reported rape, the conviction rate is even lower, suggesting high levels of impunity. While strong laws are in place, justice eludes the victims.

This project aims to provide women who are victims of violence with greater access to justice and more equitable power within the criminal legal system. By uncovering lacunae in the law and developing protocols for better legal implementation, it will contribute to ending impunity for such crimes. 

An innovative methodology will document approximately 150 victims' experience of accessing justice for rape and domestic violence while the cases play out in the family, community, police station, and court rooms. 

In addition, the project will study how domestic violence law works for ordinary women in the 35 urban and rural districts of Maharashtra. It will also look at positive court rulings in domestic violence cases and analyze these for use by judges and prosecutors.

This project is the first of its kind and findings are likely to have a major impact on policy and programs.

title: Creating Livelihoods for Urban Slum Women
description:
The urban poor are a rapidly increasing segment of India's population. Many have migrated from rural areas, landing in slums and squatter settlements. A large proportion of these are traditional craftspeople and artisans, including semi-skilled women.
 
This project targets this group of women by providing and harnessing skills in textiles, foods, and crafts. The aim is to identify women with artisanal skills and then re-train them to make more marketable products, especially those with high margins and low volumes.

The Swami Sivananda Memorial Institute (SSMI), with its mission of empowering women to achieve their potential with dignity, will pilot this initiative. The project will target one of SSMI's urban slum clusters in West Delhi, through their Samjik Suvidha Kendra (Gender Resource Centre), which has a catchment area of 15 colonies and about 100,000 people.

SSMI has an established design and production centre called Subha, where the women's products will be designed and produced. The project aims to increase Subha's overall product output by 25%. This one-year project is part of the Good Neighbour project, funded by IDRC's regional office in New Delhi. The Good Neighbour Project addresses social and development issues of marginal communities in and around New Delhi.
Swami Sivananda Memorial Institute of Fine Arts and Crafts
Swami Sivananda Memorial Institute of Fine Arts and Crafts

title: The Justice Project in South Asia
description:
As countries in South Asia move toward greater economic integration, a range of interconnected challenges to constitutional and human rights guarantees are emerging. These challenges revolve around established norms, gender-based violence, poor justice delivery mechanisms, and inconsistent legal practices and protections. Together, these factors produce distinct patterns of violent conflict, social and cultural inequalities, structural injustices, and governance gaps across the region.

The Justice Project brings together prominent documentary film-makers, senior scholars, and practitioners to document the state of justice in the region. It will produce research papers and five films in Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and India on violent conflict and its aftermath; conflict and gender-based violence; justice delivery systems; group conflict, public space, and state order; and land, conflict, and the nation state. These films and papers aim to influence public policy and raise public awareness about the importance of challenging impunity in conflict and post-conflict contexts.

title: Studying Alcohol Pricing and Taxation Policies in India
description:
India is the third largest market for alcoholic beverages in the world. As many as 32% of Indians consume alcohol, with 4% to 13% consuming it daily. While per capita alcohol consumption has fallen since 1980 in most developed countries, it has risen over 115% in India. While excessive alcohol consumption has become a health, social, and developmental concern, there is little research in India on how taxation affects alcohol consumption. 

This project proposes to fill this critical gap and to help Indian policymakers develop effective alcohol control policies. The Public Health Foundation of India will carry out the research. The research team will study trends in alcohol taxation and pricing policies across 10 selected Indian states and analyze their linkages with alcohol expenditure patterns and consumption over 12 years (from 2001 to 2012). 

Researchers will use econometric models to estimate price and taxation elasticities-or how changing one economic variable will affect others. These estimates will account for specific beverages and differences between rural and urban populations. The controlled analysis will include a series of state-level and household-level confounders (extraneous or hidden variables). They will collect data from multiple sources, including the National Sample Survey Office of India and the 10 state excise tax departments. 

Based on the results, researchers will recommend evidence-based alcohol taxation policies suited to the Indian context. They will disseminate the results through scientific papers, media briefs, and policy briefs for legislators, administrators, and alcohol control advocates in India, as well as throughout South and Southeast Asia.

title: TTI Matching Funds: Strengthening Communication Skills of Researchers
description:
The Think Tank Initiative (TTI) is a multi-funder program dedicated to strengthening independent policy research organizations in developing countries. Its provision of core funding and technical support helps grantee organizations improve their research quality, policy linkages, and overall organizational performance. This research support project is part of TTI's grants of matching funds to promote peer learning and collaboration.

Effective communication of policy research-which is critical for evidence-informed policy-making-depends on researchers' communication skills. Developing researchers' capacity for improved communication is also a long-term institutional objective of two TTI grantee institutions in India: the Center for Study of Science, Technology and Policy (CSTEP) and the Public Affairs Centre (PAC). CSTEP is at the forefront of applying scientific and social research outputs for policy recommendations, while PAC focuses on its globally renowned citizen monitoring and social audit tools, and on collaboration with policymakers. This research support project will enable these institutions jointly to enroll 30 research staff for a customized training program on communication skills. Since both CSTEP and PAC are engaged in policy research and share similar objectives, their collaboration on this training could promote further cooperation in substantive areas of research between the two institutes.
Center for Study of Science, Technology and Policy
Center for Study of Science, Technology and Policy

title: Analyzing Financial Flows from Emerging Economies to the Developing World
description:
The context of development assistance is changing, with private financial flows now well exceeding official development assistance levels. In addition, growth in emerging economies in the coming 10-to-15 years will likely result in sizable increases in aid-like flows from these countries, further changing the traditional aid landscape. 

Despite these trends, there is currently no systematic collection or dissemination of these flows. This project will measure and analyze four types of financial flows - official development assistance, global philanthropy, remittances and private capital investment - to the developing world by Brazil, India, China, South Africa, and other selected emerging economies.

Deriving best possible estimates for South-South flows will fill an important gap in development thinking and policy by providing information on the amount and types of financial flows. The data and analysis will inform current thinking on the role of so-called "new donors" and private actors, and suggest areas where future research is warranted. 

The trends extracted from the research will be useful to donors, emerging economies and developing countries alike in understanding these changing dynamics. Results of the research will be published in the Center for Global Prosperity's annual Index of Global Philanthropy and Remittances, and will comprise the focus of the 2013 publication. Results will also be disseminated through seminars, the Center for Global Prosperity blog, targeted media outreach, op-eds, and white papers.

title: Workshop on Time Use Data Collection and Analysis for Policy-Making
description:
Time use statistics and analysis are important tools for understanding human development and gender inequalities. They provide information on all forms of paid and unpaid work, its distribution by socioeconomic group, and its relationship to inclusive growth. However, the application of time-use statistics and an appreciation of their policy implications for development are not widespread.

The International Association of Time Use Research, in association with the International Association for Feminist Economics, has established a global program of training workshops to increase capacity to carry out time-use studies in developing countries. 

The goal of this project is to build capacity of selected participants in time-use studies by implementing one of these training workshops. The workshop will be held in 2012 in New Delhi, coordinated by the Centre for Development Alternatives, in collaboration with the National Academy of Statistical Administration of the Ministry of Statistics and Program Implementation, Government of India. 

Participants were selected from developing countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America. The workshop will consist of hands-on training exercises focusing on empirical techniques for conducting time-use studies. It will help to increase the ability of participants to design and implement policy-relevant time-use studies, and raise awareness of the importance of time-use surveys for gender-aware development.

title: South Asia Conference on the Changing Dynamics of Peacebuilding in South Asia: Recasting Women's Agency and Transformative Strategies
description:
Promoting women's participation in all aspects of peacebuilding, including peace negotiations and mediation, is slowly being recognized as the missing piece in successful post-conflict recovery and reconstruction. Awareness is also growing about the fact that the exclusion of women and the lack of gender expertise in negotiations lead to setbacks for women that are difficult to reverse. These setbacks often deprive them of access to justice, reparations, economic opportunity, and security.

This project will provide support for the conference, "The Changing Dynamics of Peacebuilding in South Asia: Recasting Women's Agency and Transformative Strategies." The conference will aim to generate knowledge about women's participation in peace processes and post-conflict reconstruction.  

South Asia has a rich history of peacebuilding. It offers valuable lessons on strategies that have worked to enhance women's participation in political settlements and peace processes. There is a need for researchers to examine these important experiments in women's participation to understand whether they lead to strong outcomes. Sri Lanka has a gender subcommittee, which ensures women's participation at the peace table. Nepal offers an example of how women elected to the Constituent Assembly are shaping that country's constitution. They represent a cross-section of class, caste, and ethnicity in Nepal. The key question, however, is whether these inclusive processes actually led to inclusive outcomes.

The South Asia conference will examine the gendered challenges confronting peacebuilding and post-conflict reconstruction. Senior South Asian academics and practitioners will lead the program, which will:
-respond to the complex challenges confronting women building peace and empowerment in contexts of violent conflict; 
-document contributions that have been overlooked in formal negotiations; and, 
-consider mechanisms that will enable women to have an impact on peacebuilding and reconstruction.
South Asia Forum for Human Rights Limited
South Asia Forum for Human Rights Limited

title: Informal Employment and Inclusive Growth in Asia: Planning Workshop
description:
IDRC's project on Informal Employment, Poverty and Growth in India and China revealed major differences between the two countries. Following the project, consultations took place between the project coordinators and researchers from Thailand and Indonesia about developing a similar project throughout the Asia involving ASEAN partners. 

This project aims to arrive at a common set of policy research questions and methodological approaches addressing informal employment issues in India, China, and the ASEAN region, leading to the development of a research proposal. 

A project planning workshop will be held in December 2012 in Bangkok, Thailand, coordinated by the Thailand Development Research Institute. Participants will include researchers from the Institute of Rural Management Anand in India, the Institute of Population and Labor Economics of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, the Centre for Asia Pacific Studies, and The Universitas Gadjah Mada in Indonesia. Advisors and government officials from the region will also participate.

To facilitate discussion and planning, participants will make presentations on specific research issues and policy questions pertaining to their countries and the region. These will include, for example, why some high value activities remain informal, and what policy measures encourage or discourage formalization. They will also reflect on gender issues around informality, vulnerability, mobility, and formalization.

title: Justice in Perspective: Building Consensus for Seeking Justice for Past Crimes
description:
In South Asia, the movement for justice for past crimes reached an important milestone with the establishment of the First War Crimes Criminal Tribunal in Bangladesh in 2012. However, the tribunal has run into serious trouble with allegations of misconduct and concerns over a lack of fair trial safeguards.

This project will help address this situation and will provide funding for Bangladeshi scholars and human rights practitioners to begin a national consultation process. The aim is to build consensus among public intellectuals on a legitimate justice process to address the crimes committed during the liberation of Bangladesh in 1971.  

As the country marked the 40th anniversary of liberation, the War Crimes Criminal Tribunal was to hold a historic trial against the perpetrators responsible for killing thousands of people, including hundreds of secular intellectuals, just before the liberation on December 16, 1971. 

When the War Crimes Tribunal was activated in 2012, it began prosecuting the cases involving the Pakistani army and their local collaborators. Today, a number of cases are awaiting verdicts. However, the trial process is now in question. 

In December 2012, the presiding tribunal judge resigned amid criticism of his conduct. The tribunal is trying 10 opposition politicians on charges of arson, rape, and other atrocities committed during the war of independence from Pakistan. Opposition political parties mounted campaigns against the tribunal, terming it a political plot to discredit the opposition. Amnesty International also claimed that the International Crimes Tribunal Act of 1973, and its 2009 amendment, under which the trials in Bangladesh are being held, lacks "adequate fair trial safeguards."

As the trial process has come under an increasingly hostile campaign at home and abroad, the fear is that the long-awaited moment for survivors and their families to see justice is once again at risk. Public intellectuals, researchers, human rights practitioners, women's rights activists, and concerned citizens in Bangladesh and other parts of South Asia are trying to keep the demand for justice alive. They are pointing to concrete legal and procedural measures which such tribunals should adhere to in order to preserve the legitimacy of the process. International human rights groups are also contributing to the process so that the trials are fair and impartial. IDRC, which is committed to finding effective ways to assist local communities in developing and acting on the knowledge they need, has been mobilized to help as well.

title: "Understanding Impunity": Publication and Dissemination
description:
This research support project will assist Zubaan, an independent non-profit publishing house in India, to edit, print, and disseminate essays and empirical material generated through the study, "Understanding Impunity: Failures and Possibilities of Rights to Truth, Justice, and Reparation." 

Supported under earlier IDRC programming on peace, conflict, and reconstruction, the study aims to arrive at fresh conclusions regarding the origins, workings, and culture of impunity. Impunity is the failure to bring perpetrators of human rights violations to justice. The fieldwork conducted as part of the project generated a collection of 143 case studies from three states in India. Researchers also compiled 25 academic articles, an inventory of Web-based sources on impunity, and a list of landmark cases from one of the three states to complement the primary research findings. 

The published research will make available analytical articles from experts in the field and case material generated through field studies.

Zubaan has published work on impunity and has a solid publication record. It is known for high quality publications and its excellent capacity to disseminate material widely. It has been an intellectual partner in this project's long journey and will see the project through this final stage to completion.

title: Building Evidence from Intervention Research on Violence Against Women
description:
Violence against women in India is a complex issue. Conducting research on the subject is fraught with ethical and methodological challenges because there are safety and confidentiality concerns for respondents. There is also social stigma and fear among survivors. As a result, there is little reliable social research on violence against women in India. Existing feminist analysis is often based on a small number of case studies. Although India's National Crime Records Bureau presents annual data on violence against women, it is drawn from police records and does not go beyond reporting statistics. There is a gap in knowledge about how violence plays out in the lives of women and how institutions respond in crisis situations.

This research project aims to produce an evidence-based analysis of domestic violence and sexual assault in India to assist with building a comprehensive, gender-sensitive healthcare response to sexual assault. India does not include domestic violence in health policy or public health programs. This analysis will help support ongoing advocacy, policy-making, and public interventions. The Centre for Enquiry Into Health and Allied Themes (CEHAT), a research centre of Anusandhan Trust, will lead the project, analyze data, and write papers for peer-reviewed journals. 

In 2000, CEHAT collaborated with the Municipal Corporation of Greater Mumbai to establish a response to domestic violence at a public hospital. This initiative, known as "Dilaasa," was the first attempt to make accountable and sensitize India's health sector to the issue of violence against women. Dilaasa trained healthcare providers to recognize and respond to women reporting violence. A crisis intervention department was established where women facing domestic violence could receive psychosocial support. 

To sustain the programs, a core group of doctors and nurses was selected to train their peers on how to respond to women seeking help. The training was offered to professionals in five hospitals and led to the emergence of a committed group of about 60 health professionals. They raised concerns about the need for a comprehensive response to survivors of sexual violence. They observed that the protocols for examination were not systematic across the hospitals and that doctors had no training in this area. 

CEHAT seized the opportunity to establish a model for providing comprehensive services to sexual assault survivors at three of the hospitals that received a substantial number of survivors of sexual assault. This intervention produced rich empirical data from 2,400 case studies of women facing domestic violence and 100 sexual assault survivors. Data on burn cases taken from the hospital register and crisis centre records was also mined for analysis.

CEHAT will analyze this data and write papers for peer-reviewed journals. The papers will help ensure that the analysis is translated into scientific evidence to support policy planning and gender-sensitive health sector action that responds to gender-based violence.

title: Asia Regional Office: Lecture Series
description:
IDRC's Asia Regional Office lecture series, held at the Ramalingaswami Conference Hall in New Delhi, provides a forum for IDRC partners to share their research findings, new ideas, and project experience with their peers, donor representatives, academia, policymakers, IDRC staff, and other guests. This grant will enable the Asia Regional Office to organize public policy dialogues and debates around major regional economic, political, and social issues in 2013-14.

The lectures will be delivered at the Conference Hall and other venues in New Delhi, including the Canadian High Commission. Funding will also allow program staff to invite scholars from within the region to New Delhi. More specifically, it will achieve the following:
- facilitate and promote participation by policymakers, decision-makers, academics, business people, professionals, and other members of civil society to explore Asia's public policy issues; and 
- celebrate IDRC's contribution to public policy and social science research through commemorative lectures by influential policy researchers and share current directions for policy research and research support in the region.

The lecture series was launched in in 2001 to inaugurate the Conference Hall, which is named after former IDRC Governor, Dr. Vulimiri Ramalingaswami. Since then, eminent scholars, policymakers, grassroots workers, and development researchers have been invited to lead seminar discussions.

title: Compiling Scholarly Material on India's Foreign Policy: History, Institutions, and Relations
description:
An emerging economy's actions on the world stage influence poverty and growth at home and within neighbouring countries. Foreign policy, combined with bilateral and multilateral relations, plays a role in determining a country's opportunities.

While there is a wealth of analysis on India's foreign policy, it is fragmented among memoirs, commentary, journalism, and scholarly books-the majority of which are not available outside the country. The Centre for Policy Research in New Delhi will address this gap. The Centre will draw this material together into an authoritative survey covering India's foreign policy history and institutions, along with its bilateral and multilateral relations. 

Specifically, project funding will help convene three workshops to prepare a series of invited papers. Each paper will synthesize existing knowledge, drawing on literature and primary material. The Centre will incorporate these papers into an edited volume that will contribute to existing literature on how emerging economies contribute to and influence global governance.
(Chief, Administrative Services) for and on behalf of Centre for Policy Research Registered Society
(Chief, Administrative Services) for and on behalf of Centre for Policy Research Registered Society

title: Water Security and Chronic Under-Nutrition in India
description:
Despite its relatively robust economic growth, India has the largest number of underdeveloped, or stunted, children in the world; more than over 40% of Indian children under five are moderately or severely underweight. India faces another important health challenge: open defecation. With 575 million people in rural areas or 69% of the rural population and 18% of urban dwellers with no access to clean, safe toilet facilities, open defecation and malnourishment are issues with huge implications for nutrition, water, sanitation, and hygiene.

This project will allow researchers to critically assess the linkages between nutrition, water, sanitation, and hygiene to inform policy and program design in India. A team of water, sanitation, and hygiene specialists at UNICEF will lead the project.

Stunting depends on food intake, general health status, and the physical environment. Access to safe water, sanitation, and hygiene systems and services is critically linked to all three factors that influence stunting. When young children and infants ingest faecal matter, it causes infection or diarrhea. Worse yet, it severely undermines a child's nutrition status and can cause irreparable damage to long-term physical and cognitive growth.

There is little evidence available globally to assess the impact of improved water, sanitation, and hygiene on reducing stunting. UNICEF's conceptual framework (1990) on the causes of under-nutrition makes it clear that nutritional status is a function of access to food, care practices, health services, and an environment without faecal matter. 

There is a lack of inter-sectoral evidence on program interventions or best practices which have had an impact on child malnutrition. UNICEF itself addresses nutritional gains separately from its evaluation of how improved water, sanitation, and hygiene contribute to health. More importantly, there is limited gender-specific data, particularly in India. Without a clear understanding of how gender inequality intersects with access to water, sanitation, food, and nutritional security, researchers cannot provide full analysis and policy recommendations.

This project will allow researchers to review all available secondary data, both quantitative and qualitative, to better understand the correlations and links between improved water, sanitation, and health and nutrition across different socio-economic groups in India. 

The research team will write a chapter for a book on under-nutrition and public policy in India. They will also prepare an article for a peer-reviewed journal. UNICEF will use the evidence to design advocacy and communication strategies and to influence programming on food and nutritional security in India.

title: Conflicts around Water Use in Rainfed Agriculture: Addressing the Cross-Sectoral Dimensions
description:
Water scarcity is increasing worldwide. Conflicts over access to water for agriculture do not happen in isolation. They cross sectors and needs. They include conflicts between access to drinking water and access to irrigation water. In India, the existing legal framework for dealing with these conflicts is conceptually sound, but loses potency when different needs simultaneously come into play. These result in contestations. The problem is largely based on India's sectoral understanding of water, which considers surface and groundwater rights separately. There are also distinct regulations for irrigation and drinking water supplies.

This project will examine the Rajsamand Lake dispute, which has been under judicial proceedings for several years. Researchers will collect primary data from a range of stakeholders and use secondary material to analyze this case study. The project will fill a key research gap. It will unearth and highlight the kinds of problems, both theoretical and empirical, which arise when various water rights clash-in this case, irrigation and drinking water. 

The project will result in a set of relevant policy recommendations on the issue. The research team will publish the findings in a peer-reviewed journal.
(Chief, Administrative Services) for and on behalf of Centre for Policy Research Registered Society
(Chief, Administrative Services) for and on behalf of Centre for Policy Research Registered Society

title: Author's Workshop: Building an Indian State for the 21st Century
description:
India is demonstrating immense potential and capacity to contribute to the global economy, security, and development. It has emerged as one of the world's largest democracies. Its economy is growing. It is also an important regional power in Asia.

However, considerable weaknesses in its state institutions persist, restricting the country's ability to generate inclusive economic growth and political stability. Many state institutions, such as the judiciary, police force, public administration, and diplomatic corps, remain critically understaffed. They struggle to provide public services, and governance weaknesses are hampering them. 

This project will help improve our understanding of how Indian state institutions can function more effectively to support inclusive economic growth and political stability. Researchers will examine capacity gaps in key Indian state institutions. They will propose ways to strengthen human capital and institutional performance. The project team will work closely with Indian think tanks and senior government officials to ensure the findings are relevant.

More specifically, the project will support a three-day author's workshop to:
- bring together researchers to develop a multi-year research framework focusing on India's core state institutions; and,
- support the development of new papers on the capacity of India's state institutions. 

The chapters will be included in an updated and expanded edition of the book, Public Institutions in India: Performance and Design (Oxford University Press).
University of Pennsylvania Institute for the Advanced Study of India
University of Pennsylvania Institute for the Advanced Study of India

title: Publication and Dissemination of Mass Violence Study
description:
This project will help the Centre for Equity Studies in India publish and disseminate the IDRC-supported study, "Accountability for Mass Violence: Examining the State's Record." The goal is to share the research to help generate a public debate on ending impunity for human rights violations.

Researchers pieced together official, but unshared information collected through hundreds of Right to Information applications in India. The result is a public record for four cases of mass violence: 
- 1983 Nellie massacre in Assam; 
- 1984 anti-Sikh riots in New Delhi; 
- 1989 Bhagalpur violence between the Hindus and Muslims; and, 
- 2002 Gujarat violence between the Hindus and Muslims.

The researchers examined this violence on three specific dimensions of state accountability: 
- access to criminal justice;
- accountability of public officials; and, 
- compensation and rehabilitation. 

The public record of these events shines the light on governments, public authorities, and public institutions, allowing researchers to evaluate public officials' accountability and impunity after episodes of mass violence. This comparative study is significant in its use of Right to Information applications in human rights and points to their crucial relevance to contemporary governance debates around the notion of citizens' right to truth and justice. Distributing the report widely will contribute to ongoing discussions on justice and accountability.

title: Publication and Dissemination of Mapping Civil Society Initiatives
Contemporary Political Violence and Ways of Reconciliation
description:
The brutal sexual assault of a young woman on a private bus in New Delhi, followed by her death in December 2012, and the May 2013 Maoist attack on political leaders in Chattisgarh are two recent violent incidents that had serious social implications in India and have generated enormous interest in sections of the population that have until now typically kept away from such debates.

These acts of violence have instigated heated debates on issues ranging from sexual violence to women's rights, judicial and police reforms, juvenile justice, ideologies that glorify violence, non-violent resistance strategies, the displacement of indigenous people, panchayati raj (or self-governing) institutions, and the decentralization of governance. The most visible debates have played out in the electronic media, which tends to portray the issues in "for or against" terms. 

Serious discussions in public spaces and universities in metropolitan cities like New Delhi, which have better resources to plan and host debates, have taken place. However, youth and students from smaller cities such as Patna, Gaya, Lucknow, Allahabad, Jodhpur, and Jaipur have not been exposed to critical debates on these issues. Support from IDRC will enable the Delhi-based AMAN Trust to organize a series of five workshops and seminars in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Rajasthan on the broad theme of how to mitigate and resolve violence through peaceful and constitutional means. The workshops will be interactive and designed to give space to young people to raise doubts and to seek answers.

title: National Conference on Feminist Research on Gender, Poverty, and Development in Honour of Feminist Economist and Activist, Devaki Jain
description:
Devaki Jain has been at the forefront of feminist development research, activism, and advocacy in India for decades. She has been an active member of the women's movement at the local, national, and international levels through women's organizations and networks. She co-founded Development Alternatives for Women for a New Era (DAWN), a developing world network of women social scientists who provided an alternative framework for understanding and advancing the cause of poor women in developing countries. 

Devaki Jain is the founder of the Institute of Social Studies Trust (ISST) in New Delhi and was its director until 1994. This workshop will help mark Devaki Jain's contributions with a tribute to her life and her work. It will also make a substantive contribution to developing a future research agenda for ISST and the wider global research community. This project will provide funding to help organize the workshop. The grant will be used to create a short audio-visual film, and pay for the venue and reception. The event will be held in November 2013.

Devaki Jain's work mirrors the leading areas of feminist economics research in India. Her work on measuring women's work, and its implications for policy, resonates to this day and remains relevant given the continuing struggle to identify and value women's work.

Devaki's work on gender in human development and on macroeconomics, trade, and gender has made a significant contribution to the debates on gender, poverty, and development. Her critical writing on gender and development and her participation in feminist activism and policymaking have shaped gender discussions worldwide.

title: Seminar on Food, Farming, and Farmers
description:
Alarmed by growing patent demands on the developing world's genetic resources, Dr Suman Sahai and a group of concerned Indian citizens founded Gene Campaign in 1993. This grassroots non-governmental organization was also concerned with the impact patent demands were having on the food and livelihood security of marginalized, rural communities. 

Over the past 20 years, Gene Campaign has been recognized as a competent research and advocacy organization working with a diverse range of stakeholders, including the scientific community, civil society, and youth. The organization brings greater awareness to the condition of farmers and farming in India. 

In November 2013, Gene Campaign will mark its 20th anniversary by hosting a seminar to discuss the agriculture crisis and the implications for food and nutrition security in India. Following the recently approved National Food Security Act (2013), the seminar will provide a much needed opportunity for key stakeholders to discuss the sustainability of smallholder farms and farmers in India. Participants will develop a charter for action. The seminar will include a food festival of locally produced products from northern and eastern India. Both regions were hit by floods in 2013. 
This project will provide funding to support the seminar. Its goal is to generate awareness, particularly among urban middle classes, about India's food, farming, and farmers' crisis. Participants will examine what needs to be done to ensure sustainability and collective well-being. More specifically, they will: 
-develop a charter of demands for policy advocacy on agricultural change and reform to ensure adequate food and nutrition security for all;
-galvanize urban youth through a range of media, including music and film, to act on farming and farmer issues in India; and, 
-produce a seminar report and a charter of agriculture policy change demands (this will be shared with the media).

title: Youth Helpline and Resource Centre
description:
Over the space of a generation, the Old City of Hyderabad in India has undergone many changes. Once a thriving hub in the eyes of its inhabitants, it is now reduced to a neglected neighbourhood for which the government does not have a plan or vision. Joblessness, especially among youth, is increasing sharply as the local economy declines. New businesses are not being set up. The industrial estates, established decades ago, have closed. Government offices close regularly and are moving to the new city.

This project will empower disadvantaged urban youth in the Old City of Hyderabad by establishing a youth helpline and resource centre. The non-profit advocacy group, Yugantar, will lead the project. The organization has been working with youth from the Old City and has found that while there is a strong desire among youth and their parents for quality education and employment, there is little information on locally available opportunities. The resource centre and helpline will act as a focal point to help the disadvantaged access basic services, such as scholarships and government support. They will also serve as a knowledge hub for information on education and employment.

Poverty, discrimination are obstacles to youth employment
The challenges are particularly acute for young people. For many with educational certificates, the poor quality of their educational training makes it difficult, if not impossible, for them to get jobs with multinationals or big national firms. A large part of the population of the Old City has the double disadvantage of poverty and religion (many are Muslim). The Sachar Committee Report (2006) pointed out that Indian Muslims are not only lagging behind other socio-religious groups, but they also endure discrimination. This fuels a sense of injustice and alienation from mainstream society.

Hyderabad has a history of communal tensions. This has led to the near-complete ghettoization of many parts of the Old City. Mixed neighbourhoods have forcibly become single community areas often delineated by borders. These changes, combined with fractured families and traditional support structures, create ongoing tensions. They also increase feelings of insecurity, inhibit mobility, disable access to public spaces and institutions, and erode civic trust. There is an urgent need to help Old City youth in their social recovery by building their human, cultural, and social capital. This can best be done by leveraging technology to rebuild social and institutional networks, encouraging dialogue between community and state actors, and overcoming trauma and concerns.

title: Comprehensive Development of Marginal Communities in Delhi: Good Neighbour Project 2013
description:
This project will address homelessness in two areas of New Delhi, by providing outreach services and shelter. The Centre for Equity Studies' (CES) shelter for men in the Yamuna Pushta area and the shelter for single women in the Jama Masjid community will provide psychosocial care and will give vulnerable people access to basic rights and public programs.

The Good Neighbour Project team selected the CES proposal to provide these rehabilitation programs. CES set up a National Resource Team for the Urban Homeless (HAUSLA) as part of its national campaign to address fundamental problems identified by the Supreme Court and the Hashim Committee Report on Urban Poor. 

While the Government of India has introduced schemes to help the homeless, the country lacks an adequate methodology to identify the poor and homeless. This makes it very difficult, and unlikely, that people who depend on public services to survive will access them. In many cases, the vulnerable lack proper government identification, such as birth certificates or ration cards. This problem further excludes them from welfare and development programs.

The project team will identify the homeless in Yamuna Pushta and Jama Masjid. They will provide access to basic services and rights. They also plan to document mental and emotional traumas that homeless people face as a result of long-term suffering-and provide counselling. 

The project funds will also help form a network for advocacy, services, and documentation on public health issues with other NGOs and special care providers working in the streets of Delhi. The network will allow these groups to pool knowledge and document problems. It is likely to result in better coordination between NGOs and between the NGOs and government departments. 

Information gathered through surveys and programs will be presented at a meeting between NGOs, agency representatives, and special care providers. The project will provide long-term benefits to marginalized groups, along with immediate care, relief, and life skills training.

The project's specific objectives include:
-understand, communicate, and target homeless men's and women's problems through a community mobilization program;
-provide trained counsellors to treat, profile, and follow up on cases;
-deliver awareness and access to basic rights sessions to shelter staff; and,
-provide basic and advanced life skills training to homeless men and women.

title: Prevention and Protection of Children from Sexual Violence and Abuse
description:
India is home to the largest child population in the world. Despite the guarantees and rights given to them under the Indian Constitution, including a life of dignity that is free of discrimination, violence, and abuse, many children continue to face threats of sexual, physical, and emotional abuse. This project will address the problem by empowering local communities to create a violence-free environment for their children.

Sexual violence in Indian society
A recent Asian Centre for Human Rights report notes an alarming increase in reported rape cases against children in the decade from 2001 to 2011. National Crime Bureau (NCB) figures also show a similar increase in reported violent crimes against women and children. According to the report, the total crimes against women increased by 7.1% between 2010 and 2011. Rape shows an increase of 9.2%; 30% of these are child rape victims (about 11% under 14, and 19% between the ages of 14 and 18). 

Empowering children and families
This project addresses children's safety and security. It recognizes that there is a real need to make children, communities, and parents aware of the widespread nature of the abuse. It also empowers them with knowledge about their rights and responsibilities in mitigating sexual violence, giving children the childhood they deserve and that is enshrined in the constitution. 

The project will include a series of workshops on children's rights with the children and communities in Gujarat. The workshops will focus on abuse, its types, signs, symptoms, and prevention and protection strategies. The Peace and Equality Cell will co-lead the project with the Human Development and Research Centre of St. Xavier's Non-Formal Education Society. Both have an excellent track record of community-based work on child rights and women's rights in Gujarat. The workshops will equip participants with the knowledge and tools they need to report crimes of sexual violence and to access the support and legal services available to them under the existing legislation for most marginalized children.
[Director] for and on behalf of St. Xavier's Non-Formal Education Society
[Director] for and on behalf of St. Xavier's Non-Formal Education Society

title: Asia Regional Office: Lecture Series 2014-15
description:
IDRC's Asia Regional Office's lecture series has invited eminent scholars, policymakers, grassroots workers, and development researchers to lead seminar discussions since 2001.This grant will support the series through 2014-15.

Regional Office staff will organize a series of public policy dialogues and debates around Asia's major economic, political, and social issues. Events will be held in New Delhi, India, and at other locations in the region.  

The project will cover travel and other expenses for visiting scholars. More specifically, the project's objectives are to:
-provide a forum for IDRC partners to share their research findings, new ideas, and project experience with their peers, Delhi-based donors representatives, academics, policymakers, staff members, and others;
-facilitate and promote efforts to articulate Asia's public policy issues; and
-highlight IDRC's contribution to public policy and social science research through a series of commemorative lectures by influential policy researchers.
