title: Barmer Dist CES EC BJSS
description: This project aims to provide affordable and accessible eye care services to people in the Barmer District. The main activities of this project include:  Establishing four vision centres to make primary eye care services more widely accessible; Providing training for the health workforce at the primary level to extend preventive and referral services in Barmer district; To provide diagnostic services for Diabetic Retinopathy, Glaucoma and Low Vision; Provision of spectacles; Organising outreach camps with the support of tertiary centres; Providing training for teachers in Low Vision screening; Raising awareness at the community level of eye health and the services available

title: JAISALMER district IE SURE
description:
These are district based pilot programmes being implemented in most inaccessible districts of Rajasthan with difficult geographical terrain and recurring drought making the lives of people very challenging. 

The projects aim to ensure that all visually impaired children up to the age of 18 years receive quality education within the wider education system. The project has adopted an approach of strengthening education system at the district level for effective planning, monitoring and implementation of the inclusive education activities. 251 children (165 in Jaisalmer and 86 in Barmer) are being supported for continuous education and inclusion. The projects also demonstrate the effective community mobilisation for improving resources for children and importance of bridge courses in improving level of learning of children through follow-up and inclusion of Information technology.

title: Barmer district   IE SURE
description:

The projects aim to ensure that all visually impaired children up to the age of 18 years receive quality education within the wider education system. title: Jagaran Jan Vikas Mandal trust, Dungarpur
description: The project is focused on strengthening the ophthalmic human resources of the hospital and building convergence with various stakeholders for enhanced service delivery.

title: VAAGDHARA Banswara district CES Project
description:
Social Inclusion project through Comprehensive Eye Services approach. It served the education, rehabilitation and eye health needs of tribal dominated community of the area. 40 visually impaired people were rehabilitated and 17 children with visual impairment were enrolled in the mainstream education setup. 
This is a CBR project implemented on a Comprehensive Eye Services approach. The project has three main components  social inclusion of visually impaired people, education of children with visual impairment and addressing the eye health needs of the community.

The project has facilitated rehabilitation of 112 VI persons and 20 children have been mainstreamed in to the wider education system. 

The project also demonstrated a convergence initiative at the district level. Under this initiative three vision centres were established for which support was raised from a Cement company in the district. The equipment for the centres was supported through the project, and government has agreed to support the human resource for the centres. The project also influenced the district administration in ensuring that all four positions of ophthalmologists are occupied, thereby ensuring required human resources at the district level as well as grassroots level.  

A DPO has been formed at the district level which has started advocating for the rights of disabled people in the area.

title: CUTS-CBR
description:
Social Inclusion project through Comprehensive Eye Services approach. It serves the education, rehabilitation and eye health needs of tribal dominated community of the area. 40 visually impaired people have been rehabilitated and 17 children with visual impairment have been enrolled in the mainstream education setup. 
This is a CBR project implemented on a Comprehensive Eye Services approach. The project has three main components  social inclusion of visually impaired people, education of children with visual impairment and addressing the eye health needs of the community.

title: Sirohi District Social Inclusion
description:
The project focuses on promoting equal opportunities environment for disabled people in the district by integrating social inclusion approach 

In addition to ensuring basic rehabilitation (including social and education) for visually impaired people, the project will strengthen capacities of VI people on accessing and undertaking livelihood initiatives. The project will also develop leaders among disabled people in the district who will take lead in advocating for their members rights. 

So as to develop an enabling environment, the project will sensitise and support wider stakeholders in mainstreaming disability in all their development programmes.

title: South Rajasthan Social Inclusion Project
description:
This is a first of its kind comprehensive approach in social inclusion in the southern division of Rajasthan. This will help prioritise disability within the local environment and also help in replicating good practice in south Rajasthan.

The project focuses on three changes:
1. Disabled Peoples Organisations are formed and are advocating for their rights and entitlements
2. Disabled people have increased access to livelihood options and sensitised community is including disabled people in all initiatives
3. The implementing organisation (Aastha) is sensitised and is an inclusive organisation (with inclusive policies and practices)

title: LVPEI - Retinoblastoma
description: LVPEI - Retinoblastoma

title: Assistive technology - Vision Aid
description:
The project aims to create an atmosphere whereby the Visually Impaired (VI) are provided with training for personal development, career enhancement, bring in a facilitative environment and to train teachers of the VI children so that they are able to provide this training to their students in schools. 

The programme focuses on providing computer skill training to the VIs from Vizag and the neighbouring sub districts. It also supports colleges for setting up satellite training centres where VIs students are enrolled through which VI students are trained in computers. Besides, it trains the teachers and the students pursuing Bachelors of Education (B. Ed) with an aim that these individuals will further use the learn skills while teaching VI students. Also a resource centre has been established under this project which has few computers that can be utilised by the students for practise and also has various devices for persons with blindness and Low Vision. This acts as a centre for creating awareness among the general public and also among those interested in working for people with VI.

title: CBR and DPO/BPO advocacy programme - ORRC at distr
description: Previously on care and maintenance.

title: CBR with TARA at Visakhapatnam district
description:
The project aims to increase the reach of the Visually Impaired (VI) both in terms of access to services as well as by widening the awareness and acceptability within the larger society. It also envisages that people actively seek eye care service and enjoy a change in quality of life through community development programmes. It is implemented in 3 sub districts of Vishakhapatnam district of Andhra Pradesh namely Payakraopeta, S Rayavaram and Nakkapalli. 

The project works with the objectives of establishing a network of Disabled Peoples Organizations (DPOs)/ Blind Peoples Organizations (BPO) in the project area for facilitating appropriate quality services to PWDs and to ensure that the government services, schemes and facilities are accessed by the community and the disabled persons according to the government acts on rights based approach. 

Besides it aims to establish cadre of advocacy agents at each administrative level of the district in order to facilitate service delivery to the Visually Impaired persons. 

It also works on creating awareness on eye health and bring about change in the knowledge, attitude and behaviour among the community in the project area. 

The project also trains VIs in Orientation and Mobility (O&M), Daily Living Skills (DLS) and in income generation activities. The project aims to enable the VIs to lead independent lives and become active members of the society.

title: CBR  JKS for Visakhapatnam district
description: Previously on care and maintenance.

title: Andhra Pradesh Eye Health
description:
The project aims to strengthen health system in the state of Andhra Pradesh and ensure that quality eye care is received by the community at large. 

The purpose of the project is to train ophthalmic human resource working under public health system in the state of Andhra Pradesh for providing quality eye care services to the people. 
The specific objectives of the project are, 
1. To ensure capacity building of 23 ophthalmologists in screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (DR), Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) and Glaucoma, 6 Ophthalmologists in management of DR and ROP and 3 in Glaucoma management  by the end of 2013   
2. To build capacity of 90 paediatricians and 260 gynaecologists for prevention of ROP among premature babies by the end of 2013
3. Ensure capacity building of 9 Paramedical Ophthalmic Officers (PMOOs) in equipment maintenance and , 69 identification and referral of DR and glaucoma patients, 23 PMOOs in management of low vision patients by end of 2013  
4. To ensure enhanced knowledge and capacities of community health workers (CHWs) in primary eye care by end of 2013
5. To ensure enhanced knowledge and capacities of District Programme Managers (DPMs) in Vision 2020 District level planning

title: Advocacy Project at Panchayat Level for Eyes, NAB
description: Advocacy Project at Panchayat Level for Eyes, NAB

title: Intigration of PEC in PHC
description: This project aims to provide primary eye care services integrated in primary health centres. The main objectives of this project are: To strengthen 10 Vision Centres in 10 Primary Health Centres in Karnataka; To provide primary eye care services through integration of primary eye care with primary health care; Providing training for Paramedical Ophthalmic Assistants to provide quality refractive services in the ten vision centres; To advocate with State Health authorities for replication of this concept in 30 Primary Health Cares

title: Comprehensive Pediatrics Eye care project (Partner
description: The aim of this project is to raise awareness and provide eye care services to children in Bangalore. The main objectives of this project are: To provide comprehensive paediatric eye services in the project area; To ensure that all identified irreversibly blind and low vision children receive timely rehabilitation and education services and are made aware of the facilities and benefits available for them; To raise awareness on childhood blindness, eye cancer and to promote community ownership and wider impact of the initiatives; To network and work with other local Non-Government Organisation (NGOs) and eye services providers in the project districts; To provide appropriate assistive vision devices to the children with severe visual impairments
Sri Kanchi Kama Koti Medical Trust, Sankara Eye Hospital, Bangalore

title: Gulbarga Dist Education Programme
description:
This is the district based inclusive education programme initiated at Gulbarga District. The district houses 5% of the states population and is poorly equipped in relation to education of Visually Impaired (VI) children. 

The aim of the programme is to integrate the 225 VI children in that area into inclusive education set up, provide the necessary support services such as learning Braille, Taylor frame, abacus, daily living skills and orientation and mobility and facilitate the regular teachers with classroom management of the VI children. 

The programme simultaneously focuses on building a strong linkage with the Govt. education systems, to ensure that Govt. education system is primarily responsible for the inclusive education needs of the VI children.
National Association for the Blind, Bangalore, Karnataka

title: Mysore District Education (SVYM )
description:
This project focuses on reaching out to the marginalised Visually Impaired (VI) children in the Mysore block of Karnataka. 37 VI children, who were not part of the Govt. inclusive education system, have been integrated into the regular schools.

The project aims to build capacity of human resource of government, non-government agencies and other stakeholders for appropriate planning and implementation of the inclusive education programme.

title: Comprehensive Pediatrics Eye Care Project-Shimoga
description:
The purpose of this project is to prevent blindness, restore sight of children in Central and coastal Karnataka, viz., Shimoga, Uttar Kannada, Haveri, Chikmagalur, Udipi and Davengere districts. 
The specific objectives of the project are, 
1. To provide comprehensive paediatric eye services in the project area to identify and treat visually impaired children.
2. To raise awareness on childhood blindness and to promote community ownership and wider impact of the initiatives. 
3. To network with other local NGOs and eye services providers in the project districts.
Sri Kanchi Kama Koti Medical Trust, Sankara Eye Hospital, Shimoga

title: Life Skills training for VI with Enable India, Ban
description:
This project aims towards personal development and self- integration of the disabled into the mainstream. Its purpose is to create an atmosphere whereby all Visually Impaired (VI) individuals of employable age get opportunities to learn important life skills which will enable them to secure employment in open market resulting in their total inclusion with confidence. 

The Project conducts life skills education training with the VIs and also conducts Training of Trainers for creating a pool of master trainers who may further pass on the skills to the VIs in their work area. 

The project also provides intensive counselling to the trained candidates and conducts sensitization workshops with the potential employers in order to ensure smooth transition of the candidates in their work place. 

The objectives of the project are 
 To integrate life skills training as an important part of the holistic development of a person with disability. 
 To ensure that the trainers of the VI are equipped with necessary skills to handle their real lives issues and train them with adequate skills.

title: Disable girl employemnt (NAB)
description: This project aims to provide skill based training with emphasis on Computer, English and Personality development to the identified visually impaired girls from Karnataka and link them to the available jobs at the end of the course period. It is also envisaged that some girls after completing the course will enrol themselves for higher education in turn giving them better job opportunities. The main project activities include: Providing training sessions for low vision, visually impaired and sighted girl on employability skills; Providing training for volunteer resource persons
National Association for the Blind, Bangalore Karnataka

title: DR Dharward Project
description:
This project aims to improve the health seeking behaviour of general population in Dharwad on Diabetic Retinopathy (DR). The projects main activities include:

To develop network and linkages in Dharwad for accessible DR services.

To develop self- sustainable business model for DR.

Increase awareness among the general population of Dharwad on Diabetes and DR through technology                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The goal of this project is to contribute towards the elimination of avoidable blindness among the population of 100,000 in Dharwad District

title: Project Access (XRCVC)
description: The project aims at 4 major objectives, namely, bringing about amendment to Indian Copyright Act, 1957; To bring about financial access to the visually impaired in particular and disabled in general; to open up various mainstream educational courses that are hitherto unavailable to visually impaired students and to facilitate independent living by advocating for creation of enabling environment in areas like transport, infrastructure access, etc.  Both the above projects are well on their objectives.
Xaviers Resource Centre for Visually Challenged, Mumbai, India

title: Mumbai Eye Care Campaign Project
description: This comprehensive eye care project aims to provide affordable and accessible eye care services. The main activities of this project are: Establish 15 vision centres in the slums of Mumbai to provide Primary eye care services to the people living in slums; Raising awareness among the slum population about the importance of eye health; Educating prospective employers about the employability of the blind; Advocating for the rights of the blind; Providing training for eye health workers; Providing eye care services to the 'floating population' through the mobilisation van; Conducting sensitization and education workshops and mega workshops to reach out to the larger community; Networking with Government and NGO's to encourage their involvement
Khan Bahadur Haji Bachooali Charitable Ophthalmic and ENT Hospital (KBHB)

title: Education project for Amravati district, National
description: The programme focuses on a district based approach. The district based inclusive education programme at Amravati reaches out to 7 blocks of the 14 blocks of the district. The project aims to provide educational services to 71 visually impaired children including teaching plus curriculum according to their age and need. The project focuses on capacity building, networking with stakeholders and building strong linkages with Govt. education systems. The project is currently filling in the gaps of the Govt. inclusive education systems for the VI children in this district.

title: South India low vision HRD programme
description: The project aims to stabilise and strengthen low vision primary and secondary centres in 30 colleges of Optometry. The main objectives of this project are: Developing human resources by capacity building of Optometric educators and rehabilitation specialists on Low Vision; Incorporating Low Vision as the part of the curriculum in optometry colleges; Initiate low vision and refractive error policy development process at country level

title: Eye Care For Truckers Pilot Project
description: This Pilot Project aims at targeting the nomadic population of truckers. The main project objectives are: To raise awareness of eye care in the community; To increase the awareness amongst truckers about eye health; To establish two vision centres in the target area for the truckers community; Screening and treating truckers; Provision of spectacles

title: Niligiri District Social Inclusion
description: This project is designed to improve the quality of life of Persons with Disabilities (PWDs). The main activities of this project are:  Facilitating the development of a cadre of Advocacy agents promoting eye care and the rights of the Persons with Disabilities; Facilitating the process of making Government offices accessible; Strengthening the DPOs/ BPOs and developing them in to independent entities; Establishing a training and resource centre for the Persons with Disabilities; Providing training in Orientation, Mobility and Daily Living Skills for Persons with Disabilities; Conducting eye screening camps, with a special focus on reaching Persons with Disabilities
Centre for Tribal and Rural Development (CTRD) Trust

title: South Inida Livelihood for PWDs
description:
The goal of this project is to contribute to the socio-economic empowerment of persons with disabilities (PWDs) through employment and a comprehensive development of organization of PWDs in Tamil Nadu. 
The objectives of the project are,
1. To facilitate the employment for PWDs after imparting skill based trainings and linking them to the industries and offices functional within the project districts.
2. To strengthen five District Nodal Agencies (DNAs) by building leadership qualities so that they can work towards their welfare and development. 
3. To empower the youth in the educational institutions  in Tamil Nadu to become socially responsible citizens with committed approaches for the welfare and development of the PWDs.

title: Inclusive Education for the States of Tamilnadu
description:
The aim of this Inclusive Education Project is to provide quality education for disabled children in Tamil Nadu.
The main activities of this Inclusive education project are:
 To provide eye screening for children enrolled in government schools among the seven districts (Villupuram, Salem, Nilgiris, Namakkal, Theni, Ramnathpuram and Madurai).
 Provide appropriate treatment for children that are identified as being visually impaired
 Providing training for Inclusive education teachers
 Providing teachers with training on undertaking refractive screening
This Inclusive education project is being implemented with a purpose to ensure that the government of Tamil Nadu provides quality education services with support services within the wider education system for Visually Impaired children by strengthening the Inclusive Education model by 2015

title: Cataract Surgeries
description: Cataract surgeries performed by partner organisation

title: Democratising citizens debate on safer food and the environment
description:
In the next four years DDS aims at democratizing the debate on the GE crops/ foods by involving various stakeholders such as farmers, opinion leaders in the villages, panchayat leaders, students, consumers, legal experts and media so that they are in a better position to challenge the introduction of GE in South India. To achieve the objectives, DDS plans to exert its influence on the following areas:
a. Improving the understanding on Genetic Engineering (GE) among farmers, consumers, policy makers, academicians and civil society actors enhanced. This is expected to lead to rejection of GE consistently by at least 30% farmers among the focus groups by 2012.
b. Increased resistance by farmers, local bodies and consumers to GE. This would be reflected by at least 100 panchayats passing resolutions against GE, at least 500 farmers' clubs and SHGs ban the use of GE seeds by its members; legal actions would be initiated against GE seed companies in all south Indian states; media would allocate more time for GE debates
c. Policy support for greater regulation on GE and for ecological food and farming would be enhanced. This would be reflected by demands for stricter clauses from GEAC by state governments, existing regulatory clauses would be strictly enforced; policy in support of organic agriculture in all south Indian states would be announced.
d. Ecological options for food and farming would be further explored and promoted. This would lead to the emergence of 5000 organic farming groups under participatory guarantee systems by 2012; organic seeds farmers groups with 10,000 members are formed; increase in organic food outlets from 10 to 30 by 2012.

DDS' campaign objectives, its concerns regarding the threats faced by small and marginal farmers, and the issues that it raises regarding bio safety, are all very much in line with Hivos' own overall policy objectives, and particularly with its policy on sustainable production. The emphasis on working with majority of dalit women as its primary beneficiaries is also in line with the priorities of the sector.

title: Strengthening Minor Forest Produce-based livelihoods of tribal women in south Rajasthan
description:
In this phase SS will continue to strengthen institutions of MFP collectors with a view to sustain their livelihood base. The purpose of this project is to enhance access and control over livelihood resources of forest dependent communities in 5 districts and 10 blocks of Southern Rajasthan by 2013.

The activities would primarily seek to strengthen the existing cooperatives them at the state level, build their capacities for collecting, processing and marketing of 5 forest products. Samarthak Samiti and its members would also intensify their lobby with the government, on one hand to ensure that the community members have rights over the forest resources and also ensure that forest department takes measures for conservation of the resource base.

By the end of this phase SS would have promoted and strengthened 9 cooperatives with 70% of its members as women and 30% of the women would be in leadership positions. SS will reach out to 1600 marginalized families directly out of who 1000 are women, and 3000 families indirectly in approximately 70 villages of 10 blocks extending over 5 districts of Southern Rajasthan. Also one centralized processing centre would have been set up catering to the 9 cooperatives. Other activities include training, exposure visits, production of IEC materials, linkages with traders and forest department, propagation of saplings, providing business development services, networking and organizing pressure groups.

Its advocacy efforts would specifically address issues related to the forest dependent communities in the Forest Act, Panchayati Raj Extension in Scheduled areas (PESA) act, Tribal Self Rule (TSR), transit permit, tendering process and it would also sensitise the panchayat members related to these issues.

It is expected that by the end of the phase SS would have established 9 vibrant cooperatives with strong membership and leadership of women that would be functioning autonomously. The empowerment process should also enable the cooperatives to strengthen their bargaining power with various arms of the state and also participate in the local markets from a position of strength.
SS' goals and strategies to strengthen the MFP based livelihoods of tribal women are in congruence with HIVOS' policy on sustainable production.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Improving the food and nutrition security of farm families in rainfed areas of Jharkhand
description:
Gene Campaign, has on the basis of its experience of working in Jharkhand and after discussions with its stakeholders, decided on the primary objectrive of piloting community-based production of high quality seed. This it feels will help local farmers cope with the acute shortage of seeds and Gene Campaign hopes that this model will prove successful for upscaling by the state. It envisages that seed producing farmers groups will be organised into seed producing cooperatives leading up to the establishment of a Producer Group Company in the long-term. The other objectives of the project are the provision of weather advisories to farmers, conservation of crop genetic biodiversity by setting up an additonal two community gene seed banks, making crop production sustainable and high yielding via field research on System of Rice Intensification [SRI] and improving local soil health, and lobby and advocacy for as part of the Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture network.

Some of the expected results are:
- 600 farm families from 55 villages take part in seed production
- 550 metric tonnes of disease-resistant rice seed and 160 metric tonnes of aromatic rice seed produced by the third year of the project
- 70 metric tonnes of horse gram produced by the third year of the project
- Scientific data gathered on the performance of SRI under different field conditions
- Improvements in soil health in working area
- Evidence of gradual shift in subsidies for bio-organic cultivation, especially in rain-fed areas
- Increase in the government's policy focus on decentralised seed production.

Gene Campaign's objectives and plans as part of this project fit well with the policy priorities regarding sustainable agriculture of both Hivos and the Ford Foundation, with whom the Hivos Regional Office has established the Ford Foundation-Hivos Fund for Sustainable Rainfed Agriculture. Hence, Gene Campaign will be supported via the joint fund.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Just Governance through Gram Swaraj in rural Orissa
description:
01-11-2010 - 31-03-2014

In this phase OPDSC in collaboration with OGSAS will work in 120 villages in Orissa covering a population of 600,000 people. The focus will be on ensuring active and informed participation of tribals, dalits, women and other marginalised groups in local governance structures using the strategies of community mobilization, capacity building of all the stake-holders, research, and alliance building with civil society organizations, etc. Working in a phased manner (30 villages annually) OGSAS and OPDSC will work towards the following objectives a) To ensure that marginalized people have greater access to political, social and economic opportunities in the process of development at state and local level. b) Strengthen grass root governance institutions like Palli Sabhas (PS) village governance institution in non-tribal areas and Gram Sabhas (GS) village governance institutions in tribal areas, to address social and economic issues c) To create a space where people have equitable access to health, access to knowledge, skills, technology and information so as to live with dignity as human beings d) facilitate active involvement of citizens (increased women's participation) to ensure effective and functional PRIs e) Strengthen the capacity of staff, local activists and partner/constituents of OGSAS. OPDSC and OGSAS willl strive to build a state level movement for just governance through strengthening the active participation of community members in local governance bodies. At the end of the four year period some of the key results envisaged by OPDSC and OGSAS are: a) increase (by 30%) of women, tribals and dalits participating and contesting in PRI and other local elections b) (90%) all eligible people access benefits of various social welfare schemes viz. National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (NREGS), National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), Right To Education (RTE), Public Distribution System (PDS), old age pension and housing leading to a reduction in distress migration c) 120 PS and GS develop their own annual development plans and these are ratified by the PRIs, d) (50% of) PS and GS conduct social audits of various programmes in their villages e) increase in quality and completion (by 75%) of all development works in the village f) (by 50%) increase in women voters attendance in all PRI meetings g. (50%) increase in women's representation in various for decision making bodies at the village level.
OPDSC and OGSAS's focus is on collectivisation and alliance building amongst civil society actors, activists and the community members. The planned interventions and strategies of strengthening community participation in local governance structures, social mobilization, alliance building and advocacy to build a large-scale movement for just governance fits well within Hivos policy on Human Rights and Democratization and the proposed Rights and Citizenship Programme.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Project 1: Establishing the Institute of Pluralism in Gujarat; Project 2: Mobilising women in Maliya Block, Rajkot District
description:
Safar will continue to work on different levels of grassroots mobilization, networking for advocacy, capacity development and legal assistance. In addition Safar will be the secretariat for the Institute for Pluralism in Gujurat. 
 
For the work in Maliya Block, Safar in particular will:
-	Conduct ten leadership trainings for 30 Mahila Nyay & Shanti Panch members in Maliya
-	Organise at least 30 workshops and engage with at least 900 women from Maliya (OBC, DNT, SC/ST, Muslims) building their legal, social right awareness levels from a feminist perspective
-	Extend counseling, Legal, Medical and other crisis related support in particular for Violence against Women cases in Maliya 
-	Campaign, advocate and network to promote concepts of justice and peace and to promote awareness on the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act
-	Publicize publications/material related to gender and legal rights 

The expected outcomes envisaged are: 
-	Increased confidence of community members in Maliya to understand dynamics of power and patriarchy, discuss cases of violence against women, seek legal redressal thereby providing a platform for women in distress

For the work on the IPL, Safar in particular will:

-	Organise five training programmes for 150 Grassroot Practitioners & students for a period of nine days each.
-	Organise three Training of Trainers programmes with 90 Grassroot Practitioners for seven days each.
-	Create of a rich resource centre with more than 150 books, magazines, newspapers, films, audio CDs, posters, pamphlets, etc.
-	Organise 12 talk shows, lectures, film shows in colleges and with local youth groups.
-	Organise at least 36 cultural events- street plays, debates, etc in colleges and with local communities within the area of member organizations.

The expected outcomes envisaged are: 

-	Creation of a pool of 90 trainers on plural values.
-	Creation of a cadre of more than 500 persons on the issue of Pluralism.
-	Provision of a platform for interaction between various movements in whose interest it is to promote pluralism.
-	A framework for grassroot practioners and youth to bring about the incipient but latent conflicts in their thinking process against any form of fundamentalism and lead them to question the existing systems.
-	Grassroot practioners are empowered with tools and innovative strategies to promote the concept of diversity and pluralism. 
-	Development and dissemination of methodological tools for analysis and introspection on the issue of pluralism.

title: Democratising Law: Alternative Lawyering and Human Rights

title: Enhancing Adivasi rights in Andhra Pradesh
description:
In the next three years of support from UUHHJIF, Yakshi will mainly focus on capacity building of tribal activists representing various CBOs, and in cooperation with the tribal activists, work on its objectives. It aims to do so via its youth leadership development programme with 30 activists belonging to the 12 CBOs which constitute the tribal alliance – Adivasi Aikya Vedika. Of these, annual fellowships will be provided to 12 senior fellows and 12 junior fellows. Youth leadership trainings will be held across the year. Yakshi will also organise women leaders’ exchange visits for 320 women leaders in as many villages. With regard to networking and alliance building, Yakshi will facilitate the continued growth of the Adivasi Aikya Vedika. The tribal activists, women leaders and the network CBOs of Adivasi Aikya Vedika, with facilitation support, are well placed to involve themselves in and  to work on Yakshi’s overall objectives: to strengthen and democratise the role of the Gram Sabha [the villag-level local self governance set-up]; strengthening peoples resilience to sustain traditional forms of agriculture; leadership development for sustainability of tribal initiatives; and alliance and networking between tribals, Gram Sabhas, tribal organisations and activists. 

Some of the expected results/indicators for monitoring progress are: 
-	Improved capacity of 320 village Gram Sabhas across 9 districts to function effectively with community participation to make independent decisions on issues of land, biodiversity and development interventions and approve development and budget plans of the Panchayat
-	Increased participation of women in the Gram Sabhas; addressal of women’s issues in the Gram Sabha
-	Progress made on 320 community claims and 41128 individuals to forest resources [using FRA] 
-	Increased knowledge and effective monitoring of government policies, schemes and development programme
-	women take the lead in promotion of sustainable agriculture and management of resources in 320 villages [total no. of women involved in the promotion of sustainable agriculture] 
-	Increased household food security from traditional and local sources; increase in the livestock and poultry assets of families [with specific, measurable data]. 
-	Maps of community forest resources will be used as tools for conservation and management of resources. 
-	30 activists [both men and women] from 12 adivasi organisations trained
-	Improved leadership of the adivasi organisations. 
-	Enhanced role of Adivasi Aikya Vedika as a tribal peoples forum at the state, national and international level
-	Improved coordination and networking between the 12 tribal CBOs; addition of newer CBOs to the fold of Adivasi Aikya Vedika
-	Increase in the no. of women members in each of the tribal peoples CBOs [women are primary members]

Yakshi is a key partner of UUHHJIF and will make contributions to Result Area 1 of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme – Excluded and marginalised citizens citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Promoting Inclusive Finance through the Microfinance sector in India
description:
The focus of the previous phase of support has been on developing human resources in the sector, which Sa Dhan has well catered to. With the changing priorities of the sector, the focus of support for 2011-2014 will be on the following:
A.	Policy interventions towards inclusive financial services
- Consultations with various stakeholders on the Micro-finance bill; Regular meetings of the Task Forces set up by Sa-Dhan; State-level conference; Strengthen Odisha and West Bengal State Chapters 
B.	Promote Ethical practices, Transparency and Social performance
- Organize a workshop to raise awareness on the importance of code of conduct; Publish the code in local languages; Train MFIs on the content and implementation of consumer protection principles, Code of Conduct and Social Performance Management (SPM); Data collection, analysis and validation on code compliance and SPM by MFIs; Annual report on publication on the Code and SPM compliance; Regular Grievance and Redressal committee meetings; Regular information sharing on the code and SPM.
C.	Promotion of Micro-enterprise and Livelihood financing
- Develop appropriate micro-enterprise loan products in ten clusters; Develop client assessment tool; Conduct four regional multi-stakeholder workshops on micro-enterprise financing; Consult and collaborate with selected institutions working on micro-enterprise promotion; Section on micro-enterprise in Sa-Dhan’s website; Section on micro-enterprises in Sa-Dhan’s monthly news magazine 

Outcome
A.	Government of India and Regulatory bodies recognize the importance of a national level regulation for micro-finance in India
B.	Sa-Dhan member MFIs follow the code and implement the consumer protection principles
C.	Enhanced credit flow to livelihoods and microenterprises by MFIs
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

description:
The thrust of DISHA’s work in the three-year project is to engage in mobilisation and collectivisation of tribals for lobby/advocacy and monitoring towards making government institutions more accountable, specifically  with regard to forest land entitlements, job guarantees, and the rights and entitlements of unorganised sector workers. DISHA will also continue to build and strengthen its partner people’s organisations [the tribal organisation Eklavya Sangathan and 69 CBOS, including the Atarsumba Women’s CBO] and trade unions [Agricultural Labourers Union, Forest Workers Union, Construction Workers Union, Mine Workers Union, NREGA Workers Union and the all-women Tendu Leaf Pluckers Union] by providing technical assistance, financial support, legal aid, capacity building support and infrastructure. 
DISHA’s planned activities for the project are: campaigns and social mobilisation for effective implementation of laws and policies; monitoring meetings to track progress, capacity building training programmes for executive members of trade unions and staff; legal support; providing honorariums to 7 community workers; advocacy and lobby with government institutions; research and documentation; and organising bi-annual executive committee meetings of the 6 trade unions. DISHA is expected to have a direct outreach of approximately 84,000 individuals, all of whom are members of its partner people’s organisations and trade unions. 
The envisaged outputs and linked indicators for DISHA’s activities are: 

Objective 1: Promotion of Forest Land rights and entitlements
657 community claims for forest land submitted; 10,000 farmers receive forest land record books each year; increase in the number of individual claims accepted each year; number of cases filed for denial for forest land rights and number of cases redressed successfully; number of women with joint-ownership of granted land titles; 90% of eligible scheduled tribe families have applied for forest land. 

Objective 2: Job guarantee under NREGA
At least 1,800 households receive 100 days’ employment from NREGA and 4,500 households receive NREGA job cards each year; number of women receiving 100 days’ employment each year; increase in the number of households receiving 100 days’ employment and job cards every year; follow-up made against violation of NREGA provisions; supervision and monitoring of work sites by mandal members; functional operational structure of the NREGA Workers Union at the taluk-level. 

Objective 3: Access to rights and entitlements by unorganised workers
Effective mobilisation by the 6 trade unions, Eklavya Sangathan, the Atarsumba Women’s CBO, and the Land Rights Protection Committee to advance the rights of unorganised workers; follow-up made on violations of legal provisions for and/or exploitation of unorganised workers; number of women and men receiving the revised minimum wage for agricultural labourers each year; institutional development and increase in membership of the trade unions, Eklavya Sangathan and the Atarsumba Women’s CBO. 

DISHA is a key partner of UUHHJIF and will make contributions to Result Area 1 and 3 of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Program -   excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship; llegislation and policy meet international standards and are implemented in a manner that benefits all citizens and reduces existing inequalities.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Building farmers' institutions in Andhra Pradesh for sustaining farming livelihoods
description:
The primary focus of this phase (2011-15) would be on the following broad objectives - Establishing integrated farming system models which are ecologically and economically sustainable; Building farmers' cooperatives which improve farmers' access to markets; Building capacities of farmers, agricultural workers and civil society workers for promotion of sustainable agriculture; Lobbying and campaigning for a better and supportive policy environment for sustainable agriculture. The main beneficiaries are small and marginal farmers, of which majority are backward communities, dalits, schedule tribes and particularly resource poor and women farmers. CSA (and its partner organizations) is expected to reach out to 5,000 farmers directly through farmers cooperatives. Most of these (except 5 villages) have been covered under the previous phase under NPM, now the emphasis is on adopting organic practices in addition to NPM, and linking them with markets. The analytical approach to be adopted for the next phase would be on a ‘value chain approach’, i.e., developing backward and forward linkages to the sustainable production systems. 

In the last phase, CSA partnered with nine organizations to demonstrate alternatives at the ground level and to organize farmers into cooperatives. In the present phase, consolidation of previous efforts would be concentrated in three locations (two districts each) in the state of Andhra Pradesh.  Three of CSA's partners – CROPS (Jangaon, Warangal district), PEACE (Bhongir, Nalgonda dist), REDS (Ananthpur dist) will continue and in Kurnool, Vijayanagaram and Vishakapatnam districts CSA will directly work with community-based organizations. The other four cooperatives established during the last phase continue to be in the Federation and technical support would be extended to them. In this phase, the focus will be on building a federation of these cooperatives and on mobilizing resources from government programs and banks. The project outcomes/effects are envisaged as follows -  farmers move into local-resource-based sustainable agriculture; productivity is increased because quality seed is available in a timely way at field level through community seed banks (10 crops per seed bank); farmers' incomes increase due to adoption of ecological practices, crop diversification and horticulture; food and nutritional security enhanced; community and state-level institutions are formed for improving marketing and policy advocacy; pro-farmer, pro-sustainable agriculture government policies are made. 

The various activities planned are necessary to achieve the results of an ecologically sound, socially relevant and economically promising agriculture.  Sustainable agriculture provides an alternative to chemical farming and also empowers the farmers to use their practice-based knowledge for advocacy work and network building for greater impact. These outcomes are congruent with the objectives of Hivos' Green Entrepreneurship programme.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Rural women's entrepreneurship to enhance access to energy
description:
With the objective of providing sustainable livelihoods and incomes to women belonging to SHGs and helping them to secure allied job opportunities in services and other sectors, SSP founded Sakhi Retail as a revenue model. The primary goal of Sakhi Retail is to create and scale-up outreach through distribution networks led by grassroots women while building the rural entrepreneurship ecosystem. As of now, Sakhi Retail is operational in Solapur and Osmanabad district of Maharashtra, selling a range of Renewable Energy,agriculture, and health and environment friendly products. 

In the current project, SSP aims to create “Clean and Green Aware Communities” through developing a network of technology providers and a women-led distribution chain which will design and implement effective communication strategies on renewable energy. 

The project focuses on identifying village-level women entrepreneurs (Sakhis) and developing their business and marketing skills in order to educate and assist rural communities to gain access to low-cost energy products. The project will also assist SSP and Sakhi retail to act as product incubator for innovative solutions in biofuel and solar energy sectors using previous experience of co-development of products and grassroots business models, such as smokeless cookstove and low-energy mini fridge. 

The project is expected to benefit the lives of 29,000+ rural households by supplying quality and affordable renewable energy products through an established network of 250 Sakhis in Latur and Beed districts of Maharashtra.The number of households and Sakhis is expected to rise based on the result of awareness created. In addition, SSP will document and share the process, strategies and results as project learning. 

The project's overall objective of assisting rural communities to gain access to clean and low cost energy products through women-led distribution networks fits well into the result area-2 of Hivos' Green Entrepreneurship(GE) programme.  Consequently,supporting the innovation will be Hivos' first step towards expanding its engagement with renewable energy initiatives in India under the GE programme.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: The Holistic and Enterprising Livelihoods Programme [HELP] for tribal areas in Orissa and Jharkhand
description:
In this three-year (2011-14) phase, DF would be largely working in tribal areas to strengthen people's institutions promoted during the last phase and will evolve a model for integration of microfinance with livelihoods. DF will continue to work in five tribal locations of Mayurbhanj district of Orissa and Latehar district of Jharkhand.  In addition, DF will engage in green entrepreneurship activities in specified locations in Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. The main activities are - Organising tribal women into SHGs (with bank linkage) and forming federations (Saturating Locations, Development of SHGs, Capacity Building of SHG Members and Leaders, Cluster Promotion and Federation Promotion and Development); promoting green entrepreneurship (promoting activity-based livelihoods viz., red gram procurement, value addition and marketing, soya bean collective marketing, cashew nut processing and marketing, promoting urban agriculture); agricultural development programme in tribal areas (focused on kharif rice stabilisation to ensure year-round food security through improved cultivation practices along with promotion of critical irrigation support like SRI); inland fisheries programme in Tribal locations; institutional developmental processes of DF (Consultative Forum Meetings, annual retreats and organising state-level workshops and seminars) and policy advocacy for tribal welfare.

The expected outcomes by the end of project period are: 
a) Emergence of community-owned and managed SHGs (with bank linkages) and related network institutions such as cluster development associations and federations in tribal areas of Mayurbhanj district, Orissa and Latehar district, Jharkhand. 
b) 15,000 tribal women are organised into 1,100 SHGs and these SHGs have graduated into 40 cluster development associations in 5 federations.
c) A model for integrating SHGs and activity-based green entrepreneurship interventions is evolved and the livelihoods status of SHG members is enhanced.
d) 3,000 households in rural, coastal and urban locations benefit from the promotion of agriculture-based livelihood interventions. 
e) Productivity and income from agriculture is enhanced for 500 tribal families by upgrading their skills and building linkages through agricultural interventions in two project locations. 
f) The supplementary income of 1000 tribal families is increased by promoting freshwater fish rearing (30 new ponds and 20 existing ponds).
g) The institutional developmental processes of DHAN Foundation are strengthened and policy advocacy efforts for tribal welfare are undertaken.

In total, 20,000 households will be reached during the project period. Most of these households belong to the very poor and are located in remote tribal areas where financial inclusion is minimal. Hence, DHAN Foundation's model of microfinance coupled with livelihood development is imperative for community development in the context, and hence the project qualifies strongly for Hivos' support.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Improving the lives of women in the informal sector in Madhya Pradesh
description:
In the next three years of support from UUHHJIF, MSSN will ensure that it has deepened its capacity to service the needs of its membership, as well put in place systems, plans and processes to ensure institutional sustainability. 

Some of the expected results are: 
-Membership of the Union increased from 4,00,000 to 5,00,000 women from the informal sector in Madhya Pradesh. This will include organising 90,000 forest workers, 1,50,000 construction workers, 90,000 home-based workers, 60,000 domestic workers, 70,000 agricultural workers, 40,000 hawkers and street vendors.
-Policy advocacy linkages with the government are strengthened by ensuring representation of MSSN members in various committees of the government for implementation of existing laws and preparation of new laws in favour of informal sector workers. 
-Increased organisational and financial sustainability of both the Union as well as the Credit Co-operatives
-Awareness levels of workers on specific schemes related to their occupation is increased and  income opportunities of members are enhanced.

MSSN is a key partner of UUHHJIF and will make contributions to Result Area 1 of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme – Excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening the credit plus initiatives of a grassroots Microfinance institution in Rajasthan
description:
In the past years, JCS achieved notable success in strengthening microfinance activities in rural areas of south Rajasthan by forming a tribal savings and credit co-operative society (ABESSSL), and expanding its outreach and portfolio. Subsequently, in light of challenges faced by the rural community, JCS has endeavored to improve livelihood systems. Improvement in crop cultivation techniques, forest-based livelihood interventions and livestock development to further diversify livelihood options are urgently needed to improve the economic status of the community. Rapid agricultural growth complemented by non-farm sector initiatives in rain-fed and semi-arid areas hold the key to poverty reduction.

During 2011-2013, JCS will provide institutional development support to ABESSSL in order to improve its credit plus services and its ability to provide entrepreneurship skill development training to its clients. Institutional development support comprises of systems and process development including audit, HR and Monitoring & Evaluation, capacity building of staff, designing credit products and financial policy, computerization of MIS and streamlining  operation and delinquency management to make the organization self reliant.

In association with National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) and Rajasthan Mission on Skill and Livelihoods (RMOL), JCS will provide entrepreneurship skill development encompassing training on turmeric production, dairy, goat rearing, NTFP collection / process / marketing, petty shops, cycle repair and other opportunities.

The project is expected to improve the livelihood of 10,000 poor tribal households through providing financial and livelihood assistance and social security benefits by the end of two years in Sirohi district of South Rajasthan. Capacity building of grassroots organizations such that they can contribute to financial inclusion is a key aspect of Hivos’ Green Entrepreneurship programme. Hence, the project fits well into the framework of Hivos’ Green Entrepreneurship programme.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Negotiating Privatisation, Medicalisation and Technologies: Advocacy on Gender and Health Rights
description:
HIVOS’s support to SAMA is to continue to strengthen advocacy, monitoring and policy reform on various health related issues with a focus on sexual and reproductive rights of women. In the next two years Sama will undertake- 
•	Two workshops on health care rights with 60 participants from Dalit and disability communities.
•	Exposure visit for 12 activists to Chittorgarh, Rajasthan to understand the model on access to free drugs.
•	Three workshops with 30 community activists on the issues of maternal health care, need for strengthening regulation of the private sector and ethical issues in clinical trials.
•	Dissemination of posters, pamphlets, reports and contribution to newspapers and journals to mobilize public opinion for regulation of the private sector and on unethical clinical trials.
•	Press conference with at least 20 media representatives on the issues of clinical trials and surrogacy.
•	Workshop with 30 members from LGBT and disability communities on the issues related to surrogacy.
•	Meeting with 20 media representatives on issues of surrogacy and the draft ART Bill.
By 2013, it is anticipated that Sama would have contributed to the following:.
•	Knowledge and skills on health rights and programmes of approximately 30 community-based organizations and networks that are working with marginalized communities developed and strengthened.  
•	Initiation of approximately ten policy advocacy initiatives on access to free drugs, based on the successful Rajasthan model.   
•	Engagement of 30 community-based groups and activists in evidence-based advocacy on maternal health care.
•	Enhanced abilities of about 30 community-based organizations to engage in advocacy with regard to free treatment, regulation and service provision in the private health sector. 
•	Evidence base for advocacy regarding regulation of the private health sector is consolidated and disseminated. 
•	Capacities of 30 LGBTQ and disability rights groups and activists developed on the issues related to sexuality and disability within ARTs and surrogacy
•	Media representatives sensitized to a feminist health analysis of the issues in surrogacy and clinical trials.
•	Policy brief on the draft ART Bill 2010 to inform policy makers and parliamentarians. 
•	Facilitation of mobilisation of civil society organizations and networks to advocate for effective regulation of clinical trials.
Sama’s planned interventions will influence the equitability of health policies and programmes and strengthen community monitoring for a more comprehensive and inclusive health system. The Rights and Citizenship programme in Hivos continues to support Sama for its demonstrated ability to engage effectively with different stakeholders within the health system to protect the sexual and reproductive rights of women.
Sama- Resource Group for Women and Health
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Increasing farmer incomes through value addition in Anantapur and Adilabad Districts, Andhra Pradesh
description:
During 2011-13, SMS will work towards the following goals: a. promotion of cooperatives; b. training and capacity building of the farmers and cooperatives; c. promotion of marketing activities; d. improvement in agricultural yields using sustainable agricultural practices. 6100 farmers will be reached in largely interior villages of Anantapur and Adilabad districts of Andhra Pradesh.

The main objectives to be achieved are to create well-run cooperatives that substantially raise farmer incomes, allow them to save, improve yields, bring in better farm practices, move up the value chain in marketing. The goal is financial independence of small farmer families along with adoption of more sustainable farming practices. SMS' philosophy is to enable cooperatives to eventually manage their own business operations.  SMS intends to create a model that is substantial in scale, can replicated, and can influence policy. The increase in farmers' incomes will be achieved mainly through setting up of processing units - for groundnuts in Anantapur and cotton in Adilabad.  SMS plans to help farmers to move up the value chain where possible. 

SMS will establish cooperatives, enable them to engage sustainable agriculture, improve yield and scale them up.  SMS will set up systems that will enable them to market their produce. SMS will also extend business development support. SMS will continuously study the markets for the three commodities it works with - soyabean, groundnut (or peanut) and pulses (toor dal). In addition, SMS will tie up with various financial institutions for working capital on behalf of the cooperatives. SMS will also raises investments for the processing units, two of which have already been set up. SMS will also help farmer organization federations to negotiate and enter into agreements for input purchases. 
 
SMS' enterprise development model through farmers' cooperatives and adoption of sustainable agricultural practices is congruent with Hivos' Green Entrepreneurship programme.
Center for Collective Development / SAHAKARA MITRA SOCIETY
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Institutionalising community organisations in Karnataka working for financial inclusion
description:
IDF has developed a unique four-tier structure for organising small producers.  The foundation of the structure is village-level Self-Help Groups (SHGs).  The subsequent tiers are at the cluster level, village panchayat (unit of self-government), and district levels.  The district-level apex community-based organisations (CBOs) have been registered as mutually aided societies. Eight such apex CBOs have a membership of 0.2 million poor households across 11 districts of Karnataka. 

Between 2011-2014, IDF will work to strengthen these CBOs of the poor community through various institutional development processes so that they become autonomous, self sustaining, and self propagating and are able to help the poor come out of poverty through various services facilitated by Civil Society Organisations. The CBOs are also expected to contribute to the robustness of grassroots democracy and the effectiveness of governmental, bank and corporate, civil society organisations. 

The primary objective is institutional development of the present and evolving CBOs promoted by IDF.  It is expected that there will be an improvement in self-governance and in local leadership.  One of the consequences of such strengthening would be promotion of self-help and entrepreneurial culture among the poor and enhancement of financial inclusion and generation of sustainable livelihoods.  It is expected that standard process documents and communication tools for replication of institutional development of CBOs would also be produced.

By 2014, it is anticipated that  the CBOs would have achieved at all levels (a) Well-developed shared vision and core competencies of the governance team; (b) Sound financial and accounting systems; (c) Well-developed skills in mobilizing financial resources, and ability ot seize livelihood opportunities and link with policy makers and markets; (d) Knowledge regarding CBO institution building in terms of best practices and process documentation.

IDF's objectives and approach are in line with the Green Entrepreneurship program of Hivos.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Building strategies for the protection of civil & political rights of Adivasi communities 2011-12
description:
In this project period, CSD will take initial steps towards devising and building strategies for the protection of the civil and political rights of adivasi [tribal] communities in India. 

To further this agenda, CSD has visualised a three-stage process in the long term, with the first stage being the development of legal practice guides for lawyers and human rights activists for issues pertaining to the civil rights of tribal communities. These practice guides will include legal procedures and strategies used in actual cases, and CSD will undertake research to map successful strategies and the range and types of litigation available for the protection of the human rights of tribals. In addition, research towards strategic litigation [Public Interest Litigations, petitions etc] will be undertaken via Public Interest Litigations or by petitioning local, statutory or constitutional authorities.  In the second stage, CSD will identify and train activists and lawyers in selected districts and states on using the practice guides, and prepare a curriculum for this process. In the final stage, it is envisaged that units of trained paralegals will be formed in selected states, which will investigate, monitor and draft cases pertaining to adivasi rights, and which will draw on established lawyers to argue cases.

In 2011-12, CSD, with UUHHJIF support, will undertake the following activities:
-	Case research 
-	Research for strategic litigation
-	3 fellowships [of 4 to 12 weeks each] to researchers 
-	Meetings with researchers to discuss cases, the status of adivasi rights, and the methodology for case research, archiving and documentation. 
-	Development of legal practice guides
-	Testing of practice guide modules
-	3 [15 days each] legal clinics for senior undergraduate law students from selected states on the civil and political rights of adivasis, with 25 students per clinic
-	4 training programmes for community activists from Andhra Pradesh to equip them to be paralegal workers. 30 participants are expected in each training.

The main expected or anticipated results are:
-	Development of legal practice guides on adivasi rights;  
-	Through use of the legal practice guides lawyers and activists are able to intervene more effectively; 
-	Strategic legal interventions are undertaken; 
-	Researcg knowledge outputs are prepared;
-	The understanding of undergraduate law students of civil and political rights of adivasis  is enhanced;
-	Community activists from Andhra Pradesh are trained to function as paralegal workers.

CSD is expected to make important contributions to Result Area 1 of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme: “Excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship.”
CSD-COUNCIL FOR SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT[SOUTHERN REGIONAL CENTRE]

title: Electoral and Political Process Reforms in India
