title: Facilitating self-reliant Non-Timber Forest Produce cooperatives in Orissa
description:
Vasundhara endeavours to work for Community forestry with explicit focus on the sustainable livelihood of the marginalised sections and on different environmental and biodiversity conservation issues.  Vasundhara's initiatives aim to create an enabling environment that will help rural and tribal population (especially women) to come out of the poverty trap by increasing the scope of forest-based livelihoods in the state of Odisha. 

Vasundhara works on sustainable livelihood issues by facilitating development of community enterprises  in the form of self-reliant cooperatives based on Non-Timber Forest Produce (NTFP). In addition, it contributes to environmental conservation by supporting and strengthening community-based initiatives to protect and conserve forests in Odisha.

Vasundhara's work helped to make NTFP-based livelihoods a central element in several rural and tribal development interventions in Odisha and led to the NTFP Policy of 2000 that eventually gave rights to more than 67 NTFP items to Gram Sabhas (Village Assembly). Vasundhara's interventions on livelihoods have led to the formation of 27 primary cooperatives and 2 unions trading in NTFPs covering around 1850 households in 30 Gram Panchayats (Village Councils jurisdiction) of four districts.  This resulted in a rise in income for an estimated 6000 indirect beneficiaries from commodities traded through the cooperatives . Women form the membership of the primary cooperatives, and 80% belong to scheduled tribes. 

The cooperatives and unions are engaged in collective trade of various NTFPs (e.g., Mohua, Siali leaves, Sal seed) and are creating a variety of value-added products. The cooperatives practice an advance-based commodity pooling model of business and sales are coordinated and facilitated by the unions at a nominal service charge. The goal of Vasundhara is to assist communities to gain access and control over the use of forest resources, thereby contributing towards sustainable livelihoods of the poor and to a greater economic decentralisation.

Vasundhara was formed in 1991 to work for institutional and policy changes in community forest management in the state of Odisha. It was registered under the Societies Registration Act in 1992.  Initially the work was focused on research , policy advocacy and networking. After 2000, with Hivos’ support, Vasundhara's work became more diversified towards sustainable forest based livelihood.  During 2012-2015 Vasundhara will support the women's cooperatives and unions to become economically independent and self–reliant in terms of their decision-making ability. 

By 2015, it is anticipated that these unions including primary cooperatives will have clear and comprehensive business plans. The income of cooperative members will increase with newer livelihood areas being integrated. Two retail outlets will be opened at union level which will be run and managed by their members. Members of the cooperatives will be able to negotiate with government for better infrastructure facilities (rural godowns) for the NTFP business.

Vasundhara's objectives are congruent with Hivos's policies: on access to resources (land, water, agriculture & forests) for marginalised forest communities and promotion of community enterprise for economic empowerment. Vasundhara's objectives of strengthening community participation and developing of networks of tribal and women's organisations and promotion of community based enterprises, are central to Hivos' policy concerns.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Mahbubnagar District, Andhra Pradesh
description:
WASSAN promotes initiatives inspired by community based natural resource management approaches, and focuses on mainstreaming these initiatives. This ensures scale and sustainability of these initiatives. Community based organisations (CBO) are at the heart of all  initiatives; CBO membership has been primarily of women. 

While several CSOs have been working on related issues of management of natural resources, very few have been able to use 'models' to embed them within state policies and programmes.  WASSAN is also one of the few organisations that has been able to work on an integrated systems approach where work on several themes like seeds, water, livestock, crops, soils etc is layered in a common geography.  Its work has gained WASSAN significant recognition at policy levels at the state and national levels. 

WASSAN would be the role model for the implementation of the comprehensive pilots which other CSOs across the country would try to emulate. The comprehensive pilots are key to demonstrating how the public investment regime needs to be structured to achieve higher agricultural productivity gains in rainfed areas.  

WASSAN intends to implement a comprehensive pilot in Daulatabad mandal of Andhra Pradesh. It aims to integrate aspects of seed systems, water management, livestock, inland fisheries, institutions etc into the government programmes and schemes. The uptake of the evidence related to productivity gains and increased food security will be directly into the State policy and programmes.     

As a secretariat of the Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network, WASSAN commands substantial respect from CSOs, academia and State alike. Its inclusive approach and strong value system has enabled the growth of the network. 

There is good resonance between the goals of WASSAN with that of Hivos.  Also, congruence in terms of values make WASSAN a natural ally.
WASSAN - Watershed Support Services & Activities Network
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: A Grassroots Cultural Centre Promoting Regional Theatre
description:
Ninasam is a community theatre institute with ‘no gates’ located in a small town called Heggodu in Shimoga district of Karnataka, India.  Ninasam nurtures young theatre practitioners and develops theatrical productions reaching a rural audience of at least 100,000 in Karnataka.

Ninasam is a highly creative and innovative theatre institute and always strives to create a larger communitarian base for theatre. Some of their prominent interventions have been as follows
Ninasam Theatre Institute enables theatre students from rural areas of Karnataka to be part of a 10 month course on theatre arts. Some of the graduates of these courses have begun their own unique initiatives in their hometowns and have also achieved national and international acclaim.
Tirugatta a travelling theatre troupe made up mostly of the graduates of the Ninasam Theatre Institute, which takes major theatre productions to different rural and semi-urban centers in Karnataka every year.
Ninasam Film Society is one of the few rural film societies in India to conduct Film Appreciation Courses. It also has the distinction of introducing film studies to Kannada audiences by publishing a number of books related to cinema. It has organised festivals of world film masters such as Chaplin, Bergman, Satyajit Ray, Kurosawa and Alain Resnais for local communities in and around the town of Heggodu.
Fellowships are given to junior and senior theatre practitioners to work for the Theatre Institute as directors, teachers, technicians and trainers. The fellowships have helped to enrich the quality of the Institute’s syllabus and teaching methodology as well as enabled the students to interact and work with diverse and experienced theatre practitioners.
Culture Conference is one of Ninasam’s flagship annual events. It provides a forum for interaction among celebrated artists, writers, intellectuals and lay theatre enthusiasts and for complementary academic discussions and art performances. 
Short-term Summer Theatre Workshops are aimed at young enthusiasts who cannot be part of the longer course.  The workshops enable them to employ theatre as a vital medium in community-related work in their respective geographical areas.

During 2012-2015 with Hivos’ support Ninasam will focus on building the capacities of the board members, grooming second line leadership and improving their Information and Communication Technology (ICT) skills. Additionally the cultural conference and summer theatre workshop will also be supported. 

Ninasam, a registered society, was founded in 1949 by theatre practitioners.  Ninasam’s work has brought many honours, including the Ramon Magsaysay Award for Creative Arts, Communication and Journalism, which was conferred on its co-founder K.V. Subbanna.

Hivos values Ninasam for its ability to bring high quality theatre production to the rural audiences. Also, Ninasam has been able to build a bridge between rural cultural spaces and larger national and international theatre discourse. Ninasam is also part of the India Theatre Forum, a budding forum of theatre groups, which aims to represent and respond to the interests and concerns of Indian theatre groups.

Considering Ninasam has created and promoted spaces for cultural expression of the rural masses it finds high synergy with the framework of the Expression and Engagement programme in Hivos
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Dewas District, Madhya Pradesh
description:
Over the last two decades, Samaj Pragati Sahayog (SPS) has grown to be one of India's largest grass-roots initiatives for water and livelihood security in around 260 villages of Dewas district of Madhya Pradesh, mainly in the  Adivasi (tribal) belt. This work has enhanced drinking water availability and has sustained employment generation and livelihood security in intervened villages.

SPS believes that location-specific watershed development combined with low-cost, low-risk agriculture, other nature-based livelihoods and women-led microfinance, can dramatically raise rural incomes, providing an enduring panacea to farmers in India's drylands.  SPS has worked out a package of agricultural practices finely tuned to the locally available natural resources and, thus, accessible to the poor (low-cost) and sustainable (low-risk). This approach arrests distress migration and liberates the rural poor from the clutches of usurious moneylender-traders. The central mandate of SPS is to empower India's most disadvantaged people - women, Adivasis, Dalits and the poor - thereby contributing to the strengthening of democracy at the grass-roots.  SPS also focuses on building and strengthening women-led people’s institutions which support participatory and decentralised governance.  Besides, SPS has worked closely with the government in programmes like MGNREGS (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme) to ensure effective expenditure leading to increase in irrigation and creation of sustainable livelihoods.

SPS is a society registered in 1990 under the Societies Registration Act, 1860 and headquartered in Bagli block of Devas District of Madhya Pradesh.  SPS is also a member of Revitalizing Rainfed  Agriculture  (RRA)  Network which  has  109 members spread across rainfed areas of the country, and is emerging as an important platform articulating the issues of rainfed agriculture at the national level.

SPS intends to implement a comprehensive pilot to revitalise rainfed agriculture in 200 villages in and around Bagli block of Dewas District, Madhya Pradesh.  Though this pilot, SPS proposes to formulate the framework and elements of a comprehensive package of rainfed area interventions. 

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Khandwa District, Madhya Pradesh
description:
The Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (India) works as a catalyst for the betterment of rural communities by providing direct support to local communities for activities and to develop models for sustainable use of natural resource and development of human resources. 
After 25 years of committed involvement in the development sector, AKRSP (India) today is working in over 1500 villages in three states of India namely Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat and Bihar.  AKRSP has been working in over 1100 villages in four environmentally challenged and economically vulnerable regions of Gujarat: the tribal blocks of Bharuch, Narmada, Surat & Tapi districts, coastal salinity-affected Junagadh & Porbandar districts and the drought-prone Surendranagar district. 

AKRSP has innovated and pioneered several initiatives in different thematic areas such as participatory irrigation management, joint forest management, rain water harvesting, watershed development, salinity ingress prevention and alternative energy to improve the quality of land, increase the availability of water for irrigation and introduce new inputs or technologies that improve agricultural productivity and to empower rural women and marginalized communities. Its work in these areas has helped to improve food security, increase agricultural income and reduce risks for the landed farmers and provide livelihood options for the poor and landless farmers. Focusing on landless farmers, families with small holdings and farmers with three acres or less, it has introduced a range of options from systems to improve rice and wheat yields to small-scale vegetable farming and other alternative means of livelihood.

AKRSP was selected as Project Implementation Agency for the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS) in Madhya Pradesh, which ensures that employment generation schemes lead to productive assets. Distress migration has been reduced by 70-90 percent among farmers and by 30-50 percent among agricultural labourers, according to a research study carried out by the International Water Management Institute titled “Agrarian Transformation Among Tribals: From Migrants to Farmer Irrigators”. AKRSP was the first NGO to implement Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) in Gujarat. Today, there is a PIM Act in Gujarat. AKRSP’s watershed approach has been recognised by Government through a citation of AKRSP in the revised national watershed guidelines.
AKRSP (India) is the part of Global Aga Khan Development Foundation eshtablished by His Highness the Aga Khan in 1984. It began its field operations in 1985 and has since become one of the largest grassroots NGOs in India with more than 250 staff in 27 locations and an annual budget of $6 million. It is also a member of Revitalizing Rainfed  Agriculture  (RRA)  Network which  has  109 members spread across rainfed areas of the country, and is emerging as an important platform for articulating the issues of rainfed agriculture at the national level.

AKRSP will implement a comprehensive pilot project on rainfed agriculture, which aims to  improve rural livelihoods and food security in four districts (Khandwa, Burhanpur, Khargone and Barwani)of Nimar region of Madhya Pradesh.  AKRSP has conceptualized a comprehensive model of rainfed agriculture, which would improve rural income through increased local employment opportunities, and have an impact on rural governance.  AKRSP will share its experience of implementing this model in larger domain.  

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Malkangiri District, Orissa
description:
Parivarttan works with the underprivileged and marginalised tribals in Malkangiri district (the poorest and most neglected district) in southwest Odisha to strengthen peoples' organizations, promote livelihood and food security, community health, advocacy & network building. Parivarttan assists vulnerable groups especially (e.g., women, children, tribals, dalits) to make optimum and sustainable use of locally available natural resources, to increase productivity of these resources, to generate off-farm / non-farm enterprise development, and to enhance access to land, water and forests.  Parivarttan promotes environmentally sustainable and socially equitable development. 

Parivarttan has supported the formation of self-help groups (SHGs) covering income generating activities, and has engaged in trainings, lobby and advocacy and capacity building of tribal communities in sustainable agriculture. The organisation carries a wide range expertise and working experience on livestock, soil and water conservation, seed preservation and mapping and rainfed agriculture-related activities. As mitigation activities, Parivarttan is actively involved in cultivation of paddy through the System of Rice Intensification (SRI) method.  Parivarttan also promotes inter-cropping, vegetable cultivation and the use of bio – fertilizer and pesticide.  Networking and building common platforms at village, block and district levels to streamline government social security schemes meant for the rural poor are important parts of Parivarttan's strategy.   Parivarttan works in close collaboration with various government schemes.  Apart from this, Parivarttan has taken a lead role in developing a network of like-minded organizations in Malkangiri District called ‘Malkangiri Action Group’. This network aims to develop a common platform to advocate for creating fair development policy for the poor and tribal people of Malkangiri district.  Parivarttan along with its network NGOs, works in 250 villages and 10,705 community-based organisations with a prime focus on tribal families. 

Parivarttan was registered as a society in 1994 and became fully functional in 1998. It was founded as a non-political and non-governmental voluntary organization to engage in sustainable development activities.

Parivarttan and the 14-member Malkangiri Action Group intend to improve rural livelihoods and especially food security in Malkangiri  district of Orissa by conceptualizing a comprehensive model of rainfed agriculture,  and to improve rural income through increased local employment opportunities.  Parivarttan anticipates a positive impact on rural governance and intends to share its successful model / approach in the larger domain.  

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Sustainable livelihood enhancement and enterprise promotion in Orissa
description:
Rashtriya Grameen Vikas Nidhi (RGVN) is a national-level development support organization that provides financial, technical and management  support to civil society organisations in fourteen Eastern and Northeastern Indian states .This support has strengthened 2700 civil society organizations benefiting nearly 1,50,682 households through more than 10,000 Self Help Groups (SHGs) formation. These networks of civil society organisations and SHGs are RGVN’s strength; many of them are now capable of taking up larger development projects. 

RGVN was founded as an autonomous, non profit organization in 1990. Since its inception, RGVN has worked relentlessly to explore and support sustainable  livelihoods,  promote  individual  and  community  initiatives  and build local capabilities. With the demand from the field and changes in the external world, RGVN also initiated microfinance (MF) retail programme in 1995.  RGVN’s MF activities  have now taken the form of an independent legal entity called the Brahmaputra Community Development Trust. Separation  of  MF  activities  has  given  RGVN  a  new  direction  to  focus  on  livelihood  sub-sectors  and  livelihood  enhancement  projects.  RGVN is now focusing on developing certain potential livelihood sub-sectors across various regions within RGVN’s operational area.   RGVN  has received an Award for “Outstanding Financial Inclusion Project in Northeastern Region” from the Small Industries Development Bank of India (SIDBI) in 2010. 

In Orissa and Andhra Pradesh, RGVN has enabled promotion of more than 350 grassroots organisations and reached out mostly through women to nearly 92,000 households through its  main programmes like  NGO Support Programme (NGOSP) and  Credit and Savings Programme (NGOMF).  

Next phase of Hivos support to RGVN focuses on empowering women in agriculture, NTFP and Handicraft through by organizing them into Producer Groups and making systematic interventions to enhance their participation and productivity in order to improve their Household income and food security. The project aims towards organizing 3650 women  from tribal dominated pockets of South & west Odisha , Telengana & north Andhra Pradesh into Eight Producers’ groups (Six Organic Vegetable  growers organization, One NTFP Producers  Group and One handicraft artisan based Producers Organization) 

RGVN's multi- dimensional approach to reduce poverty through socio-economic empowerment of the poor fits well with the policy focus of HIVOS' Green Entrepreneurship Programme.

title: Garima Abhiyan: Campaign for Elimination of Manual Scavenging and in 60 Districts in India
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Accelerating Inclusive  Development  through  Building and Strengthening Producer Collectives
description:
Building and Enabling Disaster Resilience Of Coastal Communities (BEDROC), formerly the NGO Coordination and Resource Centre (NCRC), has been active in Nagapattinam since the Tsunami of 2004. While initially it was involved in facilitating equitable and sustainable post-disaster rehabilitation efforts, by 2007 it was registered as a formal agency for building up long tern resilience of the vulnerable coastal communities. Understanding that resilience could only be built up through inclusive development, BEDROC focused on building the resilience of the farming communities by strengthening traditional livelihoods. This is done through Better Water Resource Management, Improved Farm & Crop Management, Collectivization and Institution Development. Through the project, 'Accelerating Inclusive Development Through Building and Strengthening Producer Collectives (2012 - 2014)', Hivos supports BEDROC to a. Promote inclusive development through agriculture; b. Build capacity and develop community-based institutions; c. Develop systems for value chain management; and d. Build, stabilize and strengthen remunerative markets

Through this project, BEDROC will include the generally excluded. BEDROC will work with women, landless and dalit agricultural labourers and support them for cultivation of horticultural crops, small millets, fodder, etc during income stressed periods. Women in certain areas will be encouraged to take up homestead cultivation. They will be encouraged to register as members in existing Water User Associations (WUA) or will be encouraged to form a Farmers’ Association. In addition, BEDROC will promote sustainable agriculture through a comprehensive package of practices starting from increasing soil fertility to water management, supply of quality seeds, improved on-farm practices and better crop management. BEDROC will be work closely with reputed organizations like CIKS, Krishi Vigyan Kendra, etc for transfer of knowledge, capacity building and for supply of inputs. 

BEDROC worked strongly in building the capacities of local communities for sustainable operation and maintenance of their resources, and 27 village level WUAs were formed. Given the fact that all the stakeholders in the Water User Associations (WUAs) are farmers, these platforms built up were seen to have an advantage that went beyond just water resource management. There are 1063 farmer members in these WUAs, of which, 84% are small and marginal farmers. With a view to leveraging their improved economies of scale through collectivization, a separate institution dedicated to marketing aspects was set up and registered as the Nagai Agri Producers’ Company (NAPROC). All commercial activities are activated through this Company. BEDROC will work towards building up people’s institutions by instilling sense of ownership, building up the capacities of the members and developing local leadership so that these organizations manage their operations on their own. The members of the producer organization will be capacitated to understand marketing as a collective effort apart from mandatory requirements associated with running a legal commercial enterprise like taxation, audits, quality control aspects etc, so as to make the producer organization sustainable. BEDROC will facilitate market linkages with retail chains and neighboring markets to sell agri produce through NAPROC. Women homestead cultivators, landless and dalit labourers will be encouraged to take up contract farming on fallow lands after understanding the market needs. 

As a part of the dairying activities, 10 milk collectives have been set up and these Milk Collectives have been federated under the Nagai Milk Producers’ Company (NAMPCO). There are plans to increase this to 50 milk collectives in the next three years. The transaction levels will be very high and the record keeping will become difficult and labour intensive unless the transactions are computerized on a daily basis. BEDROC will use customized computerised MIS for streamlined business operations.

The project will reach out to 1000 small holder farmers approximately. About 700 farmers will be benefited through provision of inputs like certified seeds, 200 agricultural labourers/ assetless families be will be supported in augmenting their income through horticulture and  relay cropping. Apart from this, the project will also be involving 100 women directly through horticulture and homestead farming and 100 farmers benefit from development of remunerative markets. The project also benefits around 3000 milk producers indirectly.

BEDROC will work in rainfed areas and will help smallholder producer companies to become sustainable. It will promote sustainable agricultural practices and build the livelihood options of women and marginalized communities. All of these are the priority areas of the the Green Entrepreneurship programme of Hivos.
Building&Enabling Disaster Resilience of Costal Communities
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Mainstreaming and upscaling sustainable agriculture in Tamil Nadu
description:
Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems (CIKS) has been working with a vision of utilization of indigenous knowledge and resources for sustainable growth and agriculture since the last eighteen years and has significantly demonstrated the viability of several sustainable agricultural practices. It has currently reached a stage where several of the research outcomes, field engagements and models are ready for upscaling and mainstreaming. Through this project, "Towards Mainstreaming and Upscaling Sustainable Agriculture in Tamil Nadu (2012-2015)" Hivos supports CIKS to position itself as a flagship organization and work towards being a national centre for sustainable agriculture to ensure food and nutrition security while sustaining and enriching the natural resource base through knowledge, scalable models and creating an enabling environment. This project has three components, namely, A. Poverty reduction through sustainable agriculture in Tamil Nadu; B. Development of human resources for sustainable organic farming; and C. Up-scaling technologies through convergence. 

'Poverty reduction through sustainable agriculture in Tamil Nadu' (co-funded by DFID) aims to enhance incomes of 9000 small holder agricultural households in three districts of Tamil Nadu (1400 landless, 5400 marginal and small and 2200 medium farmers from 75 villages in the districts of Kancheepuram, Tiruvannamalai and Nagapattinam) in an accelerated and sustainable way. Emphasis is on farming that uses locally generated inputs and resources to assure farmers get better returns for their produce and ensure their livelihood security. Based on this understanding, the strategy is to have a four pronged approach - increase production, decrease cultivation cost, improve credit and improve markets. There are seven direct interventions viz. 1) Home Gardens, 2) Full package of practices, including organic practices, 3) Provision of quality seeds and fertility improvement products, 4) Provision of Bio-pesticides, 5) Market information and linkages 6) Value addition, 7) Allied activities like backyard poultry. CIKS' experience shows that quality inputs and services related to these seven interventions can substantially make agriculture remunerative for the small holders. The delivery model for carrying out these interventions will include farmers’ sangams at the village level and farmers federation (agriculture producer company) at the district level. Agriculture services will be provided by Village Agricultural Business Development Services Providers (lead farmers) and they will ensure delivery of local and household-specific critical information on proven technologies and practices. This will be a farmer-led social enterprise model with the potential to sustain itself, and to upscale for larger impact.

'Development of human resources for sustainable organic farming' is seen as an important need. While many civil society organizations are involved in promoting sustainable agriculture, a major lacuna is human resources in the sector, as technical personnel in the agriculture sector are almost completely or largely trained in chemical agriculture; hence, have no orientation in sustainable agriculture. To address this, CIKS will identify and select youth at high school level who have interest in farming. Orientation and training to teachers as well as students on sustainable agriculture will be done in 100 identified schools in Tamil Nadu which have agriculture as a vocational training subject. In addition, CIKS will also work with Shriram IGNOU Community College which offers a two year course on integrated farm management. The students who are admitted to this course are those who have completed high school with vocational training in agriculture. Through these efforts, CIKS will develop a cadre of at least 20 village youth per year with aptitude and orientation in sustainable agriculture.  

CIKS will be 'Up-scaling technologies through convergence' by working with other agencies promoting large scale programmes on agriculture. By using existing programmes already on the ground, CIKS will liaise with Government departments and NGOs so as to upscale several tested technologies in a short time in an effective manner. This way, CIKS will reach out to at least 300,000 beneficiaries in three years.

CIKS was registered as a Trust in 1995 with five founding Trustees and four additional Trustees were inducted subsequently. The board comprises of scientists, industrialists, academicians, an advocate and a medical doctor. All the board members are renowned people in their respective fields. Through this project, CIKS supports small holder farmers in mostly rainfed areas through sustainable agriculture and facilitate in developing their own enterprises. All these are areas of priority within the Green Entrepreneurship programme of Hivos.
CIKS: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Thematic Inputs on Seeds towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture
description:
Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems (CIKS) is a not for profit organisation striving to strengthen and revitalize Indian Knowledge Systems with particular focus on sustainable agriculture and traditional knowledge based health care systems. Biodiversity Conservation, Organic Agriculture and Vrikshayurveda (the ancient Indian plant science having relevance in the areas of ayurveda, agriculture, horticulture and life sciences) form the core focus areas of the organisation. 
CIKS’ initiatives in biodiversity conservation have helped farmers in Tamil Nadu conserve over 180 indigenous seed varieties, hence protecting the dwindling genetic base and giving farmers a way to prepare and overcome stress situations. Moreover, CIKS is engaged in developing feasible and user-friendly programs to help farmers adopt organic agriculture. CIKS has explored the application of Vrikshayurveda in seed treatment, soil testing and preparation, methods for yield increase, identification and treatment of plant diseases, land classification, details of cultivation of plants etc. 

The programmes of CIKS can broadly be classified into research and extension. The research programme draws mainly from the work on the dedicated experimental farm, actual field experiments, and knowledge mining from ancient texts and local folklores. The extension work comprises of training programmes and production of educational material. CIKS undertakes action research, training and extension on various aspects of organic farming, cultivation of organic rice, cotton, oil seeds, vegetables etc. Under its biodiversity initiatives, CIKS has set up rural gene banks for the conservation of traditional seed varieties. The community seed banks promoted in four districts of Tamil Nadu covering 125 villages have a network of 3,000 farmers and have managed to conserve more than 130 varieties of paddy and 50 varieties of vegetables seeds. From the past one year CIKS has been anchoring the seeds node of RRA network. CIKS has also established a resource centre that provides information on organic farming and has been marketing the local organic produce under the brand name of Arogyam.

CIKS came into existence in August 1993, when it was formed as an autonomous centre under the Academy of Development Sciences, Maharashtra. In January 1995 it was registered as an independent trust in Chennai, Tamil Nadu. It works in five districts of Tamil Nadu covering about 12,400 acres of land under organic cultivation. Over the last 17 years, its action research with farmers has demonstrated that apart from reducing the costs of cultivation, organic agriculture enhances the food and nutritional securities of the small and marginal farmers.

Anchoring the seeds node of Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network, CIKS would endeavour to promote a deeper understanding on the issues of ‘seed’ in varied rainfed contexts and the nature and functioning of related public investments and institutions. It aims to synthesize existing experiences on various innovations and evolve newer approaches amenable for mainstreaming into public institutions advocating for developing appropriate seeds systems for rainfed regions.
CIKS: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Bellwether: Caspian Debt Fund - HTF (2012)
description:
While the Indian microfinance industry has grown over the years, Indian microfinance, in essence, has been largely a single product credit industry, making it imperative to find ways to design basket of products and services to create 'real' financial inclusion. Micorfinance in India has largely been concentrated in a few geographies with limited products which did not address the varied financial needs of the population. Some segments of the population were neglected by both the mainstream financial institutions as well as the microfinance sector. For example, many microenterprises and producer organizations in the agriculture sector came in this 'missing middle' category. Through this Caspian Debt Fund (CDF), Bellwether will address this issue by providing finance to the largely unreached sectors apart from microfinance institutions. 

The Bellwether Microfinance Fund (BMF) is a Non Banking Finance Company in India with Investments from the Hivos Triodos Fund, Gray Ghost Microfinance Fund and other investors. The Bellwether Fund was established when two social investors (Gray Ghost Microfinance Fund and Hivos Triodos Fund) came together with a local entrepreneur/ microfinance professional (Mr.Viswanatha Prasad) in 2005, to establish what would be India's first Microfinance Investment Fund. Since 2005, Bellwether has made twelve equity investments and seventy debt investments. Bellwether was structured as an open ended fund, with no liquidation date. However, now Bellwether seeks to exit partially from its present portfolio and initiate a second portfolio within Bellwether, recycling/ redeploying part of the proceeds recovered from the initial portfolio. This initiative will be referred to as the Caspian Debt Fund (CDF). 

Through CDF, Bellwether would be re-affirming to its broader mission that focuses on delivering flexible and innovative funding support to sectors that have the potential to create greater impact and inclusion of low income and underserved communities across the country. Apart from Microfinance & Micro, Small & Medium Enterprise (MSME) sectors, CDF will extend its rigorous but creative investment approach to other additional areas which are Agriculture & Allied activities and Micro-mortgage/ Housing Finance. Subject to Indian regulation, CDF will extend short term, long term, secured or unsecured debt to Indian corporate and non-corporate entities. It is expected that a significant majority of the loans would be made to regulated and for-profit entities. Within the MSME and Micro-mortgage/ Housing Finance segments, CDF will reach out to the end clients (largely microenterprises in the unorganized sector and low income households for micro housing) through intermediary financial institutions. Within the agriculture and allied activities, CDF would look for opportunities to engage at different stages in the value chain. While the focus would be on producer organizations and will reach out directly to them; CDF would also reach out to private companies engaged in the post-harvest supply value chain after careful examination of the role played by these intermediaries in the value chain.

As a result of this initiative, entrepreneurs (including producer organizations) will be better organized, have more options at their disposal, negotiate better with the market, which in turn will lead to better incomes. CDF would be strengthening organizations and businesses that support smallholder farmers and MSMEs in rural areas; and contribute to sustainable economic development and direct poverty alleviation. CDF will thus will increase the capacities of enterprising people living in rural areas and strengthen their economic position. Hence, Hivos supports this initiative as it directly addresses the objectives of the Green Entrepreneurship programme of Hivos.

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Kuchchh District, Gujarat
description:
Arid Communities and Technologies (A.C.T.) is a voluntary organization based at Bhuj, district Kutchh, Gujarat. A.C.T. aims to strengthen livelihoods of communities in arid and semi-arid regions. It supports communities to resolve ecological constraints through facilitation, by providing access to appropriate technologies and by engendering technological and institutional solutions. 

A.C.T. extends technical support to individuals, institutions and communities in the field of natural resources management with a focus on ground water management. It also undertakes action-research in generating technological solutions for strengthening livelihoods of communities and implements innovative initiatives such as designing entrepreneurial solutions to deal with the over growth of prosopis juliflora and marketing of organic products for organic farming communities. The organisation was founded in 2004 and registered under Societies Act, 1860 and Charitable Trust Act, 1950.

A.C.T. has worked on key projects on ground water management in the states of Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan. It specializes in developing GIS-based database of natural resources and associated knowledge systems of Kachchh and other parts of Gujarat. In addition to conducting studies, A.C.T. engages in policy and advocacy at various levels and collaborates with government and non government agencies.The representatives of A.C.T. hold membership of advisory committee of District Watershed Management committee.

The present proposal focuses on launching a year long preparatory phase of comprehensive pilot (CPs) in rainfed Villages of Abdasa Taluka of Kachchh district, Gujarat and seeks to complement the overarching objective of Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network to advocate for a comprehensive agriculture policy ensuring resilient growth of rainfed regions by generating evidence. Reducing cost of cultivation by minimising dependence on external inputs and promoting ecological agriculture practices and sustainable use of natural resources leading to enhanced income and food security of small and marginal producers form the core of RRA programme and remain central to Hivos’ approach. RRAN’s objectives are aligned to Hivos' approach of environmental sustainability and resilience of agricultural production systems.

A.C.T. has vast experience of working on livelihoods issues in arid and semi-arid regions. It has supported the communities to resolve ecological constraints through facilitation, by providing access to technologies and by engendering technological and institutional solutions. A.C.T. will leverage its experience of engaging with and building capacity of government departments on water resource management. The project will be implemented in partnership with Satvik:Promoting Ecological Farming, Shri Vivekanand Research and Training Institute (VRTI), Naliya  and Kutch Fodder Fruit and Forest Development Trust (KFFFDT). Satvik has experience of promoting ecological farming and will be responsible to provide technical support and implement agriculture related field interventions. VRTI and KFFDT have a strong grassroots presence and are implementing ongoing government projects. The complimentary expertise of each organisation will aid effective launch of the comprehensive pilot in Abdasa. The project aims towards setting up a team for CP implementations, carrying out situational analysis of rainfed areas of Abdasa block and proposing comprehensive solutions suited for rainfed geographies as per the framework of RRAN and mapping out potential of various ongoing and proposed government programs to invest in the interventions proposed in CP.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Palamau District, Jharkhand
description:
Vikas Sahyog Kendra (VSK) is a non-profit organization working with tribal and dalit communities in Jharkhand. VSK's interventions are planned around promoting sustainable agriculture and ensuring food security by advocating for these issues in district and local governance institutions.

In 1997, VSK was registered formally under the societies registration act, 1860. It follows a rights based approach for development initiatives in order to secure access to natural resources, public investments and welfare benefits that contribute to improving livelihoods of adivasi and dalit communities. The approach comprises of organizing and building capacities of primary stakeholders by establishing issue based advocacy forums at multiple levels and providing technical support for implementation. Since its inception, VSK has promoted various community institutions and forums around the key issues of community forest management and labour rights under various programmes. 

The current programmes of the organisation are drawn on ensuring wage and food entitlements provisioned under various public welfare programmes. The organization is also working on channelising resources to develop natural resources based livelihoods. 

The present proposal as part of the Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network focuses on carrying out one year of preparatory phase for implementing comprehensive pilots (CPs) in rainfed villages of Chhatarpur block of district Palamau, Jharkhand. RRA programme aims to evolve a comprehensive public policy to realise growth and development potential of production systems in rainfed areas. Enhancing sustainability of natural resources, reducing cost of cultivation and strengthening diverse local production systems to contribute substantially to food and income security of small and marginal farmers in rainfed regions constitute the key elements of RRA programme. These propositions of RRA augment Hivos’ programme efforts in integrating ecological and social considerations into policies on agriculture creating an environment conducive for small producers.

VSK seeks to further the objectives of the RRA network by ensuring greater flow of public investments enhancing the livelihood of the farmers in rainfed areas. The organisation has prepared ‘Panchayat Centric Rainfed Area Plans’ for the current agriculture season and has mobilized labour networks in the villages that will be advocating for resource allocation to projects supporting the rainfed agriculture sub-systems in the villages as conceived by the RRA network.  Harnessing the agency of the rural communities for attaining their full potential is also at the core of the Hivos' Green Entrepreneurship programme.

The project aims towards setting up of team for CP implementations, carrying out situational analysis of rainfed areas of the block along with specific problems and solution and mapping out potential of various ongoing and proposed government programs. At the end of the preparatory phase, VSK would be able to develop detailed proposal for demonstrating comprehensive pilots in larger programme area and the strategy for embedding these into suitable government programmes.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Tumkur District, Karnataka
description:
IDF is a resource and action research organization that works at grassroots level for the empowerment of underprivileged sections of the society .The organization has domain experience in micro-credit and credit-plus services aimed at developing entrepreneurial culture. It works with both rural and urban poor of the society who are financially excluded. 

IDF got registered in November 2001 as a Public Charitable Trust . It is a Bangalore-based organisation, founded by former bankers who worked in social banking and the small micro-enterprise sector. It works in Karnataka, especially North Karnataka, and has one Regional Office in Dharwar and 5 branch offices in other parts of Karnataka State. 

IDF aims to achieve its mission through holistic approaches involving social mobilization, financial inclusion of the excluded sections and, promotion of prudent financial practices and sustainable livelihoods. It has the experience of working with the small, marginal and tenant farmers and women, promoting sustainable agriculture, enhancing farm productivity, making viable farm livelihoods, enhancing their capacities in CBO management, promotion of marketing linkages through producers collectives and whole rounded financial inclusion.

IDF has successfully piloted the Business Correspondent/Business Facilitator Model which envisages involvement of Community-Based Organisations (CBOs), Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs), and Micro-finance Institutions (MFIs) and others who are embedded in financially excluded communities to act as financial intermediaries to achieve the goal of financial inclusion. IDF has promoted and mentoring nine Community based organisations of the SHGs of women and farmers, artisans, cumulatively in 11 districts falling under rainfed – poverty track across Karnataka reaching out to 2.41 lakh poor households, enabling to secure their livelihoods.

Under RRA -CP,IDF endeavours to develop small pilots on Seed, soil productivity, water, livestock, financial inclusion, etc  in few clusters of villages in two  gram panchayats (Madikehalli and Chowdanakuppe) of Kunigal Taluka in Tumkur district of Karnataka in partnership with local mainstream institutions and the government departments. The proposal also aims at developing detailed proposal for implementing larger comprehensive pilots.

IDF is working to increase access to financial services in under-served regions and for excluded communities; further, it helps small producers in business development and to access markets.  These focus areas are congruent with that of RRA network under Green Entrepreneurship Programme of Hivos.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Thematic Inputs on Water towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture
description:
Advanced Centre for Water Resources Development and Management (ACWADAM) is a not for profit organisation having expertise in various branches of earth and water sciences. Hydrogeology being its core strength, ACWADAM engages in action research and education on groundwater management. It is currently facilitating work related to groundwater management in various parts of India, through partnerships with other Civil Society Organisations and with the Government. ACWADAM’s goal is to establish a groundwater management agenda in India, an agenda based on the science of hydrogeology and the principles of managing a “common pool resource” through community participation.

ACWADAM has also provided technical advice to various agencies on specific aspects of groundwater management.  The varied spectrum of work around ground water management has helped the organisation analyze the hydrogeology of different regions in India, diagnose problems of groundwater and seek solutions that attempt to combine practical aspects with larger issues such as sustainability and equity of water resources. With these experiences, ACWADAM has successfully been involved in developing strategies for water resources, especially groundwater, at wider, policy levels. ACWADAM was founded by prominent geologists and registered in 1999 under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. 


The current proposal from ACWADAM to provide support in the thematic area of water for rainfed regions as part of the Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network (RRAN). The overall goal of RRAN is to evolve a comprehensive public policy package to realise growth and development potential of production systems in rainfed areas with focus on enhancing sustainability of natural resources, reducing cost of cultivation and strengthening diverse local production systems to contribute substantially to food and income security of small and marginal farmers in rainfed regions. These propositions of RRA augment Hivos’ programme efforts in integrating ecological and social considerations into policies on agriculture creating an environment conducive for small producers.
Advanced Center for Water Resources Devpt & Mgmt-ACWADAM

title: Voice for the Verbal - Enabling Technology Appropriation by Adivasis
description:
For the level of public scrutiny and debate in India about the rights of Adivasi's (indigenous people of India) over their resources and issues of governance in these regions, the information that comes into public domain (blogs, newspapers, tv channels, radio) are all reported by non-adivasis who cannot speak the local language and relate directly with the Adivasi's. Therefore the concept of 'Swara' (voice) is relevant and unique, for it provides the Adivasi's access to a voice-based platform simple enough to understand and use to air their aspirations and concerns to a wide range of audience who otherwise will not have a chance to be connected to them.

The fundamental theory of change underpinning Swara is that if conversations and mutual sharing of experiences are facilitated, concerns and aspirations at a mass scale will lead to to improved understanding and positive spirit of partnership between communities and governments and therefore resolve conflict and eases the path towards sustainable progress. 

The project which was first piloted in Chattisgarh in February 2010 was implemented as a way to have people use mobile phones as a mass communication medium by allowing users to record their own content as well as listen to content left by other people via an IVR system linked to a website. The content is moderated by trained volunteers, often professional journalists who edit the content for quality, verify its accuracy and finally publish it to the web and phone interfaces. This simple technological intervention has quickly taken the shape of a community communication platform where people with the most basic technical skills can share their concerns with the world in their own voice. The pilot has logged over 100,000 calls and continues to receive 200-300 calls a day in over five languages. Over 1600 reports from citizen reporters have been published to the web. The content generated on the voice is also included as daily email bulletins that reaches about 4000 people everyday. Members subscribing to this list include Government officials, mainstream media professionals, activists and grassroots leaders. Many-a-time the information that has been shared on Swara has facilitated positive actions and responses by the state as well as analysis and coverage by mainstream media. 

All organizations part of Swara including Environics Trust have a constitutional and fundamental commitment to open sharing of knowledge and information. The audio content at the moment is completely in the public domain with no license associated with it. At the outset of the project we would prefer to keep the content open under a creative commons license. Technology related content, such as source code, and all new technology developed as part of the project will be released into the public domain under a Free Software Foundation approved Open Source License, such as GPL or Apache. 

The Environics Trust was established in 1991 and Hivos supports it for its contribution to use technologies to promote the voices of the unheard to make democracy as a participatory and inclusive process.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Scaling up of decentralized bio-energy centers for improving rural energy access and creating   livelihood opportunities for the tribal and rural poor in the Konkan region of Maharashtra
description:
Applied Environmental Research Foundation (AERF) is a registered non-government organization (registered as Charitable Trust on 5 August 1994) based in Pune, India that aims to demonstrate the conservation of biological diversity through the active participation of local communities combined with the use of research techniques. The Foundation aims to address the biological diversity loss of a region by building sustainable development models that would also benefit the areas' local populace. AERF believes in community-based conservation or participatory conservation which implies involving people in the process of conservation which will not only link to ecosystem development, but also aid in poverty alleviation. It's work is spread in the two biodiversity hotspots of India– Western Ghats and North East India. To fulfill its aim, AERF works through five complementary programmes in both the  region i.e Sacred grove conservation, Applied Biodiversity Research, Community, Climate Change and Conservation, Energy & Biodiversity and Business & Biodiversity. AERF manages, monitors and restores biodiversity and habitats on private and community lands as well. The Foundation develops natural resource management models that actively involve local communities in the cause of conservation. AERF has a dedicated team of researchers & practitioners who bring varied expertise, experience and skills supported by an advisory committee of eminent scientists and advisors. AERF also operates through a strong network of organizations including  IUCN and LEAD.
 
In Maharashtra, AERF’s work is spread across four districts - Pune, Raigad, Ratnagiri and Sindhudurg. AERF is active through partnership with communities in about 100 villages with an outreach of around 4000-6000 largely tribal beneficiaries. With the focus on sustainable development through community based natural resource management and enterprise development, AERF has demonstrated the benefits of Straight Vegetable Oil (a kind of Bio-fuel which is extracted from Pongamia pinnata and Mahua) in running any fossil fuel (diesel) powered instruments like Oil expeller, electricity generators, tractors and irrigation pump sets without making any modifications in them, in two districts of Maharashtra. Moreover, the success  of the enterprise was also demonstrated in creating livelihood opportunities for the unemployed youth and tribals through setting up  bio-diesel resource centers which has made a very good case for development of sustainable rural enterprise with high replication potential in different parts of India. 

The support of Hivos is towards successful expansion of the initiative by establishing two decentralized bio-fuel resource centres (for SVO extraction) in the Village Kitadi in Sakoli tehshil of Bhandara district and Village Dolkhamb in Shahapur block of Thane district which will create an alternative livelihood opportunities for about 2000 rural families (including tribals) from 60 surrounding villages and empower them to manage the supply chain of the Straight Vegetable Oil (SVO) right from Seed (Mahua and Pongamia) collection to SVO marketing. By establishing the decentralized bio-fuel resource centres, this project also aims at ensuring a continuous supply of clean bio-fuel in the Thane and Bhandara districts of Maharashtra. The objectives of the planned initiative dovetail well into the mandate of Green Entrepreneurship programme of Hivos.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Evolving into a National Resource Centre for Child Rights to ensure greater advocacy and monitoring of the implementation of Right to Education Act
description:
Based on the non-negotiable principle that ‘no child works and every child attends full time formal school as a matter of right’, Mamidipudi Venkatarangaiya Foundation (MVF) has been working towards abolition of child labour in all forms and mainstreaming children into formal schools for over two decades now.

MVF is rights based organization actively involved in elimination of child labour through universalisation of education and has so far mainstreamed over 1 million children from work into full time formal education. MVF has been crucial in strengthening community ownership towards child rights especially with regard to formal education in 2259 villages in Andhra Pradesh and other states like Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Bihar and Tamil Nadu.  The MVF’s model to abolish child labour has inspired many civil society organisations. Even State governments like Madhya Pradesh and Bihar have invited MVF to provide technical support to implement such an initiative in their states. MVF has also inspired the International Stop Child Labour campaign which is a campaign of NGOs (non government organisations) and unions from 6 European countries who closely work with developing countries to abolish child labour. This campaign was initiated by Hivos. Presently MVF provides technical support in implementing the campaign in various Central American and African countries

Some of MVF’s strategies for mainstreaming of children in school have been proved to be universally replicable. For instance the residential bridge course camps which help in mainstreaming older children who have been out of the school system for longer periods of time have been implemented as part of the State Government’s programme in Andhra Pradesh. Another such initiative is their work on strengthening quality of education by mobilising government school teachers to create student friendly curriculum and low cost educational learning material to enable a creative and fun learning process. They have also mobilised 1500 government school teachers together under the banner of Teachers Forum for Child Rights.

The focus of this phase of Hivos’ support to MVF is two- fold. MVF will leverage on its field experiences to enable effective monitoring and advocacy on the Right to Education (RTE) Act 2009 in Andhra Pradesh, Bihar and Madhya Pradesh. MVF will work towards building the capacities of  its stakeholders namely community forums, school monitoring systems, gram Panchayats, and teachers so that they work more closely with the government machineries to ensure effective implementation of the RTE Act. MVF will also focus on strengthening its capacities to be a national resource centre on child rights in the country by providing technical support on child rights issues as well as to strengthen advocacy on child rights issues. The other focus of the support is more institutional which is to enable MVF to diversify its donor base especially to sustain their core costs as well as to build their internal capacities on gender issues.

The Mamidipudi Venkatarangaiya Foundation (MVF), a registered trust, was established in 1981 in memory of educationist and historian Prof. Mamidipudi Venkatarangaiya. It began as a research institution on issues relating to social transformation.

MVF’s innovative approach to build the capacities of rural and urban communities for abolition of child labour by universalizing school education is really been effective and Hivos continues to  find value in being able to support MVF’s initiative  through the  Rights and Citizenship Programme in Hivos.

title: Thematic Inputs on Soil towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture
description:
Forum for Integrated Development (FFID) is a not for profit organisation that works with small and marginal farmers towards improving their livelihood options and making farming a sustainable and profitable occupation. The organisation is dedicated to supporting, empowering and strengthening rural communities in coping with adverse situations. It aims to reducing rural distress through livelihoods interventions focusing on natural resource management and agriculture development. With the core belief in minimizing risks and attaining the goal of self sufficiency for smallholder farmers, FFID develops and promotes alternative models of agriculture. The experiences from the field inform the policy and advocacy initiatives of FFID, which aim to reorient policies in favor of sustainable and organic agriculture.

In 2004, FFID initiated its flagship programme, “Chetna Organic & Fair Trade Agriculture Program India (Chetna Organic)”, to support the smallholder cotton farmers from the rainfed regions of Northern Andhra Pradesh, Vidarbha in Maharashtra and South Western Odisha. The region is one of the largest cotton growing regions of the country and has witnessed high famer suicide rates due to the agriculture crisis prevailing in the country.  FFID initiated a composite pilot on Organic / Non-Pesticide Management (NPM) & Fair-trade supply chain development in these regions. With the objective of promoting ownership of the programme among the farmers, in 2007 Chetna Organic Farmers Association (COFA) was registered as a separate organisation under Andhra Pradesh Societies Registration Act, 2001. COFA works as a farmers’ support organization and provides technical and social extension services. The extension programmes range from promoting farmers’ cooperatives and SHGs and implementing watersheds activities for the member farmers to promoting investments from Corporate Social Responsibility programmes in local communities for building infrastructure. 

In addition to COFA, FFID also promoted a farmer owned commodity trading company, Chetna Organic Agriculture Producer Company Ltd (COAPCL), which works on developing sustainable market linkages for farmer’s produce in national and international markets. COAPCL is also involved in training and capacity building of farmer communities on issues such as quality management, local level market development and maintenance of organic standards and certification.

FFID has promoted sustainable agriculture covering 35,000 acres of area through various initiatives on natural resources management, integrated farming systems and value chain development. Having a firm belief in collective action and fair supply chain, FFID expanded its reach from 234 farmer members in 2004 to around 15,300 in 2012. FFID was established on 10th march, 1995 and registered under Andhra Pradesh (Telangana Area) Public Societies Registration Act, 1350 Fasli (Act 1 of 1350F).

FFID’s objectives and its propositions as the soil node of Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network align with the network’s agenda of demonstrating and arguing for a differentiated policy paradigm for rainfed agriculture and advocating for more equitable investments in rainfed farming systems through sustainable and ecological techniques suitable for rainfed conditions. FFID’s engagement with RRA network will contribute to articulating the policy propositions for investments on enhancing soil productivity in rainfed regions.

title: ProCIF - Incubation Finance Fund
description:
Friends of Women’s World Banking, India (FWWB-India) was promoted by SEWA Bank, as an affiliate of Women’s World Banking, a global network created to focus on the need for women’s direct access to financial services and recognizing women’s role in building a nation’s economy. Led by a Board of women leaders representing strong community based initiatives, FWWB’s strategy has been to act as a catalyst with the commitment to build a society based on equity and social justice where women are leaders in social change. Their operations cover the entire country and are an apex network of institutions providing financial services to women from low-income households.  

FWWB acknowledges the importance of individual as well as collective growth as a crucial instrument to the inclusive growth which can be addressed  by access to credit, developing managerial know how to optimize effective utilization of resources and identifying risks and mitigants of the same. Hence, to maximize impact, enhance institutional credit, access to technological inputs, increased livelihoods, FWWB supports organizations both for credit as well as capacity building needs either directly or through linkages.

FWWB combined its loans with technical assistance to ensure sustainable growth, and from 1989 to 2010 it has reached out to more than 300 Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs) with technical assistance and nearly 200 with loan support. With this support, they could provide financial services to more than 1 million low income people through their network in 17 states of India. FWWB has also been providing capacity building support to MFIs that includes operational support in the initial years for start-ups, training by in-house teams and external resources, exposure visits to best practices, etc. 

FWWB was formed as a Society (under the Societies Registration Act 1860) in 1982 as the first affiliate of Women’s World Banking .Currently,it is governed by a 11 member Board of Directors with Ms. Anshu Bhartiya as the CEO.

In 2010, after formidable expansion of its microfinance operations, FWWB hived-off its microfinance activity to Ananya Finance for Inclusive Growth (AFIG) Pvt. Ltd, a non-banking finance company.  FWWB now focuses to work in the areas of livelihood promotion (through its Livelihood and Enterprise Development Program launched in 2007), women empowerment, strengthening institutions and need-based financial products and services that impact the lives of the poor. Under its programme on livelihood and Enterprise development, it has reached approximately 80,000 individuals (as on 31st July 2012) to meet the need of credit, skills enhancement for scaling up operations, access to markets, product designs and increasing business development knowledge  through 16 Partner Organization working in the underserved areas. FWWB in its LEAD Programme provides support to Partner Organizations through two sources-Credit Fund and Technical Assistance. 

FWWB in the last two decades has been a leader at well known livelihood and microfinance forums in India and internationally. It has contributed effectively in policy making, leveraging international best practices and impacting overall development and growth of this sector. 
Hivos’ partnership with FWWB aims to provide handholding support [credit support – incubation finance and working capital] to producer enterprises (of small and marginal farmers - producers both in the farm and allied sectors) in their incubation stages under The Producer Entrepreneurship Catalyst & Incubation Facility (ProCIF) set up by Hivos. Hivos’s contract with FWWB is specifically intended to set up the “Incubation Finance Fund” under the ProCIF programme.

FWWB’s mandate towards providing financial and capacity building services support in order to promote livelihoods and self-reliance of the poor fits well in the current framework of Hivos’ Green Entrepreneurship programme.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture: Coordinating Policy Initiatives and Extending Support to Comprehensive Pilots and Thematic Nodes
description:
WASSAN is a membership based non-profit, support organisation registered as a Trust and started functioning as an independent organisation since December 1999. Prior to this, it was functioning as part of Centre for World Solidarity (CWS) coordinating a network of NGOs to influence the Watershed Development programme of the Government from 1995 onwards. It identifies itself as a National level facilitator for people centred NRM and related livelihoods with enhanced capacities to promote effective network culture and build and service different partnerships. 
WASSAN has emerged as a key capacity building institution at the state level. Its focus is on decentralizing the planning and implementation of development programmes and institutionalising the processes in strong community based organisations. It works on various themes like natural resource management, watershed processes, community organisations etc and provides capacity building support to NGOs and CBOs in implementing watershed and natural resource based livelihoods  programmes.
It mostly works with the Mandal Mahila Samakhyas (MMS)-the federation of SHGs of poor women. Some of the achievements of WASSAN include a) mobilization and formation of network of sheep rearers, fishermen co-operative b) backward and forward linkages for livelihoods initiatives of these co-operatives c) established linkages with research and govt. institutions and successful piloting of many NRM based livelihoods projects.
WASSAN’s work has focused on two streams of work viz. enhanced institutional capacities of CBOs for improving natural resource based livelihoods of the poor living primarily in rainfed areas and advocacy for bringing in improved laws and guidelines for NRM based livelihoods. It acts as a bridge for infusing a bottom-up approach in the Government initiated watershed programmes. WASSAN’s close association with civil society organizations, research institutions and an active engagement with women CBOs facilitate constructive engagement of WASSAN with the Government. WASSAN’s efforts are directly linked with poverty alleviation and strengthening the civil society at the lowest levels. 
As part of the RRA network, WASSAN proposes to coordinate the policy and advocacy initiatives of aiming for enhanced and diffrentiated public investments in rainfed agrciulture and extend support to the comprehenisve pilots and thematic nodes of the network.
WASSAN - Watershed Support Services & Activities Network
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Management of Small Grant Facility to Mobilise and Strengthen Effective Producers’ Organsiations that are Trade/ Market Worthy Enabling
description:
Support to producer organizations is one of the focus areas under the Green Entreprenurship programme of Hivos. Hivos has been supporting many partners across India who have a livelihood programme component. Formation and working through groups of producers of different sizes, scales and forms has been a critical strategy across various partners to achieve their livelihood outcomes. But, quite often producers are supported in smaller groups, informal groups, etc. which will require focused effort in making these producers into effective producer organisations. Most importantly, the Facilitating Organisations need to be capacitated to effectively mobilise producers into appropriate producers’ organisations, strengthen them and make these producer organisations ‘market/ trade worthy’. Unless this kind of focused effort is put in, these informal and less-formal groups will remain at the same level, and will not be able to move up in the ladder to use market instruments with respect to credit, market linkages, etc. In this context, Hivos has set up a ‘Small Grant Facility for Facilitating Organisations’to help them in better mobilise and strengthen their producer organisations. The idea is to support Facilitating Organisations (that have a good reach to producers) with funding support to enable them to access services from variety of service providers and ensure development of effective Producer Organisations.   

The Small Grant Facility for Facilitating Organisations (SGF-FO) needs to be managed effectively, as many partners of Hivos and possibly other organisations, would apply and use these funds. This will be done by Vrutti (Livelihood Resource Centre). Vrutti will house and manage effectively the small grant facility to ensure achievement of the key objective of developing and strengthening effective producer organisations. The type of services that can be availed through this fund by facilitating organisations could be – capacitating the organisations about the various forms of producer organisations, legal forms, good practices;  help them in thinking over pros-and-cons of each form and decide the most appropriate form for the producer organisations;  training the POs;  developing participatory strategic and business plans;  identifying market opportunities, products, etc.; development of detailed project report, financial projections; and even testing out the first few cycles of operations to get their capacities built.  

Vrutti, Livelihood Resource Centre works with the vision to contribute to livelihood promotion and improving quality of life of disadvantaged groups of people. Vrutti got registered in 2009 as a not-for-profit organization under the Karnataka Societies Registration Act, Karnataka, India and is part of Catalyst Group of Institutions, a passionate development support group working in the social development sector since 1994. With a mission to alleviate poverty, it works directly with the communities, supports other organisations, networks with individuals working in the area of livelihood promotion and helps them in developing effective strategies, processes, models and support systems through participatory action research, management services and sector level support. Vrutti provides support to variety of organizations viz., Government, multi-lateral and bi-lateral agencies, international and national non-Governmental organisations, community based organisations (CBOs), micro-finance institutions (MFIs) and corporates, in promoting livelihoods for their communities.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Learning and capacity development in relation to large initiatives
description:
This project promotes learning and capacity development on multi-actor initiatives, programme management and project management.

In its business plan 2011-15, Hivos made a strategic decision to gradually reorient its strategy towards supporting programmatic approaches. A diversification of roles is visualised as well.  Whereas Hivos’ traditional strength has been in grant-making, over the next few years Hivos will emphasize other roles more: co-creator, implementer / project manager, facilitator, knowledge hub, innovator, linker and policy advocacy. These are major shifts that require a steep learning curve and strategic investment in learning and capacity development.  Negotiating this curve calls for stock-taking, critical reflection, analysis and synthesis internally as well as drawing from and engaging with external debates and learning processes.

In the course of this project, specific attention will be paid to initiatives in which Hivos is playing roles other than grant-making in order to gain insight into the preparedness of Hivos to play these different roles, how Hivos could be better equipped to play these diverse roles, the tensions between / among the roles, etc.  A number of roles will be looked into; special attention will be given to the project / programme management role and to other roles where Hivos clearly adds value.  The starting point will be systematization and critical reflection on experiences within Hivos.  Simultaneously, opportunities to benefit from new research and the learning processes of other organisations will be identified and seized.  Tracking external debates, and making relevant external insights and resources widely accessible within Hivos will be an important aspect of the project.  

Specific learning questions will be formulated after an initial phase of preparing an inventory of large initiatives that Hivos is currently involved in, and analysing the findings to identify apparent patterns and recurrent concerns.

title: Thematic inputs on institutions towards revitalizing rainfed agriculture
