title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Bankura District, West Bengal
description:
PRADAN is a voluntary organisation established in 1983 and registered under the Societies Registration Act of India. 

PRADAN believes that the path towards conquering economic poverty is through enhancing the livelihood capabilities of the poor and giving them access to sustainable income generation opportunities.  The programmes are designed to build the technical, organisational, negotiating and networking skills of the poor communities in order to facilitate achievement of their goals. 

PRADAN currently works in around 4,000 villages across eight of the poorest states (Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal and Assam) of India. A majority of the families that PRADAN works with belong to the Schedule Tribes and Schedule Castes. 

PRADAN follows a four-pronged approach to achieve its goals:
•	Promoting and nurturing Self-Help Groups (SHGs) of poor women and strengthening them as organisations to leverage institutional finances for members’ livelihoods.
•	Developing and introducing locally suitable economic activities to increase productivity and incomes among SHG members; building synergic collaboration with a wide variety of stakeholders.
•	Mobilising finances for livelihood assets and infrastructure from government bodies, donors, banks, and other financial institutions.
•	Setting up mechanisms to sustain the livelihood gains made by the poor communities.

PRADAN’S livelihood programmes can be broadly classified into the following sectoral activities: Promotion of SHG's; Forest Based Livelihood, Natural resource management, livestock development and microenterprise promotion

As a strategic principle, PRADAN leverages livelihood investments by linking the rural poor to government programmes and banks.  PRADAN plays the role of a facilitator in such linkages. Additionally, people’s own resources, including savings in self-help groups are also mobilised.  

PRADAN’s objectives and its propositions of the comprehensive pilot of Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network proposed in Hirabadh of block of district Bankura, West Bengal align with the network’s agenda of demonstrating techniques appropriate for developing rainfed agriculture systems at scale and advocating for systemic changes to channelize public investment in rainfed farming systems. PRADAN’s engagement with RRA network will contribute to establishing proof of concept of comprehensive livelihoods models in rainfed regions and articulating the policy propositions aiming for enhanced and differentiated public allocations for rainfed regions.

title: Develop and operate ProCIF Secretariat
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening People's organisations of informal sector workers to ensure better implementation of policies and schemes for  informal sector workers
description:
Kislay works with the marginalized urban poor and informal sector workers to ensure their rights and entitlements especially in terms of their dignity and labour rights are protected.
Kislay had facilitated formation of Delhi Shramik Sangathan a federation of unorganized sector workers in Delhi. The member organizations of this federation are   “Delhi Nirman Mazdoor Sangathan” (DNMS), an organization of construction workers and Delhi Gharelu Kamgar Sangathan (DGKS), an organization of domestic workers. The present membership of DNMS is 6500 members and that of DGKS is 1024 members.
 
Kislay focusses on strengthening people’s  organizations to empower workers to claim their labour rights, estabilishing linkages with labour and  other government departments to ensure access to social security benefits and building alliances with other  people’s organisations to strengthen advocacy and influence policy changes. Kislay also actively engages with the slum communities of Delhi on issues of housing and fair distribution of subsidized food grains through creative community media such as theatre. Recently, performances of their street play 'Hum Jaanengey, Hum Jaagengey' (We will know!), generated intense discussion and a people-led campaign against corruption in their local Public Distribution System (for food grains).

Kislay’s’ is one of the few organisations in Delhi that have been able to build people’s organisations of marginalized urban workers as well as expand its membership consistently over the years. Their advocacy work both at the grassroot level and with other actors especially government have yielded significant achievements in terms of policy changes and better implementation of social security benefits. Some of the commendable milestones that they achieved in the recent past are as follows-
•	Registration of around 6382 construction workers in Delhi Building and Other Construction Workers Welfare Board (DBOCWWB) to avail social security benefits.
•	1500 construction workers received (Rashtriya Swasthya Bhima Yojna) RSBY card for access to medical services.
•	The slum policy of Delhi got amended as per the demands and suggestions proposed by Delhi Shramik Sangathan which in turn will  protect lakhs of informal sector workers living in slum areas from getting displaced from the city.

In the period 2013-14 Kislay will focus on strengthening the capacities of the people’s organisations to enable gender sensitive leadership, increased membership and improved communication skills. They will also work on strengthening linkages with the government labor department for enabling increase in registration of workers and release of social security benefits to workers.  Their advocacy with the State government for influencing policy changes will be done strategically by building alliances with other informal sector networks and peoples’ organsiations in the state.

Kislay is situated in Delhi and registered under the Society’s Registration Act in 1992.

Kislay’s work towards enhancing the participation of urban poor and marginalized workers to claim their labour and other constitutional rights are congruent with the programme priorities of both Unitarian Universalist Holdeen and Hivos.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening the collectives of Sex workers and Sexual Minorities in Karnataka
description:
Sangama (which means confluence) is a human rights organisation focusing on promoting and defending the rights of working class sexual minorities, sex workers and PLHIV. Sangama works with those who face oppression due to their gender non-conformity and/or sexual preference (these include 'Jogappas', 'Kothis', 'Hijras', 'Doubledeckers', bisexuals, lesbians, homosexuals, transgender (M2F and F2M) and others), with sex workers (male-female-transgender) and PLHIV (male-female-transgender). 

Even though the public discourse on issues of sexual minorities in the past couple of years has gained visibility in India, there are still very few organisations that work on the issue with the strategic direction and depth as Sangama. Their main strategy of promoting and strengthening community based organisations, movement building, and capacity building of these communities to ensure that they gain access to their citizenship rights is appropriate, relevant and has gained ground considerably. So much so that it is for the first time that a transgender person has been appointed as staff within the Karnataka High Court and the State Government has passed an order providing welfare rights to all sexual minorities in the state.   

Specifically, Sangama's work has contributed to the empowerment of sexual minorities, sex workers and PLHIV in Karnataka and Tamilnadu through education, advocacy and organising. Sangama's work has broadened and deepened the discourse on sexuality, sex work as profession, HIV status, and the right to sexual health as a fundamental right, linking these issues and the concerns of these social groups with larger social, political and development issues/movements in the country so as to mainstream them. 

Sangama has gained considerable recognition over the years as one of the few organisations in the country dedicated to the rights of diverse sexual minorities, sex workers and PLHIV  which has successfully promoted their interests and empowered them. It has high credibility in the field of human rights and has built strong links with many movements and organisations in the areas of human rights, women's rights, Dalit rights, and child rights. Sangama has contributed considerably to the change in law (Sec 377), which has opened up new areas of work and campaigning.  It is well positioned to advocate the cause of its constituencies and bring about the changes in society and law that are necessary for greater freedom, liberty and equality of the members of the constituencies it works for/with. Sangama's work is essentially collaborative in nature and its overall goal is to promote self determination and self empowerment of these social groups.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthen People's Union and Farmer Cooperatives  to advocate for important legal and constitutional rights of tribal and marginalized communities in two districts of Maharashtra
description:
Elgar Pratishthan’s core area of engagement is to advocate for the constitutional and legal rights of tribal and marginalized rural communities in blocks of Chandrapur and Gadchiroli districts of Maharashtra. 

Elgar Pratishthan has organized tribal communities into membership organizations namely Shramik Elgar, a people’s organisation of informal sector workers; the Elgar Women’s Credit Cooperative Society; two farmers’ cooperatives in Pomburna and Jivti sub-divisions; and a dairy cooperative. They have been successfully able to collectivize 67contract workers to demand for fair wages and safe working conditions. Similarly through their advocacy and campaigns they have been able to regain agricultural and forest land titles of the tribal communities. Another of their large scale campaign by rural women has been on liquor prohibition in Chandrapur district which seeks to challenge the nexus of the political parties with liquor companies and its implications on violence against women.
In the period 2013-15 the focus of their interventions will be two fold. Firstly to enhance tribal women’s rights to address issues of social security and domestic violence. Secondly to strengthen the capacities of the people’s organisation and the cooperatives to advocate for better implementation of laws related to forest resources, labour and local governance. Some of their planned milestones are 

1.	The  membership of their  people’s organisations  will increase  from 15,000 to 19,000 members 
2.	7000 women will be mobilized to campaign against prohibition of liquor in Chandrapur district in Maharashtra
3.	Ensure an 50% increase in the number of women members in their credit and farmer cooperatives
4.	60 Joint Forest Management Committees will get their fair dues and have greater control over forest produce
5.	 Increased bargaining power of 2000 urban and rural contract factory labourers to demand for timely payments and advocate for change in contract labour act

Elgar Pratishthan was founded in 1999 and is registered as a society and trust. This will be our sixth consecutive year of support to the organisation. Elgar’s ability to mobilize and organise marginalized and tribal communities to demand for their constitutional rights and have increased access to livelihood and financial resources finds high synergy with the programme priorities of both Hivos and Unitarian Universalist Holdeen.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Mahbubnagar District, Andhra Pradesh
description:
"WASSAN promotes initiatives inspired by community based natural resource management approaches, and focuses on mainstreaming these initiatives. This ensures scale and sustainability of these initiatives. Community based organisations (CBO) are at the heart of all  initiatives; CBO membership has been primarily of women. 

While several CSOs have been working on related issues of management of natural resources, very few have been able to use 'models' to embed them within state policies and programmes.  WASSAN is also one of the few organisations that has been able to work on an integrated systems approach where work on several themes like seeds, water, livestock, crops, soils etc is layered in a common geography.  Its work has gained WASSAN significant recognition at policy levels at the state and national levels. 

WASSAN would be the role model for the implementation of the comprehensive pilots which other CSOs across the country would try to emulate. The comprehensive pilots are key to demonstrating how the public investment regime needs to be structured to achieve higher agricultural productivity gains in rainfed areas.  

WASSAN intends to implement a comprehensive pilot in Daulatabad mandal of Andhra Pradesh. It aims to integrate aspects of seed systems, water management, livestock, inland fisheries, institutions etc into the government programmes and schemes. The uptake of the evidence related to productivity gains and increased food security will be directly into the State policy and programmes.     

As a secretariat of the Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture Network, WASSAN commands substantial respect from CSOs, academia and State alike. Its inclusive approach and strong value system has enabled the growth of the network. 

There is good resonance between the goals of WASSAN with that of Hivos.  Also, congruence in terms of values make WASSAN a natural ally. "
WASSAN - Watershed Support Services & Activities Network
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Malkangiri District, Orissa
description:
Parivarttan works with the underprivileged and marginalised tribals in Malkangiri district (the poorest and most neglected district) in southwest Odisha to strengthen peoples' organizations, promote livelihood and food security, community health, advocacy & network building. Parivarttan assists vulnerable groups especially (e.g., women, children, tribals, dalits) to make optimum and sustainable use of locally available natural resources, to increase productivity of these resources, to generate off-farm / non-farm enterprise development, and to enhance access to land, water and forests.  Parivarttan promotes environmentally sustainable and socially equitable development. 

Parivarttan has supported the formation of self-help groups (SHGs) covering income generating activities, and has engaged in trainings, lobby and advocacy and capacity building of tribal communities in sustainable agriculture. The organisation carries a wide range expertise and working experience on livestock, soil and water conservation, seed preservation and mapping and rainfed agriculture-related activities. As mitigation activities, Parivarttan is actively involved in cultivation of paddy through the System of Rice Intensification (SRI) method.  Parivarttan also promotes inter-cropping, vegetable cultivation and the use of bio – fertilizer and pesticide.  Networking and building common platforms at village, block and district levels to streamline government social security schemes meant for the rural poor are important parts of Parivarttan's strategy.   Parivarttan works in close collaboration with various government schemes.  Apart from this, Parivarttan has taken a lead role in developing a network of like-minded organizations in Malkangiri District called ‘Malkangiri Action Group’. This network aims to develop a common platform to advocate for creating fair development policy for the poor and tribal people of Malkangiri district.  Parivarttan along with its network NGOs, works in 250 villages and 10,705 community-based organisations with a prime focus on tribal families. 

Parivarttan was registered as a society in 1994 and became fully functional in 1998. It was founded as a non-political and non-governmental voluntary organization to engage in sustainable development activities.

Parivarttan and the 14-member Malkangiri Action Group intend to improve rural livelihoods and especially food security in Malkangiri  district of Orissa by conceptualizing a comprehensive model of rainfed agriculture,  and to improve rural income through increased local employment opportunities.  Parivarttan anticipates a positive impact on rural governance and intends to share its successful model / approach in the larger domain.  

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Dewas District, Madhya Pradesh
description:
Over the last two decades, Samaj Pragati Sahayog (SPS) has grown to be one of India's largest grass-roots initiatives for water and livelihood security in around 260 villages of Dewas district of Madhya Pradesh, mainly in the  Adivasi (tribal) belt. This work has enhanced drinking water availability and has sustained employment generation and livelihood security in intervened villages.

SPS believes that location-specific watershed development combined with low-cost, low-risk agriculture, other nature-based livelihoods and women-led microfinance, can dramatically raise rural incomes, providing an enduring panacea to farmers in India's drylands.  SPS has worked out a package of agricultural practices finely tuned to the locally available natural resources and, thus, accessible to the poor (low-cost) and sustainable (low-risk). This approach arrests distress migration and liberates the rural poor from the clutches of usurious moneylender-traders. The central mandate of SPS is to empower India's most disadvantaged people - women, Adivasis, Dalits and the poor - thereby contributing to the strengthening of democracy at the grass-roots.  SPS also focuses on building and strengthening women-led people’s institutions which support participatory and decentralised governance.  Besides, SPS has worked closely with the government in programmes like MGNREGS (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme) to ensure effective expenditure leading to increase in irrigation and creation of sustainable livelihoods.

SPS is a society registered in 1990 under the Societies Registration Act, 1860 and headquartered in Bagli block of Devas District of Madhya Pradesh.  SPS is also a member of Revitalizing Rainfed  Agriculture  (RRA)  Network which  has  109 members spread across rainfed areas of the country, and is emerging as an important platform articulating the issues of rainfed agriculture at the national level.

SPS intends to implement a comprehensive pilot to revitalise rainfed agriculture in 200 villages in and around Bagli block of Dewas District, Madhya Pradesh.  Though this pilot, SPS proposes to formulate the framework and elements of a comprehensive package of rainfed area interventions. 

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Implementing a Comprehensive Pilot towards Revitalising Rainfed Agriculture in Khandwa District, Orissa
description:
The Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (India) works as a catalyst for the betterment of rural communities by providing direct support to local communities for activities and to develop models for sustainable use of natural resource and development of human resources. 
After 25 years of committed involvement in the development sector, AKRSP (India) today is working in over 1500 villages in three states of India namely Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat and Bihar.  AKRSP has been working in over 1100 villages in four environmentally challenged and economically vulnerable regions of Gujarat: the tribal blocks of Bharuch, Narmada, Surat & Tapi districts, coastal salinity-affected Junagadh & Porbandar districts and the drought-prone Surendranagar district. 

AKRSP has innovated and pioneered several initiatives in different thematic areas such as participatory irrigation management, joint forest management, rain water harvesting, watershed development, salinity ingress prevention and alternative energy to improve the quality of land, increase the availability of water for irrigation and introduce new inputs or technologies that improve agricultural productivity and to empower rural women and marginalized communities. Its work in these areas has helped to improve food security, increase agricultural income and reduce risks for the landed farmers and provide livelihood options for the poor and landless farmers. Focusing on landless farmers, families with small holdings and farmers with three acres or less, it has introduced a range of options from systems to improve rice and wheat yields to small-scale vegetable farming and other alternative means of livelihood.

AKRSP was selected as Project Implementation Agency for the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS) in Madhya Pradesh, which ensures that employment generation schemes lead to productive assets. Distress migration has been reduced by 70-90 percent among farmers and by 30-50 percent among agricultural labourers, according to a research study carried out by the International Water Management Institute titled “Agrarian Transformation Among Tribals: From Migrants to Farmer Irrigators”. AKRSP was the first NGO to implement Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) in Gujarat. Today, there is a PIM Act in Gujarat. AKRSP’s watershed approach has been recognised by Government through a citation of AKRSP in the revised national watershed guidelines.
AKRSP (India) is the part of Global Aga Khan Development Foundation eshtablished by His Highness the Aga Khan in 1984. It began its field operations in 1985 and has since become one of the largest grassroots NGOs in India with more than 250 staff in 27 locations and an annual budget of $6 million. It is also a member of Revitalizing Rainfed  Agriculture  (RRA)  Network which  has  109 members spread across rainfed areas of the country, and is emerging as an important platform for articulating the issues of rainfed agriculture at the national level.

AKRSP will implement a comprehensive pilot project on rainfed agriculture, which aims to  improve rural livelihoods and food security in four districts (Khandwa, Burhanpur, Khargone and Barwani)of Nimar region of Madhya Pradesh.  AKRSP has conceptualized a comprehensive model of rainfed agriculture, which would improve rural income through increased local employment opportunities, and have an impact on rural governance.  AKRSP will share its experience of implementing this model in larger domain.  

The programme objectives are in congruence with the goal of revitalising rainfed agriculture, which is a key element of Hivos' Green Enterpreneurship Programme in India.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening and expanding the State and National forum of single women to represent their voices and concerns collectively
description:
Astha Sansthan has supported Association of Women Alone (ASWA) since ASWA emerged as a membership-based self-help organisation of widows and single women in January 2000.  ASWA is one of the many people's organisations that ASTHA has helped to emerge in Rajasthan. The Rajasthan-wide ASWA now has a membership of about 41,000, all low-income rural and urban women who are widowed or separated.  This membership is spread in 33 districts across 132 blocks in Rajasthan. The steady growth of the constituency is indicative of the slow, measured approach that ASWA/Astha takes to ensure as much of effective implementation as possible. The National Association of Women Alone has expanded to seven states with the specific agenda of improving visibility and voice of single women across the country and ensuring that their concerns get reflected in policies and state laws.

The Main Objective of the work with low-income Single Women is to help them to build up organizations of Single Women, to help each other solve the problems they face, to “be there”, as family, for each other, giving strength and confidence to each member of the organizations.  The women collectively will change caste and community customs that are discriminatory, will lobby the government for more resources and better laws and policies for Single Women, will prevent atrocities on Single Women, will help them to claim possession of land rights, and in all ways, be an “alternate family” for the women members.

ASWA and National forum for Single Women’s Rights have been instrumental for lobbying for positive changes in the present policies and legislation concerning single women in Rajasthan.  Their advocacy efforts have led to significant changes in financial schemes for widows and other single women in the past as well in the present as reflected in the government budget (March 2013) where provisions for single women were announced. They have also ensured the concerns of single women are included in the recommendation of the women empowerments’ committee to the Planning commission towards the 12th Five Year Plan.

Both the Association of Strong Women Alone, Rajasthan and the National Forum for Single Women’s Rights are formed for the purpose of enabling low-income Single Women to claim their rights as citizens, and as persons. The Overall Approach is organization, training, expansion, sharing, lobbying and advocacy.

Astha was formed in 1986 and was registered as a Society, under Society Registration Act.

Hivos supports Astha Sansthan/ASWA for its consistent and pioneering efforts to ensure better rights, better lives for women of ASWA and a better society based on values of justice, equality and humanism.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Supporting three federations in rural Gujarat towards self reliance and autonomous functioning
description:
Utthan Trust works with marginalised communities like women, Dalits, adivasis and minorities in the coastal and tribal regions in Gujarat to promote gender equity, social justice and sustainable economic development.

The focus of Utthan’s interventions is on women’s empowerment and livelihood security within the framework of promoting gender equity, human rights and improving the quality of life of its constituency. Utthan primarily works in three coastal districts – Bhavnagar, Amreli and Kutch and two tribal districts – Dahod and Panchmahal. 

Utthan’s key strategy is to organise rural, marginalised women into village level collectives to work towards equality, women’s empowerment, justice, access to basic rights, sanitation, food security etc. The collectives are part of larger federations, with Utthan providing capacity building support and assistance. Utthan has helped form four women’s federations which have an outreach of more than 7000 members. The federations take up a range of activities dealing with the cross cutting issues of gender, women’s rights, conflict resolution, peace building and livelihood security. 

Utthan's early interventions were marked by facilitating and supporting gender sensitization and building a movement of women and other vulnerable groups their empowerment to meet their basic livelihood needs and to protect their resources and to restore the traditional role of communities and households in managing their natural resources in Gujarat. Utthan’s major efforts in the past years have been from a view to deepen and upscale its interventions on gender and empowerment, livelihood security through Integrated Natural Resource management in the context of manmade and natural disasters, as well as on peace and justice through conflict transformation and efforts to ensure human rights. 

It is through the efforts of Utthan that women as individuals, Nyay Samiti, Land Committee members and as representatives of Sangathans have started contesting elections, raising their voices against violence, discrimination in education, inequity in PDS and other human rights violations before authorities, fighting for access to resources for improving livelihoods. Resource augmentation and conservation programmes like Horticulture development in small land holdings in tribal area, watershed development, lobster and crab fattening, agricultural development have had a huge impact on people’s livelihoods and standard of living. Their 4 women federations are successfully revolving savings for livelihood purposes and are now moving towards self reliance and autonomy

In this phase of support from the UUHHJIF [Unitarian Universalist Holdeen Hivos Just India Fund], Utthan will focus on facilitating a smooth transition and building in various mechanisms for sustainability and self reliance of the four federations.  .  

Utthan was registered as a Trust in 1981.

Utthan’s focus on collectivisation and mobilisation of women from marginalised communities finds high synergy with the objectives and programme priorities of UUHHJIF.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Building capacities of Adivasi  Youth and Women to strengthen their engagement with the Adivasi Movement in Jharkhand
description:
Bindrai Institute for Research Study and Action (BIRSA) works towards the rights of adivasis (indigenous tribes) and Dalits in the Adivasi areas of Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, West Bengal and Orissa. 

After being conceived during the height of the campaign for the creation of the state of Jharkhand in 2000, BIRSA has led and taken part in movements for human rights, labour, livelihood and land rights and to retain Adivasi culture. Due to its efforts in the last 20 years, BIRSA has established itself as one of the few civil society organizations in the country directly run and managed by adivasis and other marginalized communities. 

BIRSA expanded into four independent branches – the Human Rights, Resource and Training Centre, the Mines Monitoring Centre, the Campaign for Forest People’s Rights and a women’s wing. BIRSA’s Mines Monitoring Centre initiated the Internship Programme in 2003. According to an evaluation conducted by a 3-member committee in 2005, the internship programme was unique and a significant step to deepen the Adivasi movement. Birsa since 2003 has supported 46 interns of which 18 interns are women.   Many of these interns have returned to their local organisations and made significant interventions in their communities. 

During this phase of support BIRSA will build the capacities of its interns and ex interns to deepen their engagement with their local community organsiations. Birsa will also facilitate the formation of a women’s wing within the community based organisations enabling the participation of atleast 7000 women. Also Birsa will ensure that the participation of women members’ increases to at least 50% in governance, planning, implementation and monitoring processes of the programmes in Birsa and its community based organisations

BIRSA was formally established in 1990 and is a registered under the Society Registration Act. 

As a Just India Fund partner, BIRSA's work contributes to excluded and marginalised citizens claiming space for participation and full citizenship, an important goal of both Unitarian Universalist Holdeen and Hivos
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthen and expand the work of people’s organisations facilitated by JSK to move towards self reliance
description:
Jana Sanghati Kendra [Centre for People’s Solidarity] is an organisation which works with landless and marginalised agricultural labourers in West Bengal.

The objectives of JSK are: to assist landless poor and marginalised agricultural labourers to develop strong, independent and self-reliant organisations and to inform them about their rights; to create and develop collective programmes to strengthen people’s organisations; to assist rural women to organise and to inform them about their rights; to collaborate with like-minded organisations on local and national-level campaigns, and to encourage a process of dialogue in society through cultural action. 

The catalyst for JSK’s involvement with agricultural labourers was a local wage struggle in 1988, which resulted in the formation of PBKMS [Paschim Bengal Khet Mazdoor Samiti or the West Bengal Farm Workers’ Association], an independent union of agricultural labourers. The union then began taking part in various campaigns and struggles. In 1990, a separate women’s rights organisation - SMS [Shramjeevi Mahila Samiti or The Women Labourers’ Association], was formed within the umbrella of PBKMS. JSK plays a facilitative role towards capacity building of these two organisations. 

While the members of PBKMS and SMS work together on mobilization and collectivization of labourers, SMS keeps its focus on women’s rights, ensuring gender equality within the structure of PBKMS. As of March 2013 PBMKS had a membership of close to 50,000 individuals [all members of SMS are automatically members of PBKMS].

JSK played a proactive role among the several organisations in the country that demanded for a central legislation guaranteeing employment, which resulted in the passage of the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act [2005] (NREGA). Subsequently they have been consistently monitoring the implementation of NREGA and ensuring that agricultural labourers get access to its benefits. JSK and PBKMS have worked extensively on the issue of land rights and have taken part in various campaigns against forcible and sometimes illegal land acquisition in the state. Since 2009 JSK has been instrumental in demanding for a Food Security Bill which not just addresses the issues of entitlements but also of food production. This Bill is now in its final stages of discussion in the Parliament.  

SMS has adapted shalishi, a traditional dispute resolution mechanism in rural West Bengal to deal with 900-1000 cases of domestic violence every year.  SMS has taken an active role in preventing trafficking and forced marriages in their areas. Recognition for this work has been was received when SMS was given the Harriet Tubman Award from Free the Slaves in 2009 for its community based anti-slavery work. SMS has been an active member of Maitree, a network of individual women, women’s groups and other NGOs in West Bengal

The focus of the present phase of support to JSK is to strengthen and expand the work of people’s organisations (PBKMS and SMS) facilitated by JSK to move towards self reliance and organise large scale campaigns to ensure better access to  rights, entitlements and dignity of their constituency.

JSK was formally registered in 1984 under the Society registration Act.

As a UUHHJIF partner, JSK's work will contribute to two major goals of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme: ‘Excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship’, and ‘Legislation and policy meet international standards and are implemented in a manner that benefits all citizens and reduces existing inequalities’.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthen the Tribal development forum and implementation of PESA in in three blocks of Udaipur and Sirohi districts in Rajasthan
description:
Kotra Adivasi Sansthan [KAS] is an organisation that works on enhancing the social, economic, livelihood and human rights of Adivasis (tribals) and other marginalised communities in Udaipur and Sirohi Districts in Rajasthan. 

Since its establishment in 1998, KAS has made strong contributions for tribal rights in Udaipur District in Rajasthan, and in a very short time-frame, has become an independent organisation led and staffed by tribals. It was originally established by the NGO Astha Sansthan, but has since forged its own identity, although they continue to work closely together.

KAS, which primarily works in the Kotra Block of Udaipur District and the neighboring tribal areas. KAS provides technical support to the tribal people's organisation Adivasi Vikas Manch, which usually takes the lead in tribal campaigns and assertions by tribals for their rights and entitlements. KAS’ interventions are well thought out in relation to the problems it seeks to address: atrocities against tribals and marginalised groups, lack of sufficient employment and livelihood options, lack of food security, reduced prominence for village councils in planning local development, lack of individual and community forest rights, the lack of proper monitoring and planning in the implementation of beneficial government laws and schemes etc. 

Adivasi Vikas Manch [the Tribal Development Forum] is a 7000 tribal member organisation  that works on the following objectives supporting  tribals, backward classes and rural poor in improving their social, economic, cultural and political status; enhancing their awareness on their rights and entitlements, and ensuring effective implementation of development schemes, policies and initiatives. Since the passing of the Forest Rights Act [to provide forest land ownership to tribal communities] and the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, KAS has been monitoring the implementation and taking up follow-up action with relevant government authorities. It has also been engaged in establishing traditional community-based governance mechanisms in Kotra Block under the provisions of the Panchayat – Extension to Scheduled Areas Act. 

KAS/ AVM have supported more than 1589 Adivasis in Kotra to get their land entitlements under the FRA. It is through the advocacy and lobbying efforts of KAS that there is improved implementation of programmes programs like MGNREGA, PDS and other various government schemes for Adivasis in Kotra district of Rajasthan.

KAS in this phase of support will focus on strengthening the leadership capacities of the members of the Adivasi Mahila Manch and work on improving the implementation of PESA in three blocks of Udaipur and Sirohi districts of Rajasthan

KAS was registered as a Society in October 1998

KAS was included in the UUHHJIF partner portfolio due to its focus on collectivisation and mobilisation of the marginalised, especially tribals. KAS is expected to make key contributions to Result Area 1 of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme: Excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthen the institutional capacities of NASVI and its member organisations to evolve into a national forum of street vendor federations in the country
description:
The National Association of Street Vendors in India [NASVI] is a coalition of street vendor organisations, trade unions, community-based organisations, NGOs, and individual activists that seek to advance the rights and entitlements of street vendors in the country. NASVI’s interventions and initiatives are led from its coordination office in New Delhi. NASVI currently has 714 organisations in almost 23 states of the country. 

NASVI has focused its work on securing the livelihood and dignity of street vendors in their work through policy interventions  for changes in the political and legal framework and implementation of favourable policies and laws; undertaking dialogues and interfacing with policy makers, administrators and planners; organising campaigns, conferences and workshops at the national and international level; providing support, including legal support, to street vendors in crisis; enhancing the capacity of street vendors to take up issues at different levels; providing a range of financial services; collecting and disseminating information; and creating a favourable social environment for street vendors. 

NASVI employs a range of strategies for the benefit of its stakeholders. While it lobbies regularly with the national and state governments on issues concerning street vendors, its members also undertake ground-level campaigns and protests. It provides legal and other support to its members. NASVI consistently seeks to expand its membership and makes concrete efforts to reach out to newer areas. It effectively collects and disseminates information pertaining to street vendors through its website, newsletter and leaflets.

NASVI has been very successful in giving street vendors a unique identity of their own, and by bringing them together at the national level; it has ensured that they have strong collective bargaining powers. NASVI was also instrumental in lobbying with the national government to set up the ‘National Policy for Urban Street Vendors [2004]’, which mandates a strong legal framework to protect and promote street vending in the different states. Post which NASVI been able to successfully advocate for a Central law for street vendors with a view to protect the fundamental right of livelihood of street vendors. The Bill is at present under discussion in the Parliament. It is the credibility based on sustained work on this issue that has now placed NASVI in a position to deepen its work with Central and State Government.

In this phase of support NASVI will focus on building institutional capacities of NASVI to evolve into a national forum of street vendor federations in the country and supporting the member organisations to move towards autonomous functioning and self reliance. The other area of focus is to increase leadership capacities of women vendor members and promote women vendor federations in 6 states

NASVI, which was formed in 1998 as an informal network of 20 street vendor organisations, was formally established in 2003 when it was registered as a society.

As key partner of the Unitarian Universalist Holdeen Hivos Just India Fund [UUHHJIF] working on the issues of informal sector workers, NASVI will make important contributions to Result Area 1 of Hivos' Rights and Citizenship Programme: excluded and marginalised citizens claim space for participation and full citizenship.
New Association of Street Vendors of India - NASVI
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening institutional capacities of member organisations of SEWA and providing support towards livelihood development in 5 regions across 4 States of the country
description:
SEWA Bharat is a national federation of Self-Employed Women’s Associations [SEWAs], which are essentially people’s organsiations of self-employed workers and women in the unorganised/informal sector across India. 

SEWA Bharat seeks to actively engage with women workers who have no fixed employer or employer-employee relationship and to build their collective identity. These women workers are engaged in professions such as agriculture, fruit and vegetable vending, construction work, tailoring, embroidery work, silk weaving etc. The objective of the federation is organise women workers in the informal sector for employment and for self reliance in decision making. 

SEWA Bharat’s strategy includes organising women workers, facilitating access to social security and, microfinance including insurance, capacity building of women workers, training, facilitation support, business development services, education, media outreach and lobbying with the government for better policies at the national and state level. SEWA's members campaign for justice, visibility, and for recognition of their place in the economy. In parallel, the members are involved in building and strengthening their own women’s organisations, unions, and producer groups/companies. These organisations create employment opportunities, develop financial services, undertake trainings, and ensure members’ access to health and child care, housing and child care. 

.SEWA Bharat was formed in 1984 as a federation to bring together the various SEWAs, and to support them as and when needed. SEWA Bharat was built on the momentum created by the ‘SEWA movement’. In 1972, the first registered trade union of women informal sector workers named SEWA [Self-Employed Women’s Association] was established in Gujarat. SEWA was formed with the contention that a union was needed to promote unity amongst workers as there was no relationship between employer-employee in the case of informal and home-based workers. SEWA [Gujarat] and SEWA Bharat have derived their inspiration from the labour, cooperative and women’s movements. 

SEWA Bharat has made critical contributions to women informal sector workers in India by providing opportunities for improvement in incomes, empowering women for decision-making and creating a strong regional and national identity for its members. SEWA Bharat has succeeded in its objective of developing new SEWAs; strengthening smaller SEWAs; facilitating linkages for and between SEWAs; and building a national identity for SEWAs. SEWA Bharat has a membership of more than 1,300,000 women members with 15 units across New Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Uttrakhand, Bihar, Gujarat, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal and Kerala.

In the period 2012-13, Sewa Bharat will work towards strengthening institutional capacities of member organisations of SEWA and providing support towards livelihood development in 5 regions across 4 States of the country (Delhi, Rajasthan, Uttrakhand and West Bengal).  It will also focus on lobbying and advocacy for better implementation of laws and schemes related to worker entitlements benefiting at least 3, 16,000 women workers. 

SEWA Bharat was established as a trust in 1984, 12 years after the establishment of the first SEWA in Gujarat. 

As a UUHHJIF partner, SEWA Bharat’s work will contribute to the ability of excluded and marginalised citizens to claim space for participation and full citizenship - an important goal of Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Ensuring single women in Jharkhand have better access to their rights and entitlements and their right to a violence free life is protected
description:
SHARC [Samuel Hahnemann Associates and Research Centre] is a civil society organisation based in Hazaribagh, Jharkhand, which works with rural women and adolescent girls from marginalised and minority communities.

The objective of the organisation is to lay the foundation for a society that reflects the principles of equality and justice, without discrimination on the basis of gender, caste, religion etc. SHARC engages in the following areas: socio-economic development of women through the creation of Self-Help Groups [SHGs], women’s empowerment and leadership development, health and education, and on the protection of the environment., ENSS Jharkhand presently has a  general membership of 14,423 women.

In 2005, SHARC facilitated the formation of a state-wide coalition ‘Ekal Nari Sashakti Sangathan [ENSS] Jharkhand or the ‘Association of Empowered Single Women’. ENSS Jharkhand was formed to take up the issues of widowed, separated, single and abandoned women in the state, who were facing, and continue to face a range of problems – social ostracisation, lack of property rights, lack of food security, vulnerability to atrocities, lack of access to government schemes and entitlements, illiteracy, poverty etc. SHARC  took inspiration from the pioneering effort of Astha Sansthan in creating the ‘Association of Strong Women Alone’ in Rajasthan. 

ENSS Jharkhand has been successful in developing a collective identity for widowed, separated and single women and has provided them a platform to take up various issues. Their important achievements over the past few years include the following: 86 widowed, single and separated women filed nominations for the local self-government elections, with 17 winning their seats; 20791 applications for various government schemes were filed, with 5272 women benefitting; and more than 200 cases were filed in courts on behalf of single women. Due to its policy/advocacy initiatives, the Jharkhand government announced priorities for single women in various  policies, and  single women were included as a separate category in the state government’s draft policy for Women and Child Development. ENSS Jharkhand is now an active member of the National Forum for Single Women’s Rights.

In this phase of support ENSS will work towards strengthening and expanding its membership, building the leadership capacities of community leaders towards advocacy and lobbying and ensuring single women get access to their land.

SHARC was formally registered  in 1996.

As a UUHHJIF partner, SHARC will contribute to Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme's goal of enabling excluded and marginalised citizens to claim space for participation and full citizenship.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Develop a strong line of young Dalit leadership and build their perspective, capacities and skills to advance Dalit rights within grassroot level initiatives in Tamil Nadu
description:
Dalit Foundation’s mission is to be a partner in the struggle to eliminate caste-based discrimination and ensure equality and equal rights for all. Dalit Foundation focuses on working for the rights of Dalit communities, especially Dalit women and the scavenging communities.

The caste system which is based on the notion of purity and pollution has plagued the Indian society for almost 3000 years. The Dalits occupy the lowest position in this social system of segregation. Subjected to the practice of untouchability and social discrimination, they are not only denied access to common property (water, land) but are also denied equal opportunities in education and work. 

The main objectives of DF are to eradicate untouchability, social discrimination and caste-based atrocities with special focus on Dalit women and the scavenging community; strengthen Dalit livelihoods (minimum wages for labourers in the unorganized sector) and assist communities reclaim rights over common property and other means of production. 

Their interventions are mainly the following- supporting initiatives led by Dalits, strengthening existing initiatives with grants; promoting and supporting Dalit leaders through fellowships; training of Dalit Youths on perspective building, and project management; training of Dalit individuals from professional institutions and capacity building of partner organisations and fellows. 

Strengthening Dalit movement and building youth leadership is one of the key  focus areas of Dalit Foundation. In the last five years they  have identified  and mentored 143 leaders  of the Dalit movement across 15 states of the country with at least 40 % of these leaders being women. In the past four years Dalit Foundation has been supporting initiatives to advance Dalit rights in 19 states of the country.

In this phase of support Dalit Foundation will focus on developing a strong line of young Dalit leadership and building their perspective, capacities and skills to advance Dalit rights within grassroot level initiatives in Tamil Nadu

Dalit Foundation (DF) was registered on June 2003 at the Public Trust office at Ahmedabad

As a UUHHJIF partner, Dalit Foundation will contribute to Hivos’ Rights and Citizenship Programme's goal of enabling excluded and marginalised citizens to claim space for participation and full citizenship

title: Document best processes and practices in the implementation of the MGNREGA in Andhra Pradesh that can be replicated across the country
description:
Centre for Environment and Food Security (CEFS) was founded with the broad objective of knowledge based activism on issues of poverty, hunger, food security, sustainable development and ecological security. Research, advocacy and campaign on these issues are the core mandate of CEFS.

 The other objectives are: to disseminate awareness about environment and food security; to build a resource centre on environment, food security and sustainable livelihoods; to conduct intensive campaigns with media to highlight issues of environment and food security; and to promote strategies for conservation of natural and human managed bio-diversity, which have implications for food and human security. 

CEFS has over the past five years carried out field studies on the performance of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) in Bihar, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh, parts of which have been supported by Hivos. CEFS survey reports have been widely acknowledged by government departments, ministries; various official inquiries were undertaken, several questions in Indian Parliament were asked on these reports and these reports have got unprecedented media coverage. The Supreme Court has accepted the findings of CEFS and many landmark decisions have been taken at state and national levels to improve the implementation of MGREGS and to improve the lives of millions in these states.

Considering the state of Andhra Pradesh has managed to ensure relatively better implementation of MGNREGA the Supreme Court has asked the CEFS to explore the best practices in the implementation of the MGNREGA in Andhra Pradesh that can be replicated across the country. The focus of this year’s support is to enable CEFS to document best processes and practices in the planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the NREGS in Andhra Pradesh. Just India Fund supports CEFS for its approach and work to promote citizen participation and ownership to promote transparency and accountability in governance.

The Centre for Environment and Food Security (CEFS) was founded in April 2001 by eminent scholars, writers, environmentalists, scientists and activists.
CENTRE FOR ENVIRONMENT AND FOOD SECURITY

title: Revitalising Rainfed Agriculuture: Implementing Comprehensive Pilots in Jawadhu hills block in Tiruvannamalai district of Tamilnadu
description:
Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems (CIKS) works towards strengthening and revitalization of Indian Knowledge Systems with particular focus on sustainable agriculture and traditional knowledge based health care systems. Broad areas of CIKS’ interests and interventions are Biodiversity Conservation, Organic Agriculture and Vrkshayurveda (Science of discovering the traditional Indian agricultural practices). Apart from this, CIKS has been taking initiatives as thematic node on Seed under RRA Network.  CIKS initiatives in biodiversity conservation have helped farmers in Tamil Nadu conserve over 180 indigenous seed varieties - hence protecting the dwindling genetic base and giving farmers a way to beat stress situations. The solutions developed and provided by CIKS under Organic agriculture has helped many farmers to switch over from chemical farming.

The activities of CIKS can broadly be classified into research and extension work. The research activity comprises work on the dedicated experimental farm, actual field experiments, and mining knowledge from ancient texts and local folklore. The extension work comprises training programmes and production of educational material. Under this, CIKS is undertaking action research, training and extension on various aspects of organic farming, research on cultivation of organic rice, cotton, oil seeds, vegetables etc. It has set up rural gene banks for the conservation of traditional seed varieties, developed the use of biological control agents for the control of pests in different agro ecosystems, research on the applications of Vrksh Ayurveda (traditional Indian plant science). It has also set-up an organic farming resources centre which would act as a clearing house for information on organic practices. It has been marketing the organic produce locally under the brand name of Arogyam. 

CIKS was registered as a Trust in 1995 with five founding Trustees and four additional Trustees were inducted subsequently. The board comprises of scientists, industrialists, academicians, an advocate and a medical doctor.

CIKS works in 10 districts of Tamil Nadu covering about 12,400 acres of land under organic cultivation. It works directly and indirectly with about 13,00,000 farmers(9,00,000 men+4,00,000 women) mainly related to sustainable agriculture. Over the last 17 years, its action research with farmers has demonstrated that apart from reducing the costs of cultivation, organic agriculture enhances the food and nutritional security of the small and marginal farmers. The community seed banks have managed to conserve seeds of a large number of traditional varieties of paddy and vegetables, which has been an empowering experience, especially for the community women.

Implementing the comprehensive pilot of RRA, CIKS will be contributing in generating the evidence to support the policy agenda of RRA advocating for enhanced and differentiated investment in rainfed agriculture.
CIKS: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems

title: Promotion and Establishment of one Farmer Producer Organisation in Pudukkottai, Tamilnadu.
description:
ROSE has planned to establish a Farmer Producer Organisation (FPO) in Pudukkottai district of Tamilnadu. The FPO will be registered as a Producer Company with 750 members as shareholders for aggregation and collective marketing of the produces. This project will help the small producers who are increasingly leaving dry land farming to continue farming to ensure food security and increase income flow. 

ROSE has been working with the small farmers   in the area for the past few years with the support of NABARD and other NGO donors for promoting organic farming and collective marketing and has good rapport with the farmers in the intervention area. As part of their intervention, about 1000 small farmers in the semi-arid region is trained in organic production of paddy and minor millets and aggregated the produces and has initiated  marketing in a small way. However, ROSE did not have the required finances to move further and register a FPO and move forward in furthering their intervention. 

As part of this project, ROSE will:
•	Establish and register a FPO with  750 small farmers through a democratic process
•	Train farmers in sustainable / organic production technologies
•	 Develop business plan and establish markets for the produces
•	Support the FPO in value addition of the produces

ROSE was registered as a trust in 1993 by a group of young volunteers who consisted of farmers and social activists. The focus of ROSE is to work for the empowerment of marginalized communities such as: women, children, small farmers, unorganized laborers and dalits through education and awareness campaigns.
Rural Organization for Social Education - ROSE
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Promotion and Establishment of one Farmer Producer Organisation in Mandla district of  Madhya Pradesh.
description:
UDYOGINI is proposing to establish a FPO with 1500 poultry tribal women to improve productivity and establish markets for the products to improve the beneficiaries income levels.  The project will support women to have additional income apart from their normal income from agriculture and other activities. Under this project women will be empowered to manage their own FPO with the support of professionals would be managing the FPO. 

The partner has been working with tribal women to make them  as entrepreneurs in the rural area through formation of SHGs, Federations and skill trainings. Through this project women will be trained in improved and low cost poultry production technologies. The Partner is implementing the project with the following objectives;
1. Creation of livelihood opportunities through Backyard poultry promotion for 1500 tribal women and
2. Design and implement a community owned sustainable livelihood model around backyard poultry

UDYOGINI was established in 1992 and an non - profit organisation, as business development service organisation to support NGOs and women in Central and Northern India. The partner has experience in: Enterprise training to women producers, Value chain development to empower women to do collective marketing and developing market linkages for agriculture, poultry and hadicrafts.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening Food Security of Women Farmers in Vellore district in Tamil Nadu
description:
Women’s Collective is a collective of rural women spread over in 15 districts in Tamil Nadu promoting the socio-economic and political rights of women, children and elders of marginalized communities.

Women’s Collective was formed with five or six smaller organisations coming together by a process facilitated by Ms. Sheelu Francis in 1994. The process which was very intensive took about 8 years for the groups to come under the umbrella of Women’s Collective and form grassroot federations of member collectives in districts. They are a membership based organisation with a present membership of 26,078 women members. The executive board and the core group that is responsible for planning and implementation comprise of elected members from the collective. They have about 32 unit offices in 15 districts of Tamil Nadu. Their constituency is largely landless Dalit women.

Women’s Collective has intensively worked on issues of women rights such as violence against women, political participation of women in village councils and strengthening food security of women farmers. Over the last few years they have addressed at least 760 cases of violence against women and enabled more than 200 women to get elected in village councils. Their work on collective farming and millet cultivation has received recognition and yielded positive interventions from the government. Women’s Collective is the recipient of 2013 Food Sovereignty Prize from the US Food Sovereignty Alliance. Along with Millet network of India, Women’s Collective has played a major role to ensure millets are included as subsidised food grains in the public distribution system.

The focus of this year’s support is to enable 500 Dalit women farmers to organise themselves to undertake collective farming, build community seed banks and  work with their respective village councils to improve awareness and interventions on food security and other agriculture related issues faced especially by women’s farmers.

The Just India Fund supports Women’s Collective due to its ability to enhance the participation and promote the socio-economic rights of marginalised women especially in the area of food security.

Women’s Collective is registered under the Tamil Nadu Societies registration Act 1975 in 2001
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Promotion and Establishment of one Farmer Producer Organisation in Vishakapatinam district of , Andhra Pradesh.
description:
Kovel Foundation proposes to promote a FPO with 500 tribal farmers who are producing - Pipal Modi (Piper longum), medicinal plant,  to promote collective marketing. During the project period the FPO would registered, the farmers trained in better production practices, management of the FPO and marketing of their produces.  The project will enable the producers to get higher profit margins which would improve their standard of lives. 

The partner has been working with tribal farmers in Andhra Pradesh since several years and has established SHGs and federations to support the beneficiaries. During the contract period the partner will establish a registered FPO, Train the beneficiaries and the staff  in better production technologies, quality control, FPO management, develop business plan and establish markets for Piper longum. The partner is already working with tribal farmers and have tried to market the produces but does not have the financial resources to take the initiative forward. 

Kovel Foundation is a non-profit organisation registered in 1994 with the objective supporting NTFP gatherers whoare  primarily tribal people who are exploited by the public and private actors. Along with the government and other actors the partner has supported the tribal families in production and marketing of various NTFP products.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthening Women led collectives and undertaking advocacy on issues of women's rights in Chattisgarh
description:
Nivedita Foundation is guided by what it refers to as ‘alternative development thinking and practice’ while implementing various programmes with Dalits, tribals, women, and children and initiating and working with groups, forums and organisations in Orissa and Chattisgarh.

In 2007, Nivedita Foundation expanded its operations to neighboring Chattisgarh, where it was instrumental in setting up the state-level women’s forum Chattisgarh Mahila Manch [CMM].  CMM, which comprises individual activists and women’s collectives, has framed its interventions within a feminist philosophy of equality and a life of dignity and respect for all. Nivedita Foundation/CMM has made significant progress in altering the power relations in favour of women in its working area, which currently comprises of 10 districts. The membership of CMM has increased from 1361 to 4448 members from 2011 to 2013

Some of it significant interventions in 2012 include building the leadership capacity of 36 grassroot women elected leaders of local governance bodies in Chattisgarh. CMM members helped 290 women to secure joint land titles with their husbands, thereby protecting their property rights as women. CMM has monitored of the implementation of various government schemes and policies like the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act and the Forest Rights Act. In addition to strategic inputs in helping women get elected to Panchayat Raj institutions and tackling the issue of land displacement, activists from Nivedita Foundation/CMM have assisted women to seek legal recourse in cases of violence and discrimination. Their state level advocacy on issues of alcoholism and violence against women has resulted in positive interventions by the State machineries.

The focus of this year’s support is to enable CMM to undertake an intensive organization development process that would help them to consolidate and strengthen their structure and systems at both state and district levels. The focus is also to strengthen the leadership capacities of the local collectives affiliated to CMM so that they move towards greater autonomy and self reliance.

Nivedita Foundation’s planned activities and outputs for CMM, and its specific focus on women’s rights, are in close agreement with the programme priorities of the Just India Fund.

Nivedita Foundation is registered as a trust in 2004 in Kalahandi District in Orissa.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Strengthen the Adivasi women led collective and ensure better advocacy on PESA in Chattisgarh
description:
Jashpur Jan Vikas Sanstha (JJVS) works towards promoting the social, political and economical rights of Adivasi women in. Chattisgarh.

JJVS nurtures the Adivasi Mahila Mahasabha (AMM) which organises Adivasi women to protect their rights and also engages in state level advocacy to ensure better implementation of laws related to Adivasi communities. AMM has a total membership of about 10000 Adivasi women across the districts of Jashpur, Sarguja, and Raigadh in North Chattisgarh. The birth and growth of AMM as a collective has been a slow and organic one since it is a completely community owned and managed structure. Given that the local women speak only the dialects of Agariya and Bagheli the process of mobilising and collectivising these women and building their leadership skills to interface and negotiate their rights with both the state as well as within their communities has been a long journey. Over the past years AMM's biggest success has been in starting a public debate within the Tribal community on women's ownership of assets (land, income etc) and the success of the Anti-Liquor Campaign in Gholeng panchayat which made them a prominent name in the civil society of Chattisgarh.

The focus of this phase of support is to build capacities of 20 new community based organisations and community leaders to ensure better advocacy on Adivasi related issues.

Just India Fund the joint fund of Hivos and the USA-based Holdeen India Programme supports JJVS because of its specific focus on nurturing and supporting new and young women's and human rights community based organisation.

Jashpur Jan Vikas Sanstha (JJVS) is the registered as a society in 2003 with seven women as its board members.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Analysing nutritional value of traditional paddy
description:
The Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems (CIKS) works to strengthen and revitalize Indian Knowledge Systems with a particular focus on sustainable agriculture and traditional knowledge based health care systems. Broad areas of CIKS’ interests and interventions are Biodiversity Conservation, Organic Agriculture and Vrkshayurveda (Science of discovering the traditional Indian agricultural practices). CIKS initiatives in agricultural biodiversity conservation have helped farmers in Tamil Nadu conserve over 180 indigenous seed varieties - hence protecting the dwindling genetic base and giving farmers a way to adapt to a changing environment. 

The activities of CIKS can broadly be classified into research and extension work. Research activities include work on their experimental farm, field experiments, and revitalizing knowledge from ancient texts and local folklore. The extension work includes training programmes and production of educational material on various aspects of organic farming and cultivation of organic rice, cotton, oil seeds and vegetables. CIKS has set up rural gene banks for the conservation of traditional seed varieties, developed the use of biological control agents for the control of pests in different agro ecosystems and researched the applications of Vrksh Ayurveda (traditional Indian plant science). It has also set-up an organic farming resources centre on organic practices and has been marketing organic produce locally under the brand name of Arogyam. 

By documenting, testing and validating the nutritional and therapeutic properties of Indigenous paddy varieties of India (specifically Tamil Nadu State) based on farmer knowledge, indigenous knowledge sources and biochemical testing, CIKS will contribute to generating insights into the opportunities and challenges of a Multiple-Evidence-Base approach to promote the conservation, management and use of agricultural biodiversity for resilient farming systems.
CIKS: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Agricultural biodiversity advocacy in India
description:
Development of Humane (DHAN) Foundation [DF] is a professional development organisation incorporated as a Trust under the Indian Trust Act (1882) on 2 October 1997. Its mission is - "Building people and institutions for development innovations and scaling up to enable the poor communities for poverty reduction and self-reliance”.  The Foundation works towards bringing significant changes in the livelihoods of the poor through innovations in themes and institutions. The broad purposes for which DF works are as follows - 1. To promote and nurture new ideas on development themes; 2. Promoting Institutions to reach scale; 3. To bring young professionals into the development sector. 

Agricultural biodiversity is the cornerstone of agriculture and sustainable livelihoods. Many organisations and individuals have been working to enhance the conservation, management and use of agricultural biodiversity for the past decades. However, most of these initiatives have not been able to scale up and remain in the margins. 
Key to the wider adoption of promising models is political buy-in by decision makers in government bodies. There is a need to invest in building positive attitudes and knowledge with decision makers to motivate them to act in their spheres of responsibility.  In India, there are three precedents on how positive attitude and knowledge on the part of decision makers can lead to large scale adoption. They are 1) Self help group (SHG) model of financial inclusion of the unorganised poor, 2) Watershed based development through community organisations and 3) Joint forest management. There is an opportunity to adopt a similar approach to rally the support of policy makers to scale up agricultural biodiversity initiatives.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Developing an open source seed system
description:
Centre for Sustainable Agriculture is a professional resource organization engaged in establishing models of sustainable agriculture working in partnership with NGOs and Community Based Organizations by scaling up the successes and engaging with the establishment for a policy change. 

CSA believes in promoting sustainable agricultural technologies that are based on farmers’ knowledge and skills, their innovation based on local conditions and their use of nature’s products and processes to gain better control over the pre-production and production processes involved in agriculture. CSA works with farmers to conserve their resources and their rights. 

The seed sector in India (and globally) is increasingly driven by proprietary controls, turning seed into a ‘commercial proprietary resource’. This trend has severe impacts on farmers and their informal seed systems, resulting in increased economic and ecological costs and making farmers lose their control over their productive resources.  The existing legal framework in India primarily upholds breeders' and researchers' rights, granting farmers only residual rights. 

The development of an Open Source Seed System provides an alternative institutional and legal framework which protects farmers’ interests and ensures free access the germplasm.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes;OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Analysing scale up of biodiversity-based farming
description:
Centre for Sustainable Agriculture is a professional resource organization engaged in establishing models of sustainable agriculture working in partnership with NGOs and Community Based Organizations by scaling up the successes and engaging with the establishment for a policy change. 

CSA believes in promoting sustainable agricultural technologies that are based on farmers’ knowledge and skills, their innovation based on local conditions and their use of nature’s products and processes to gain better control over the pre-production and production processes involved in agriculture. CSA works with farmers to conserve their resources and their rights.

Great initiatives that build on agricultural biodiversity to increase resilience in farming systems can be found all over the world, but often they do not change things at a larger scale. Why is that? Why don't they make a bigger difference? How can we make sure that they have greater impact? A better understanding is needed of the factors that enable the successful scaling up of positive change for more resilient farming systems.

Developing a conceptual framework and criteria on good practice for agro-biodiversity based resilient farming, identifying cases where such practices have successfully reached scale and analysing their preconditions and impact, can generate insights that can help these solutions to transform from local islands of success into strategies that are transferable to other places and other contexts.
sector.vocabulary: OECD Development Assistance Committee 3 digit codes

title: Transforming small producers organizations into Enterprises
description:
Welthungerhilfe is the implementing partner of the TAFS program (Technical Assistance Facility & Services for transforming small Producers Organization's into Enterprises) in India. 

This program aims to enable small/marginal farmers (having 5 acres or less land) including tenant farmers and share croppers to become self-reliant producers. This is to be achieved by creating greater opportunities for these farmers - through Producer Organizations (POs) - to access financial services and markets. This will lead to increased incomes and employment. 

Rain-fed agriculture, climate change, poverty and food insecurity characterize the Indian countryside. These small producers are dependent on traders, input suppliers and moneylenders for growing their crops.  There is clear evidence  that producers organized as Producer Organizations have the capacity to set up successful businesses, break dependency relations and contribute to poverty reduction and food security through environmentally friendly production. There is also clear evidence that access to proper technical assistance (TA) and working capital is one of the principal problems to scale up. Producer Organisations are not victims, but the agents of change. The program expects to improve the living conditions for over 25,500 producer families representing approximately  127,500 rural people in India

Welthungerhilfe is a German development organization and just like Hivos a member of Alliance 2015. This is a network of eight European non government organizations engaged in humanitarian and development activities.

title: Learning from Practice: Case Study of the Stop Child Labour Campaign
